column12: Ability
column13: Flavor Text
column18: If you see something in this Master Spreadsheet that you know is incorrect, message me at any of the Pirates CSG community sites or a7xfanben@gmail.com.  Thanks!

column12: Other ships do not block this ship's line of fire.
column13: The Revenant ("one who returns after death") is an appropriate name for the mysterious flagship of Capitán El Fantasma and his ghostly crew.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The Snipe is a fast and agile sloop whose speed is her best defense. Jack Hawkins used the Snipe to capture the Sea Nymph.

column12: You own any derelict this ship explores; both ships become docked at your home island.
column13: The very sight of the black sails of Blackheart's flagship has caused ships to strike their colors and surrender.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The Zephyr was the sloop that Calico Cat stole from Havana. Her crew is made up of the most deadly fighters Havana's slums have ever produced.

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Taking the El Aquilino—now renamed the Shadow—launched Calico Cat into prominence. How she managed to take such a large ship is still a mystery, but the Cat now has more firepower in her quest for revenge.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Mastered by the mysterious and beautiful Crimson Angel, the Pandora spreads death and destruction. Unlike the evils spread by the mythological relic, however, Crimson Angel's plunderings are capricious: Some ships suffer only theft, while others are wiped out.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: The Revenge was known as HMS Sedgewick before she was liberated by Genny Gallows, who gave the ship a new purpose: sending the English to their maker.

column12: When this ship sinks another ship, you may repair one of this ship's masts.
column13: The Thief is mastered by Robert Fagan, a London street urchin who leveraged a life of petty crime into one of piracy. Fagan remembers his poor days well, ordering his crew to strip targets of every scrap before letting them sink.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S.
column13: After Captain Jack Hawkins was "asked" to leave the Ballista, he worked his way back to prominence by taking the El Gama Larga, which he renamed the Sea Nymph as an insult to his former crew.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: Captain Luc de Card won the Silverback in a card game. Ironically, he later lost the French warship when he bet three kings against a full house. He remarked ruefully that he should have known better than to depend on kings, of all people.

column12: This ship's base move becomes S when she reaches her cargo limit.
column13: The El Pájaro Relleno was Master Bianco's favorite ship before she was captured. He once said, "Given time, I could hide most of Spain in her enormous hold."

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: The Freedom's Captain James avoids stand-up fights. As he says, "Cannons are indiscriminate: They might hurt me—not just my crew!" Sneaking into port and stealing is much more his style.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down treasure on any island.
column13: The tall crows nests of the Raven's Neck provide excellent vantage points for the spotting of treasure and targets.

column12: Forts cannot shoot at this ship.
column13: The Windjammer's nimble nature makes her a tough target, but at the cost of reduced firepower.

column12: On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew from the enemy ship.
column13: Under Spain's control, the El Ballista was considered unbeatable, but Jack Hawkins won her without firing a shot. He wanted to name her the Sea Nymph in honor of his female accomplices, but his crew decided to keep the name and lose Hawkins instead.

column12: Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Sailed by a crew of buccaneers who became sharpshooters while hunting illegal game, the Recreant prefers to first eliminate enemy officers in a fight to reduce her prey's effectiveness.

column12: English ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: The Treachery earned her name and the eternal hatred of Her Majesty's Navy when she "guided" the fleet over a reef that splintered their hulls. Her crew later returned and looted the wrecked ships.

column12: This ship may never load the last treasure from an island.
column13: Although they are excellent gunners, the crew of the Longshanks do not coordinate well on any other tasks, including the gathering of treasure.

column12: Spanish ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: The Boy," formally the El Gregorio, was a member of the armada that guarded the annual treasure fleet from Tierra Firma to Spain. Her capitan, Oro Navarro, sold the fleet's location to Blackheart, and no Spaniard will rest until Navarro and his crew are dead.

column12: When this ship carries no cargo, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: No crew trims sails like this ship's, and when her hull is empty she sprints like her namesake. Her accurate fore and aft guns were made by WeaponmMaster Charles Southwyn.

column12: Eliminate one of this ship's masts when she rolls a 1 on any cannon roll.
column13: The Carrion Crow has not had the best of luck recently, as Fernando Sanchez has twice attacked and damaged her. The result is that the ship has no money and is becoming run down.

column12: You own any derelict this ship explores; both ships become docked at your home island.
column13: The Gilded One was known as the San Salvador before David "Bones" Wylie won her on a lucky die roll. His crew's talents complement his luck, with several qualified captains among them.

column12: Spanish crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The Royal Fortune seeks to deliver what her name implies. Manned by both buccaneers and ex-Spanish sailors, she preys on the royal fleets of all nations.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Spanish ships.
column13: Death to the Crown was so named by Gaspar Zuan to appease his brother's bloodlust for the throne of Spain.

column12: English crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The Bonny Kate is a welcoming berth to any British lad who will take an oath against all kings.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: Narrow of beam and light of sail, the Batavian Bat is very nimble, but not fantastically fast. She prefers to engage from long range, making her a tough target.

column12: This ship sinks when her last mast is eliminated.
column13: Nothing ventured, nothing gained. The Venture carries more gunpowder than she should in order to double pack her guns for better range. But that makes her a potential fireworks display.

column12: This ship gets +L to her base move if she has all of her masts.
column13: The Silver Dagger was taken from the Dutch near the island of St. Barts. She is swift when undamaged, but slothful when wounded. To prevent being slowed, she has excellent cannons stolen from the Spanish

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Calico Cat (real name rumored to be Catherine) got her start only recently by stealing a Spanish sloop from Havana. She leads her crew with a dazzling smile that belies her deadly determination. Her anonymous past cannot hide her suffering, and she intends to make the crowns of Europe suffer as well.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action.
column13: Angus Skyme came to the Spanish Main in the brig of HMS Prudence. He escaped the gallows and gathered the roughest crew in the Caribbean. Blackheart shows no quarter to his victims or crew, and he has killed many of both for his amusement and profit. He still bears the scar from the duel he fought with Hawkins over Lady Arcadia de Sol.

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Sailing into and out of the mists, El Fantasma uses stealth as his major weapon. None know for sure whether he and his crew are even human—they seem to appear and disappear at will and are almost impossible to hit with cannons.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.  On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew from the enemy ship.
column13: Hawkins was an expert marksman and poacher until he was caught and shipped to Port Royal as an indentured servant. Blackheart liberated Hawkins when he sacked Port Royal, and the pair was dynamic until a dispute over Lady Arcadia de Sol. Hawkins won the girl, but also a powerful enemy.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
One of this ship's treasures is worth +2 gold when she docks at your home island.
column13: Captain Gallows has hated England since the day she watched her father's neck stretched. She will attack any ship, but relishes hurting England the most. Her crew would follow her to the gates of hell, both because of her leadership and her connections on the Spanish Main.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks.
column13: Some say the Ghost Crew are damned men cursed to sail these waters until they send enough souls to hell to get theirs back. Others say that El Fantasma and his crew are human, just tricky enough to terrify their opponents before they fire the first shot.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
Once per turn, if this ship carries treasure and is within S of an enemy ship, you may randomly trade one treasure with that ship.
column13: Wiley was raised and groomed for command by the dread pirate Rodriguez. When Rodriguez was killed in combat, Wiley was paralyzed by his new post. So he carved two dice out of Rodriguez's skull, allowing his mentor to guide him even in death.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Spanish ships.
column13: Fidel Zuan loves his brother, Gaspar. He reminded himself of that every day he rotted in a Spanish prison. After finally freeing him, his brother "explained" that Fidel had been falsely accused and wrongfully imprisoned. Fidel now fights the Spanish like the devil himself.

column12: This ship gains one rank 3 cannon with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: Lady Arcadia de Sol gifted this monkey to Jack after he saved her from Blackheart. Jack renamed him Skyme in honor of his old partner, but wishes that he hadn't: The monkey seems to have picked up some of Blackheart's more evil mannerisms.

column12: This ship gains one rank 3 cannon with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
column13: Bones often has Lucky fly to a ship to see what she holds. When Lucky returns, it uses its claws to "roll" dice into a stein, determining if the ship will be spared or pursued. Potential victims know that to shoot at Lucky would result in Wiley killing them and everyone they've ever met, so they leave their fate to the dice.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Genny Gallows' crew have been known to kill each other for the right to wear cloth torn from the curtains of the Red Curtain bordello, which signifies membership in the Red Rampage boarding party. Rumor is that the banshees who survive a tour are treated to a night at the Red Curtain.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
Place this crew face up during setup. Reduce the cost of all other crew placed on this ship by 1.
column13: Gaspar was given the El Picador by Spain to hunt English pirates, and his brother Fidel was kept hostage to ensure his return. But Gaspar betrayed them both by attacking the Spanish treasure fleet. Gaspar can talk anyone into joining him, even his brother. One day his lies will catch up with him, but that day is not today.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: HMS Titan, the largest English ship on the Spanish Main, is the only ship that has ever wounded the mysterious Revenant. Admiral Lord Battonbrig commands the Titan with iron discipline.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S.
column13: HMS Albion is an excellent scouting sloop. She especially shines in slow waters, sailing circles around more bulky vessels.

column12: This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her masts.
column13: HMS Lord Algernon is constructed of double-planked American colonial hardwood, making her slow but almost cannon proof. She has come to the Spanish Main to support attacks on Spanish interests.

column12: Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: The crew of the sloop HMS Europa live in fear that Commander Temple will again come aboard on a scouting mission.

column12: This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: HMS Leicester is currently the English fleet's most effective gunship. She features batteries of a new cannon type designed by Weapon-master Charles Southwyn.

column12: This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: HMS Oxley features heavy cannons that can splinter an enemy mast in a single broadside. The downside is that the guns are too heavy for the crew to maneuver quickly, reducing accuracy.

column12: If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: HMS King Edward, the most modern English ship in the Caribbean, is often the flagship of larger naval actions. When a senior officer is on board, her crew excels—especially her gun crew.

column12: This ship's cannons may not be eliminated (masts still may be). If derelict, she cannot shoot.
column13: Ironsides Exeter, as she is known to many in the Caribbean, has plate iron surrounding all her gun decks. This makes her cannons almost impossible to destroy, but her speed and cargo capacity suffer as a result.
HMS Dover is the standard of Her Majesty's Navy. She is large, well armed, has above-average cargo capacity, and is capable of reasonable speed.

column12: Other ships do not block this ship's line of fire.
column13: Captain McGrath is not the most flamboyant of commanders, but his gun crew is among the best on the Spanish Main thanks to his endless training.

column12: When this ship sinks another ship, you may repair one of this ship's masts.
column13: HMS Gallowglass is manned by many ex-cons, including several "Bones" Wylie's crew. These men can strip valuables from sinking ships and barely get their feet wet.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: HMS Birkenhead was part of several of Sir Myngs' insertions into Spanish ports. It was outfitted with spikes and guillotine lines to aid in the repelling of boarding parties.

column12: You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: The guns of HMS Meresman have the longest range on the Spanish Main.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: HMS Wycliffe was constructed in the shipyards of Boston of incredibly strong American hardwoods. It is said that she can withstand being rammed by any ship on the Spanish Main.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: HMS Plantagenet is a small, mercurial ship able to sail in shallow waters and up streams. This pirate hunter is manned exclusively by men who have lost everything to pirates.

column12: When this ship hits another ship, you choose which mast is eliminated.
column13: HMS Lord Walpole's gun crew was personally trained by Thomas Gunn, so suffice it to say they are good shots.

column12: Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: Henry Morgan was once a feared buccaneer. Sailing under letters of marque from Sir Myngs and Governor Modyford, he became wealthy by sacking Spanish Caribbean towns. Governor Lynch sent him to England to stand trial for his crimes, but instead he was knighted and made admiral of all the English fleets on the Spanish Main.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Myngs was sent to the Spanish Main to remove the Spanish. As usual, however, he wasn't given enough ships to do the job, so he pioneered the English-buccaneer fleet. He personally led the largest of these fleets against the Spanish and Dutch.

column12: When this ship is docked at your home island, you may eliminate one treasure. It becomes a rank 3 cannon that shoots short range and can only be eliminated when the ship sinks.
column13: Always covered in soot from his forge, "Carbon Charlie" makes some of the finest firearms in the world. His crowning achievement—the secret of which he will likely take to the grave—is the world's largest cannon.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Spanish ships.
column13: Gunn's family was sailing to Jamaica when the Spanish warship El Tirón attacked. His wife was killed, and Capitán de Alva took Gunn's 18-year-old daughter, Catherine, hostage. Gunn sold his soul to the navy for ransom money, but Spain denies any knowledge of her.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: Lynch hates pirates with a passion that defies reason. He despises Morgan for being a pirate and Myngs and Modyford for sullying the crown of England by associating with them. He often leads his fleets in pirate-hunting expeditions.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
Place this crew face up during setup. Reduce the cost of all other crew placed on this ship by 1.
column13: Countess Doone is the sweet-talking belle of English Caribbean society. Her dark secret is that she was actually shipped to the Spanish Main as an Irish indentured servant. When her ship was attacked by pirates, she took advantage of the chaos to take the possessions and personality of a rich young lady who no longer "needed" them. She has spellbound the Jamaican royal court ever since.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
Other ships do not block this ship's line of fire.
column13: Myngs' most-trusted men have been with him since he was captain of the 52-gun Marston Moor. They are well trained and have deadly aim.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action, plus. Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Gunn became a marine in His Majesty's Navy to seek revenge on the Spanish for his mother's death and sister's abduction, and he becomes more convinced every day that pirates deserve to die. His marksmanship is famous on the Main, as is his pension for keeping to himself.

column12: This ship gains one rank 3 cannon with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Brother Virgil has been a spiritual guide to island natives for many years. No one knows exactly which holy order he belongs to, but it apparently does not require a vow of poverty: The affable monk has grown rich from "gifts" received for placing crew on ships.

column12: This ship gains one rank 3 cannon with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The Noose is a special unit of the King's Marines that specializes in the bloody business of boarding actions. These men are the most loyal to Governor Lynch and his quest to rid the Caribbean of pirates.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
One of this ship's treasures is worth +1 gold when she docks at your home island.
column13: Pete is Carbon Charlie's right-hand man—mostly because he caused Charlie to lose his right arm! Powder Pete knows how to turn cannons into gold and, when they have it, gold into more gold.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
You own any derelict this ship explores; both ships become docked at your home island.
column13: Temple is the second son of an English nobleman in Ireland. Many say that his success has been greased with the blood of men he throws into hopeless situations and deadly boarding actions. His only weakness is his infatuation with the lovely Countess Doone.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
Two hits from the same shoot action are required to eliminate one of this ship's masts.
column13: The captain of "The Battleship," pride of the Spanish fleet and perhaps the strongest ship ever built, claims that not even the devil himself could sink her. The mysterious pirate El Fantasma, however, may soon test that boast.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The crew of the Santa Teresa believe that their sloop is blessed by Teresa herself, for their luck has never run out.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls for every friendly ship within S of her.
column13: This is the capital ship of the Armada de Barlavento—the special fleet assigned to rid the Spanish Main of pirates. "The Guarantor" is often under the command of Almirante del Nero, who oversees his crew's competition with the El Acorazado.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls for every friendly ship within S of her.
column13: The Repulse is a small but effective scout sloop. The confidence and performance of her small crew dramatically improve when she is part of a larger force.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: An imposing armed merchant ship, "The Jewel of the Sun" can move quickly with a large cargo. Built by a consortium of merchants, she was outfitted with decent guns, but her crew is trained in little other than repelling boarders.

column12: Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Comandante Antonio de Silva personally trained the marines on "The Gunner" to pick off enemy crew from long range. The ship has thus become famous for leaving her opponents "headless."

column12: When touching a Pirate ship, this ship may load as much of that ship's treasure as she can carry.
column13: Under Capitán Alarico Castro, "The Eagle" has earned a fearsome reputation. Castro's crew has perfected the art of ransacking and destroying their pirate enemies. It is rumored that he keeps a portion of the spoils hidden from Spain.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: The crew of the "Pirate Hunter" was literally whipped into shape by the obsessive Almirante Devante del Nero. He ensured that the only thing they hated more than him was pirates.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: Capitán Alberto Ladrón was sent from the Castilian court in disgrace, his commission as capitán the only recognition of his years of royal service. He now uses the La Resolución to prepare for his triumphant return to the royal court.

column12: When this ship hits an enemy ship, you may also eliminate one cargo from that ship.
column13: The "Ship Killer" is armed with huge bore cannons capable of devastating short-range damage. Capitán Gonzalo Mora first rose to prominence on her deck.

column12: This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: Although "The Fury" was outfitted with the same cannons as the Asesino de la Nave, she does not perform as well at short range, a fact that can be attributed only to the quality of her gun crew.

column12: If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: The Duke was once the largest Spanish ship permanently stationed in the Caribbean. Even though there are now larger ships in the area, the El Duque is still the fleet's flagship by virtue of her exceptional crew.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may move S after unloading cargo.
column13: The "Silver Fish" is fast and agile. Her crews are all ex–merchant sailors, and so they are expert cargo handlers

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S.
column13: The crew of "The Heart of the Sea" certainly live up to their ship's name: They put their hearts and backs into anything they do.
The Bullfighter was named after the story of a famous matador who went to sea after losing his leg in the arena. His spirit is said to inhabit this ship, bringing much courage to her crew.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: The capitán of "The Lion" relies on his ship's incredibly strong hull and his crew's bloodthirsty nature. In combat, he favors closing in quickly and then sending boarding parties.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a D6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Castro is a dedicated man, but ultimately not to Spain. He  "overcame" his Moorish heritage to rise to the top of the Spanish Navy, but he plots against every Castilian who has wronged him. Castro does his duty, but he patiently waits to make his move.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: Some say that de Alva's influential parents are the reason for his rapid climb in the Spanish Navy; these people do not know de Alva. His singular vision is to rid the Spanish Main of foreign holdings, starting with the English and the pirates they sponsor. De Alva's biggest weakness is becoming too "involved" with his "prizes."

column12: All of this ship's cannons have L range.
column13: Vazquez can hit a wine glass with a cannonball at 500 yards. He secretly desires to own a weapon made by the master himself, Charles Southwyn, so he searches through every treasure haul, looking for items made by the English legend.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship gets +1 cargo spaces. This crew takes up no cargo space.
column13: This quiet, unassuming man is in demand for his unrivaled cargo-packing efficiency. But only Capitán Castro knows that Bianco always packs away something extra for himself. Bianco knows that Castro will one day require payment for his secrecy.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Sanchez uses information smuggled to him by Nemesio Diaz to raid enemy ports when they are most laden with gold. Sanchez has put a price on Hawkins' head for tricking his galleon onto a reef, and he's doubled that price for Hawkins' monkey, Skyme. His expensive hatred of the monkey remains unexplained.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: Almirante del Nero, commander of the Armada de Barlavento, is a man driven almost mad by his zeal to rid the Spanish Main of pirates. To fail will be to fail his duty to God. His vision is so singular that he even secretly corresponds with his nation's enemy, Governor Lynch of Jamaica.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Over the years, Capitán Castro has surrounded himself with loyal crew. They are hardened men who fight well and don't question their orders, and Castro is betting on that when the time comes to change flags.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her masts.
column13: Joaquin Vega is a master blacksmith. His swords rival those of Castile, and his ship armor is unparalleled the world over.

column12: This ship gains one rank 3 cannon with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship may unload cargo at your home island if she's within S of it.
column13: Master Bianco has a small fleet that shuttles his secret stores from the ships in the middle of the night. The strong backs and iron arms of his Haulers help to move the cargo quickly by rowboat and to defend it from curious eyes and meddling hands.

column12: This ship gains one rank 3 cannon with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
Once per turn, cancel the ability of one crew or ship within S of this ship.
column13: Nemesio Diaz (aka William Cob, Jean Parisot la Valette, and Michel van Horn) is a true son of Spain, but he spends most of his time spying on the aristocracy of Spain's enemies. He works to defeat any who would plunder the riches that are Spain's by papal decree; that is, all of the Americas.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
When this ship hits another ship, you choose which mast is eliminated.
column13: Capitán Mora is a shark who prefers surgical strikes to the blundering tactics of the English. His instincts about the weak spot of a fleet or ship are amazing, allowing his gunners to do more damage with a single shot than other crews might do with several broadsides.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: As a King's Marine, de Silva was once one of Spain's top musketeers. When he lost his right eye to a grape-shot volley fired by Christopher Myngs' ship, he feared for his career. But he learned to shoot all over again, vowing revenge on Myngs, his pirates, and all English.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down treasure on any island.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
Cannon ranges of enemy ships are reduced to S against this ship.
Do not give this ship an action the turn after loading Rum. Rum is worth gold equal to 6 minus the number of this ship's crew when Rum was loaded.
Eliminate all crew on this ship; she cannot dock. When she touches another ship, unload Plague onto that ship.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Some claim that El Fantasma is nothing but a clever captain with a bag of tricks, but they have never seen right though him as he screamed like a banshee while cutting a man in two. That kind of thing makes you believe in the supernatural!

column12: This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks.
column13: Some tales say that the ranks of the Ghost Crew grow with every sailor they slaughter, because the only way out of the purgatory they find themselves in is to find souls to take their places.

column12: Other ships do not block this ship's line of fire.
column13: Sailing out of the mists on moonless nights, the sight of the ghostly Revenant and the agonizing howls of El Fantasma and his inhuman crew have caused many ships to surrender without a shot being fired.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The Snipe fell prey to the Revenant and became part of the ghost fleet until liberated by Jack Hawkins, who had other plans for her.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: When the Revenant appeared, Capitan Alberto Ladron's crew was paralyzed by their superstitious fear. When El Fantasma offered to "borrow" the ship rather than destroy her, Ladron had no choice but to accede. El Fantasma used her to sneak into and sack the Spanish port of Cuba. True to his word, the apparition returned Ladron's ship with a handshake. Ladron now believes in ghosts ... and his right hand is still numb.

column12: Once per turn, when this ship hits an enemy ship, you may also eliminate one cargo from that ship.
column13: When the Asesino de la Nave was captured by the Revenant after refusing to surrender, El Fantasma put the entire crew to death. When Capitan Gonzalo Mora managed to recapture the ship a year later, it was said that the screams of the dying could still be heard.

column12: You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: Long range guns are of little use when there is "nothing" to hit. HMS Meresman's gunners swear they pumped shot after shot into the Revenant - without results. HMS Meresman was part of El Fantasma's ghost fleet for almost two years.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: Unfortunately, the thick hull of HMS Wycliffe matched the thick skull of her captain. He was stupid enough to boast that his ship could withstand anything the Revenant could throw at her. When HMS Wycliffe was recaptured, her captain's skull was found implanted into the base of the main mast, staring out across the ship's deck.

column12: Once after revealing, roll a d6 for each crew on the ship. On a result of 1, that crew is eliminated. Ghostly Encounter is worth gold equal to the crew remaining on the ship after all dice are rolled.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
Other ships do not block this ship's line of fire.
column13: The pirate Blackheart is said to have decapitated Captain McGrath when he took HMS Bolingbroke from him and his crew.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: Pirates of the Spanish Main™, the first constructible strategy game™, puts naval battles and treasure hunting on your tabletop! Each Game Pack contains 2 ships, crew, treasure, 1 island, 1 die, and rules.

column12: Other ships do not block this ship's line of fire.
column13: The Revenant ("one who returns after death") is an appropriate name for the mysterious flagship of Capitán El Fantasma and his ghostly crew.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The Snipe is a fast and agile sloop whose speed is her best defense. Jack Hawkins used the Snipe to capture the Sea Nymph.

column12: You own any derelict this ship explores; both ships become docked at your home island.
column13: The very sight of the black sails of Blackheart's flagship has caused ships to strike their colors and surrender.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The Zephyr was the sloop that Calico Cat stole from Havana. Her crew is made up of the most deadly fighters Havana's slums have ever produced.

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Taking the El Aquilino—now renamed the Shadow—launched Calico Cat into prominence. How she managed to take such a large ship is still a mystery, but the Cat now has more firepower in her quest for revenge.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Mastered by the mysterious and beautiful Crimson Angel, the Pandora spreads death and destruction. Unlike the evils spread by the mythological relic, however, Crimson Angel's plunderings are capricious: Some ships suffer only theft, while others are wiped out.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: The Revenge was known as HMS Sedgewick before she was liberated by Genny Gallows, who gave the ship a new purpose: sending the English to their maker.

column12: When this ship sinks another ship, you may repair one of this ship's masts.
column13: The Thief is mastered by Robert Fagan, a London street urchin who leveraged a life of petty crime into one of piracy. Fagan remembers his poor days well, ordering his crew to strip targets of every scrap before letting them sink.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S.
column13: After Captain Jack Hawkins was "asked" to leave the Ballista, he worked his way back to prominence by taking the El Gama Larga, which he renamed the Sea Nymph as an insult to his former crew.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: Captain Luc de Card won the Silverback in a card game. Ironically, he later lost the French warship when he bet three kings against a full house. He remarked ruefully that he should have known better than to depend on kings, of all people.

column12: This ship's base move becomes S when she reaches her cargo limit.
column13: The El Pájaro Relleno was Master Bianco's favorite ship before she was captured. He once said, "Given time, I could hide most of Spain in her enormous hold."

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: The Freedom's Captain James avoids stand-up fights. As he says, "Cannons are indiscriminate: They might hurt me—not just my crew!" Sneaking into port and stealing is much more his style.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down treasure on any island.
column13: The tall crows nests of the Raven's Neck provide excellent vantage points for the spotting of treasure and targets.

column12: Forts cannot shoot at this ship.
column13: The Windjammer's nimble nature makes her a tough target, but at the cost of reduced firepower.

column12: On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew from the enemy ship.
column13: Under Spain's control, the El Ballista was considered unbeatable, but Jack Hawkins won her without firing a shot. He wanted to name her the Sea Nymph in honor of his female accomplices, but his crew decided to keep the name and lose Hawkins instead.

column12: Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Sailed by a crew of buccaneers who became sharpshooters while hunting illegal game, the Recreant prefers to first eliminate enemy officers in a fight to reduce her prey's effectiveness.

column12: English ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: The Treachery earned her name and the eternal hatred of Her Majesty's Navy when she "guided" the fleet over a reef that splintered their hulls. Her crew later returned and looted the wrecked ships.

column12: This ship may never load the last treasure from an island.
column13: Although they are excellent gunners, the crew of the Longshanks do not coordinate well on any other tasks, including the gathering of treasure.

column12: Spanish ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: The Boy," formally the El Gregorio, was a member of the armada that guarded the annual treasure fleet from Tierra Firma to Spain. Her capitan, Oro Navarro, sold the fleet's location to Blackheart, and no Spaniard will rest until Navarro and his crew are dead.

column12: When this ship carries no cargo, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: No crew trims sails like this ship's, and when her hull is empty she sprints like her namesake. Her accurate fore and aft guns were made by WeaponmMaster Charles Southwyn.

column12: Eliminate one of this ship's masts when she rolls a 1 on any cannon roll.
column13: The Carrion Crow has not had the best of luck recently, as Fernando Sanchez has twice attacked and damaged her. The result is that the ship has no money and is becoming run down.

column12: You own any derelict this ship explores; both ships become docked at your home island.
column13: The Gilded One was known as the San Salvador before David "Bones" Wylie won her on a lucky die roll. His crew's talents complement his luck, with several qualified captains among them.

column12: Spanish crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The Royal Fortune seeks to deliver what her name implies. Manned by both buccaneers and ex-Spanish sailors, she preys on the royal fleets of all nations.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Spanish ships.
column13: Death to the Crown was so named by Gaspar Zuan to appease his brother's bloodlust for the throne of Spain.

column12: English crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The Bonny Kate is a welcoming berth to any British lad who will take an oath against all kings.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: Narrow of beam and light of sail, the Batavian Bat is very nimble, but not fantastically fast. She prefers to engage from long range, making her a tough target.

column12: This ship sinks when her last mast is eliminated.
column13: Nothing ventured, nothing gained. The Venture carries more gunpowder than she should in order to double pack her guns for better range. But that makes her a potential fireworks display.

column12: This ship gets +L to her base move if she has all of her masts.
column13: The Silver Dagger was taken from the Dutch near the island of St. Barts. She is swift when undamaged, but slothful when wounded. To prevent being slowed, she has excellent cannons stolen from the Spanish

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Calico Cat (real name rumored to be Catherine) got her start only recently by stealing a Spanish sloop from Havana. She leads her crew with a dazzling smile that belies her deadly determination. Her anonymous past cannot hide her suffering, and she intends to make the crowns of Europe suffer as well.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action.
column13: Angus Skyme came to the Spanish Main in the brig of HMS Prudence. He escaped the gallows and gathered the roughest crew in the Caribbean. Blackheart shows no quarter to his victims or crew, and he has killed many of both for his amusement and profit. He still bears the scar from the duel he fought with Hawkins over Lady Arcadia de Sol.

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Sailing into and out of the mists, El Fantasma uses stealth as his major weapon. None know for sure whether he and his crew are even human—they seem to appear and disappear at will and are almost impossible to hit with cannons.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.  On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew from the enemy ship.
column13: Hawkins was an expert marksman and poacher until he was caught and shipped to Port Royal as an indentured servant. Blackheart liberated Hawkins when he sacked Port Royal, and the pair was dynamic until a dispute over Lady Arcadia de Sol. Hawkins won the girl, but also a powerful enemy.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
One of this ship's treasures is worth +2 gold when she docks at your home island.
column13: Captain Gallows has hated England since the day she watched her father's neck stretched. She will attack any ship, but relishes hurting England the most. Her crew would follow her to the gates of hell, both because of her leadership and her connections on the Spanish Main.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks.
column13: Some say the Ghost Crew are damned men cursed to sail these waters until they send enough souls to hell to get theirs back. Others say that El Fantasma and his crew are human, just tricky enough to terrify their opponents before they fire the first shot.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
Once per turn, if this ship carries treasure and is within S of an enemy ship, you may randomly trade one treasure with that ship.
column13: Wiley was raised and groomed for command by the dread pirate Rodriguez. When Rodriguez was killed in combat, Wiley was paralyzed by his new post. So he carved two dice out of Rodriguez's skull, allowing his mentor to guide him even in death.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Spanish ships.
column13: Fidel Zuan loves his brother, Gaspar. He reminded himself of that every day he rotted in a Spanish prison. After finally freeing him, his brother "explained" that Fidel had been falsely accused and wrongfully imprisoned. Fidel now fights the Spanish like the devil himself.

column12: This ship gains one rank 3 cannon with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: Lady Arcadia de Sol gifted this monkey to Jack after he saved her from Blackheart. Jack renamed him Skyme in honor of his old partner, but wishes that he hadn't: The monkey seems to have picked up some of Blackheart's more evil mannerisms.

column12: This ship gains one rank 3 cannon with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
column13: Bones often has Lucky fly to a ship to see what she holds. When Lucky returns, it uses its claws to "roll" dice into a stein, determining if the ship will be spared or pursued. Potential victims know that to shoot at Lucky would result in Wiley killing them and everyone they've ever met, so they leave their fate to the dice.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Genny Gallows' crew have been known to kill each other for the right to wear cloth torn from the curtains of the Red Curtain bordello, which signifies membership in the Red Rampage boarding party. Rumor is that the banshees who survive a tour are treated to a night at the Red Curtain.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
Place this crew face up during setup. Reduce the cost of all other crew placed on this ship by 1.
column13: Gaspar was given the El Picador by Spain to hunt English pirates, and his brother Fidel was kept hostage to ensure his return. But Gaspar betrayed them both by attacking the Spanish treasure fleet. Gaspar can talk anyone into joining him, even his brother. One day his lies will catch up with him, but that day is not today.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: HMS Titan, the largest English ship on the Spanish Main, is the only ship that has ever wounded the mysterious Revenant. Admiral Lord Battonbrig commands the Titan with iron discipline.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S.
column13: HMS Albion is an excellent scouting sloop. She especially shines in slow waters, sailing circles around more bulky vessels.

column12: This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her masts.
column13: HMS Lord Algernon is constructed of double-planked American colonial hardwood, making her slow but almost cannon proof. She has come to the Spanish Main to support attacks on Spanish interests.

column12: Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: The crew of the sloop HMS Europa live in fear that Commander Temple will again come aboard on a scouting mission.

column12: This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: HMS Leicester is currently the English fleet's most effective gunship. She features batteries of a new cannon type designed by Weapon-master Charles Southwyn.

column12: This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: HMS Oxley features heavy cannons that can splinter an enemy mast in a single broadside. The downside is that the guns are too heavy for the crew to maneuver quickly, reducing accuracy.

column12: If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: HMS King Edward, the most modern English ship in the Caribbean, is often the flagship of larger naval actions. When a senior officer is on board, her crew excels—especially her gun crew.

column12: This ship's cannons may not be eliminated (masts still may be). If derelict, she cannot shoot.
column13: Ironsides Exeter, as she is known to many in the Caribbean, has plate iron surrounding all her gun decks. This makes her cannons almost impossible to destroy, but her speed and cargo capacity suffer as a result.
HMS Dover is the standard of Her Majesty's Navy. She is large, well armed, has above-average cargo capacity, and is capable of reasonable speed.

column12: Other ships do not block this ship's line of fire.
column13: Captain McGrath is not the most flamboyant of commanders, but his gun crew is among the best on the Spanish Main thanks to his endless training.

column12: When this ship sinks another ship, you may repair one of this ship's masts.
column13: HMS Gallowglass is manned by many ex-cons, including several "Bones" Wylie's crew. These men can strip valuables from sinking ships and barely get their feet wet.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: HMS Birkenhead was part of several of Sir Myngs' insertions into Spanish ports. It was outfitted with spikes and guillotine lines to aid in the repelling of boarding parties.

column12: You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: The guns of HMS Meresman have the longest range on the Spanish Main.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: HMS Wycliffe was constructed in the shipyards of Boston of incredibly strong American hardwoods. It is said that she can withstand being rammed by any ship on the Spanish Main.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: HMS Plantagenet is a small, mercurial ship able to sail in shallow waters and up streams. This pirate hunter is manned exclusively by men who have lost everything to pirates.

column12: When this ship hits another ship, you choose which mast is eliminated.
column13: HMS Lord Walpole's gun crew was personally trained by Thomas Gunn, so suffice it to say they are good shots.

column12: Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: Henry Morgan was once a feared buccaneer. Sailing under letters of marque from Sir Myngs and Governor Modyford, he became wealthy by sacking Spanish Caribbean towns. Governor Lynch sent him to England to stand trial for his crimes, but instead he was knighted and made admiral of all the English fleets on the Spanish Main.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Myngs was sent to the Spanish Main to remove the Spanish. As usual, however, he wasn't given enough ships to do the job, so he pioneered the English-buccaneer fleet. He personally led the largest of these fleets against the Spanish and Dutch.

column12: When this ship is docked at your home island, you may eliminate one treasure. It becomes a rank 3 cannon that shoots short range and can only be eliminated when the ship sinks.
column13: Always covered in soot from his forge, "Carbon Charlie" makes some of the finest firearms in the world. His crowning achievement—the secret of which he will likely take to the grave—is the world's largest cannon.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Spanish ships.
column13: Gunn's family was sailing to Jamaica when the Spanish warship El Tirón attacked. His wife was killed, and Capitán de Alva took Gunn's 18-year-old daughter, Catherine, hostage. Gunn sold his soul to the navy for ransom money, but Spain denies any knowledge of her.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: Lynch hates pirates with a passion that defies reason. He despises Morgan for being a pirate and Myngs and Modyford for sullying the crown of England by associating with them. He often leads his fleets in pirate-hunting expeditions.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
Place this crew face up during setup. Reduce the cost of all other crew placed on this ship by 1.
column13: Countess Doone is the sweet-talking belle of English Caribbean society. Her dark secret is that she was actually shipped to the Spanish Main as an Irish indentured servant. When her ship was attacked by pirates, she took advantage of the chaos to take the possessions and personality of a rich young lady who no longer "needed" them. She has spellbound the Jamaican royal court ever since.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
Other ships do not block this ship's line of fire.
column13: Myngs' most-trusted men have been with him since he was captain of the 52-gun Marston Moor. They are well trained and have deadly aim.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action, plus. Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Gunn became a marine in His Majesty's Navy to seek revenge on the Spanish for his mother's death and sister's abduction, and he becomes more convinced every day that pirates deserve to die. His marksmanship is famous on the Main, as is his pension for keeping to himself.

column12: This ship gains one rank 3 cannon with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Brother Virgil has been a spiritual guide to island natives for many years. No one knows exactly which holy order he belongs to, but it apparently does not require a vow of poverty: The affable monk has grown rich from "gifts" received for placing crew on ships.

column12: This ship gains one rank 3 cannon with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The Noose is a special unit of the King's Marines that specializes in the bloody business of boarding actions. These men are the most loyal to Governor Lynch and his quest to rid the Caribbean of pirates.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
One of this ship's treasures is worth +1 gold when she docks at your home island.
column13: Pete is Carbon Charlie's right-hand man—mostly because he caused Charlie to lose his right arm! Powder Pete knows how to turn cannons into gold and, when they have it, gold into more gold.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
You own any derelict this ship explores; both ships become docked at your home island.
column13: Temple is the second son of an English nobleman in Ireland. Many say that his success has been greased with the blood of men he throws into hopeless situations and deadly boarding actions. His only weakness is his infatuation with the lovely Countess Doone.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
Two hits from the same shoot action are required to eliminate one of this ship's masts.
column13: The captain of "The Battleship," pride of the Spanish fleet and perhaps the strongest ship ever built, claims that not even the devil himself could sink her. The mysterious pirate El Fantasma, however, may soon test that boast.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The crew of the Santa Teresa believe that their sloop is blessed by Teresa herself, for their luck has never run out.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls for every friendly ship within S of her.
column13: This is the capital ship of the Armada de Barlavento—the special fleet assigned to rid the Spanish Main of pirates. "The Guarantor" is often under the command of Almirante del Nero, who oversees his crew's competition with the El Acorazado.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls for every friendly ship within S of her.
column13: The Repulse is a small but effective scout sloop. The confidence and performance of her small crew dramatically improve when she is part of a larger force.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: An imposing armed merchant ship, "The Jewel of the Sun" can move quickly with a large cargo. Built by a consortium of merchants, she was outfitted with decent guns, but her crew is trained in little other than repelling boarders.

column12: Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Comandante Antonio de Silva personally trained the marines on "The Gunner" to pick off enemy crew from long range. The ship has thus become famous for leaving her opponents "headless."

column12: When touching a Pirate ship, this ship may load as much of that ship's treasure as she can carry.
column13: Under Capitán Alarico Castro, "The Eagle" has earned a fearsome reputation. Castro's crew has perfected the art of ransacking and destroying their pirate enemies. It is rumored that he keeps a portion of the spoils hidden from Spain.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: The crew of the "Pirate Hunter" was literally whipped into shape by the obsessive Almirante Devante del Nero. He ensured that the only thing they hated more than him was pirates.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: Capitán Alberto Ladrón was sent from the Castilian court in disgrace, his commission as capitán the only recognition of his years of royal service. He now uses the La Resolución to prepare for his triumphant return to the royal court.

column12: When this ship hits an enemy ship, you may also eliminate one cargo from that ship.
column13: The "Ship Killer" is armed with huge bore cannons capable of devastating short-range damage. Capitán Gonzalo Mora first rose to prominence on her deck.

column12: This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: Although "The Fury" was outfitted with the same cannons as the Asesino de la Nave, she does not perform as well at short range, a fact that can be attributed only to the quality of her gun crew.

column12: If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: The Duke was once the largest Spanish ship permanently stationed in the Caribbean. Even though there are now larger ships in the area, the El Duque is still the fleet's flagship by virtue of her exceptional crew.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may move S after unloading cargo.
column13: The "Silver Fish" is fast and agile. Her crews are all ex–merchant sailors, and so they are expert cargo handlers

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S.
column13: The crew of "The Heart of the Sea" certainly live up to their ship's name: They put their hearts and backs into anything they do.
The Bullfighter was named after the story of a famous matador who went to sea after losing his leg in the arena. His spirit is said to inhabit this ship, bringing much courage to her crew.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: The capitán of "The Lion" relies on his ship's incredibly strong hull and his crew's bloodthirsty nature. In combat, he favors closing in quickly and then sending boarding parties.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a D6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Castro is a dedicated man, but ultimately not to Spain. He  "overcame" his Moorish heritage to rise to the top of the Spanish Navy, but he plots against every Castilian who has wronged him. Castro does his duty, but he patiently waits to make his move.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: Some say that de Alva's influential parents are the reason for his rapid climb in the Spanish Navy; these people do not know de Alva. His singular vision is to rid the Spanish Main of foreign holdings, starting with the English and the pirates they sponsor. De Alva's biggest weakness is becoming too "involved" with his "prizes."

column12: All of this ship's cannons have L range.
column13: Vazquez can hit a wine glass with a cannonball at 500 yards. He secretly desires to own a weapon made by the master himself, Charles Southwyn, so he searches through every treasure haul, looking for items made by the English legend.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship gets +1 cargo spaces. This crew takes up no cargo space.
column13: This quiet, unassuming man is in demand for his unrivaled cargo-packing efficiency. But only Capitán Castro knows that Bianco always packs away something extra for himself. Bianco knows that Castro will one day require payment for his secrecy.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Sanchez uses information smuggled to him by Nemesio Diaz to raid enemy ports when they are most laden with gold. Sanchez has put a price on Hawkins' head for tricking his galleon onto a reef, and he's doubled that price for Hawkins' monkey, Skyme. His expensive hatred of the monkey remains unexplained.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: Almirante del Nero, commander of the Armada de Barlavento, is a man driven almost mad by his zeal to rid the Spanish Main of pirates. To fail will be to fail his duty to God. His vision is so singular that he even secretly corresponds with his nation's enemy, Governor Lynch of Jamaica.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Over the years, Capitán Castro has surrounded himself with loyal crew. They are hardened men who fight well and don't question their orders, and Castro is betting on that when the time comes to change flags.

column12: This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her masts.
column13: Joaquin Vega is a master blacksmith. His swords rival those of Castile, and his ship armor is unparalleled the world over.

column12: This ship gains one rank 3 cannon with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship may unload cargo at your home island if she's within S of it.
column13: Master Bianco has a small fleet that shuttles his secret stores from the ships in the middle of the night. The strong backs and iron arms of his Haulers help to move the cargo quickly by rowboat and to defend it from curious eyes and meddling hands.

column12: This ship gains one rank 3 cannon with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
Once per turn, cancel the ability of one crew or ship within S of this ship.
column13: Nemesio Diaz (aka William Cob, Jean Parisot la Valette, and Michel van Horn) is a true son of Spain, but he spends most of his time spying on the aristocracy of Spain's enemies. He works to defeat any who would plunder the riches that are Spain's by papal decree; that is, all of the Americas.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
When this ship hits another ship, you choose which mast is eliminated.
column13: Capitán Mora is a shark who prefers surgical strikes to the blundering tactics of the English. His instincts about the weak spot of a fleet or ship are amazing, allowing his gunners to do more damage with a single shot than other crews might do with several broadsides.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: As a King's Marine, de Silva was once one of Spain's top musketeers. When he lost his right eye to a grape-shot volley fired by Christopher Myngs' ship, he feared for his career. But he learned to shoot all over again, vowing revenge on Myngs, his pirates, and all English.

column12: If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down treasure on any island.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
Cannon ranges of enemy ships are reduced to S against this ship.
Do not give this ship an action the turn after loading Rum. Rum is worth gold equal to 6 minus the number of this ship's crew when Rum was loaded.
Eliminate all crew on this ship; she cannot dock. When she touches another ship, unload Plague onto that ship.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
This ship may repair at sea or at any island.
Versenkt das Schiff ein anderes Schiff, so darfst du einen seiner Masten repaireren.
Einmal pro Spielzug darf sich das Schiff einen verdeckten Schatz auf einer beliebigen Insel anschauen.
Englische Schiffe bekommen +1 auf Kanonenwürfe gegen dieses Schiff.
L-Reichweiten-Kanonen können dieses Schiff nicht treffen.
Ghost Ship.
column13: Damned souls are condemned to the Deliverance,where they commit the same atrocities that doomed them in life. This spectral ship is commanded by Wraith—an entity whose malice rivals that of the Devil.

column12: French crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Le Requin's language skills and treacherous use of flags conspire to lure other ships into La Victoire's net, though he is almost chivalric toward those who serve France—after all, they are countrymen!

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: Brother Virgil inspired the crew of the Ranger to become seagoing Robin Hoods —with themselves as the deserving poor! Captain Greene intends to repay Brother Virgil for his "spiritual guidance."

column12: Spanish ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: As soon as marauding pirates dispatched the crew of L'Aquila, they raided Captain Alarico Castro's private supply of amontillado, the famed Spanish sherry.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
column13: Crimson Angel is fond of ancient history, so a ship called the Cassandra suits her nicely. She believes that coupling this four-masted beauty with the Pandora will give her a leg up on the competition.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: Captain Barton named the Arabella after his former mother-in-law, a woman whose corset stays were reportedly as sturdy as the ship's masts.

column12: On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew from the enemy ship.
column13: While some pirates fly the skull and crossbones out of style, the crew of La Morte do so out of substance. After one of their own was killed savagely, they now feel it is their right that their hostages often have "accidents" right after their ransoms are paid.

column12: When this ship hits an enemy ship, you may also eliminate one cargo from that ship.
column13: Captain Alberto Ladron could care less about collecting cargo. All he cares about is refitting captured prizes so that they are worthy of a conquering hero of Spain.

column12: Ghost Ship.
column13: The Amity left England bound for the West Indies, but she never arrived. If this is the same ship, it's a pretty safe bet that she doesn't have the same crew.

column12: Schooner. Forts cannot hit this ship.
column13: Some say that naming a pirate ship "the Treasure" is asking for trouble, but Captain Prentiss isn't worried: The ship's goods are stored in a warehouse in Lucina Harbor—not in her hold.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Captain Devereaux is so obsessed with finding an artifact called the "Eye of the Dragon" that he has threatened to keel-haul any crew who pockets even a tiny trinket from a boarded ship.

column12: Schooner. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: The captain of the Gilded Monkey has trained Skyme to gibber at the crew to make them load loot faster. Anyone who defies the creature usually finds an unwelcome deposit in his hammock.

column12: Schooner. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: Distinguished by her black hull and low profile, the agile Duke excels at frustrating long-range cannons. Calico Cat covets the vessel, and Jack Hawkins wants it only because she does.

column12: If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: These pirates describe themselves as loyal English privateers and have been heard shouting "Long live the king!" in battle—despite having no reservations about firing on English ships.

column12: English crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Sailing under the secret patronage of Countess Doone, the commander of the Bonnie Liz is a relatively patriotic man who charges far less ransom for English prisoners than for others.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: An ongoing competition aboard the Royal James gives bonuses for firing efficiency. One-shot kills are especially prized, and golden guineas are doubled for Spanish targets.

column12: Schooner. This ship cannot be pinned.
column13: Captain Parrish, a man of visions, says that Branwen the White Raven protects the ship, deflecting enemy fire with her invisible wings. His claim to fame: once drinking Jack Hawkins under the table.

column12: This ship's base move becomes S when she reaches her cargo limit.
column13: Captain Hansson has made maps of many of the small inlets that litter the Crimson Coast, which he uses as refuge when his ship's small hold becomes laden with treasure.

column12: You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: To keep his crew sharp, Captain Harrison has his crew practice on larger, less-agile ships like Ville de Paris, which he would love to wrest from the simpering Phillipe du Brissac.

column12: This ship cannot carry crew.
column13: A tiny vessel with few crew, the Mermaid is the ideal bait for greedy vessels. A favorite tactic is to have the captain's sister, Maud, masquerade as a captured noblewoman.

column12: Friendly ships within S of this ship get +1 to their cannon rolls.
column13: First Mate William Houston has taught the crew a special code using flags and lights, allowing them to safely and quickly relay information to the main ship—usually about likely prey.

column12: Broadsides Attack. This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
column13: Flores signaled his resignation from the French Navy with the dead body of his superior officer, who referred to him as a half-breed. Captain Flores is ruthless to his prey but generous to his crew. gaston de St. Croix might have damned his soul, but Crimson Angel has shown him the gates of heaven.

column12: Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: A magnificent creature drenched in the blood of her enemies, Crimson Angel is from either heaven or hell, depending on your point of view. She attacks crowns and pirates alike, seemingly loyal to none but her own. Even then, she rewards betrayal with swift and deadly vengeance, but her word is legend on the Crimson Coast.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action.
column13: Havana Black suffers no delinquency, and he revels in proving it with a cat-o-nine. Nothing raises Havana's ire faster than a slaver ship, and he particularly enjoys watching the crew of such a ship being put to the most horrible death possible—despite any pleas for leniency. It is said that even Blackheart fears this powerful ex-slave.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice. This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks.
column13: There are more stories about Jack Hawkins' adventures than seem possible given his age. He has taken more treasure and ships than any other pirate in the Caribbean, yet he is always broke and looking for a new ship. He courts only the most beautiful—and deadly—women, with more than his fair share of love-hate relationships, emphasis "hate."

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn. If this crew is eliminated, place it on your home island.
column13: Does a man seek the shadows or is he forced there by the machinations of others? Some whisper of a horrific betrayal, some of years spent isolated in a French prison, and others of unspeakable torture at the hands of the Moors. Whatever the truth, El PHantasma and his sepulchral crew do not intend to make amends for their crimes.

column12: Limit. Ransom. Place this crew face up during setup. You may build your fleet using 5 more points than the game's build total. This crew cannot leave this ship unless captured or eliminated.
column13: Creole Amelie Lejeune, better known as the "Hag of Tortuga" is a sea crone feared and respected by all the sailors on the Crimson Coast, regardless of nationality. It is said that she can commune with the dead, control the winds, and stop a man dead in his tracks with just a glance.

column12: Place this crew face up during setup. Reduce the cost of all other crew placed on this ship by 1.
column13: No one knows how The Stump got his peg leg, but most are happy to buy him as many rounds as it takes to hear the latest version of the tale. He's an excellent source of gossip about the latest goings-on around the Crimson Coast, and he might even know something about the "Eye of the Dragon"—or so he says.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: The mannerisms, language facility, and learned nature of the dashing Le Requin hint at a previous life of privilege. Le Requin won his first ship from Bones Wiley in a dice game, and he has proven himself a brilliant tactician and natural leader. He is on a collision course with Hawkins over the affections of the Lady De Sol.
