This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship gains one S range rank-3 cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a chainshot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the chainshot before rolling the d6. If the chainshot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target cannot move next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a stinkpot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the stinkpot before rolling the d6. If the stinkpot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target's crew cannot use their abilities next turn.
Galley. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: American sailors returning from the Barbary Coast say that this galley, captianed by kal Bhed and his cutthroats, delivers a lethal bite to anyone who stands in her way.

column12: Galley.
column13: The Star of Siam had just raided an American ship leaving the Barbary Coast for the Americas when Wesley captured her, claiming the ship and her swollen cargo holds for himself.

column12: As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship within S of her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses she may have.
column13: As an English privateer, Wesley raided ships and ports along the Barbary Coast. But a chance meeting with Jack Hawkins in Tangier convinced Wesley that he was fighitng on the wrong side.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a chainshot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the chainshot before rolling the d6. If the chainshot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target cannot move next turn.

Joysides Attack. This ship cannot be shot at, and she cannot sink. She begins the game fully loaded with treasure from her controller's collection. Her base move becomes 6L when she has no available cargo capacity.
column13: Sailors the world over speak of the Sleigh in tones reserved for the most honored and noble of ships. Rumored to be faster than a hurricane, quieter than the wind, and crewed by magical elves, only the most pure of heart have ever seen her, and they claim she a vision of lights, magic, and joy.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn this ship's controller may choose another ship and bellow "HO-HO-HO!" Any crew on the target falls asleep, and so the target loses her next turn.
column13: The ultimate captain. Whitebeard was born to spread joy to even the most hardened of sailors. Some claim that on quiet winter nights his bellowing "HO-HO-HOs" can bring grown sailors to their knees and make them feel the unadulterated joy of being a child.

column12: Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Christened as an English ship, the Black Swan has since flown the flag of many other nations. She lists English, French, Spanish and Americans among her crew.

column12: Schooner. After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: The crew of Neptune's Hoard has mastered the fine art of negotiating the best price for their goods—then sacking the towns that can't, or won't, meet their demands.

column12: Schooner. This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks.
column13: Lady Baptiste embodies all the best qualities of Robin Hood, with the Golden Medusa as her swift sword. Her crew serves for honor, above even gold.

column12: Schooner. Broadsides Attack.
column13: At a distance, the Pride appears to be ideal for smuggling and making swift attacks. But if she comes alongside, concentrated fire from her cannons is the last thing a crew will see.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: Greed motivates El Gato, captain of the Cursed Blade. His crew have mastered many inventive tactics in order to steal an opponent's treasure, rather than fight.

column12: Ghost Ship.
column13: The crew of Hades' Flame killed the voodoo priest Papa Martineau for what they considered unholy practices. His curse trapped them on the ship, and their eerie wails terrify all who hear them.

column12: Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: French sailors named this ship the Executioner in honor of its gunners, said to be able to take the head off a man's shoulders with a single shot.

column12: American ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: The Bloody Jewel preys on merchant ships sailing to and from Charleston. Anyone who brings the ship's masthead to Ralph David will be rewarded with a plot of Carolina land as bounty.

column12: This ship's cannons may not be eliminated (masts still may be). If derelict, she cannot shoot.
column13: Stolen from the Spanish, the Tiger is the prize of Captain Vivas who uses the little blockade runner to sack Spanish holdings along the Crimson Coast.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against forts within S of her.
column13: Captain Swank uses the Cutlass' maneuverability to get in so close to ports that her crew is already ashore before the ship is spotted and the shore cannons loaded.

column12: Schooner. When this ship hits an enemy ship, you may also eliminate one cargo from that ship.
column13: The Panda, under the command of "Don" Pedro, prefers the easy prey of ships damaged in battle or by storms, attacking as they limp back to port.

column12: This ship may not be shot at while docked.
column13: In an inspired bit of engineering by a former English sailor, the Coral's main mast collapses when in port so that other ships can't target her from sea.

column12: This ship cannot shoot when she carries treasure.
column13: One of the fastest ships on the Crimson Coast, Banshee's Cry carries a cannon, but she rarely fires it. The crew prefers to concentrate on finding treasure, not fighting for it.

column12: Schooner.
column13: The Lightning was commissioned by the Americans to patrol the North Atlantic. Unfortunately for them, Captain Wright didn't like his pay, and now uses the ship as a way to collect a higher wage.

column12: Once at the beginning of each of your turns, roll a d6. On a result of 6, any ship in your fleet may be given two actions that turn.
column13: The Gentleman Pirate is so infamous in New Orleans that the French, American and Spanish leaders all have placed a bounty on his head. He has honored them with a bounty in return.

column12: Once per turn, you may eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action. After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Woodes Rogers openly scoffs at Don Pedro's claim to a noble Spanish bloodline. The English fleet considers Gilbert the lowest of the pirates, and apprehending him its highest priority.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may look at any one face-down treasure on any ship or island. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Originally a French privateer, Devereaux has lost his sanity to his obsession with finding the Dragon's Eye, a gem that legend says grants the owner immortality.

column12: Once per turn, reroll any die roll made for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: The beautiful Lady Baptiste, considered both a hero and a scourge, has even been asked by Madame LaFontaine to be one of her girls. Her allegiance remains true to her ship and crew.

column12: This ship ignores terrain when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain).
column13: How he lost his eye is a mystery, but rumors persist that he sold it to the Devil in exchange for the ability to see the shoals and reefs hidden bneath treacherous waters.

column12: This crew takes up no cargo space when revealed. When revealed, put a crew with point cost 2 or less from outside of the game onto this ship.
column13: Amos discovered rum on his first trip to Tortuga, and has been drunk on it ever since. His knack for getting friends aboard the ships he crews has saved his life repeatedly.

column12: You may reveal this event immediately after one of your ships sinks an enemy ship, but you may not reveal it on the same turn an opponent reveals Raft. You receive all gold from the sunken ship. Remove Divers from the game.
When this ship hits another ship, you choose which mast is eliminated.
column13: Though his brother gets the fame, Phillipe is a crack shot with a cannon and has trained many cannonneers. He is responsible for the devastating attacks the Pride can unleash.

column12: You may reveal this event immediately after one of your ships sinks an enemy ship, but you may not reveal it on the same turn an opponent reveals Raft. You receive all gold from the sunken ship. Remove Divers from the game.
Place your eliminated crew on this fort. They gain the Ghost Ship keyword.
column13: Rumors say that The Devils' Maw holds a king's ransom in gold, but you must give up your soul to claim it--a price even pirates hesitate to pay.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the ship's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a 6 remove the fire mast; on a 1-3 the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or at a fort, remove all fire masts as a free action.
Broadsides Attack.
column13: The newest warship in the English fleet, has been dubbed "The Pirate Hunter" and the Swallow has direct orders to work with Woodes Rogers to clean up the Crimson Coast.

column12: This ship's cannons may not be eliminated (masts still may be). If derelict, she cannot shoot.
column13: The Spanish could not defeat her. The French also tried, and failed. Now, the Dreadnought's crew looks forward to continuing its winning streak in conflicts against the American colonists.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against forts within S of her.
column13: The Crown ordered Captain Kline to accommodate veteran soldier Lt. Hardwicke in training the Oxford's crew in strategies for capturing forts and cities. Disdainful of the regular army, Kline has grudgingly complied.

column12: Schooner. If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: Responsible for patrolling the North Atlantic, the Serapis hunts down enemies of the Crown and ensures they never question her authority again.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against American ships.
column13: The crew of the Nautilus consists of colonists loyal to the Crown of England. They have destroyed many ships flying the "joke of a flag" created by the traitorous American scum.

column12: Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: Sir Watkins circumnavigated the globe in the Algiers, and counts the ship as his primary abode. He can tell her speed and direction by listening to the creaks of her hull.

column12: Two hits from the same shoot action are required to eliminate one of this ship's masts.
column13: The Lord Cauldwell was built to infiltrate pirate forts, but Lt. Nigel Hardwicke also uses this sturdy little boat quite effectively against American blockades.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against French ships.
column13: Embarrassed by Guy LaPlante in a duel fought in New Orleans, the captain of the Apollo has sworn an oath of vengeance against all the French on the Crimson Coast.

column12: Schooner. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The Frolic has yet to see combat. Rumor has it that the crew is so embarrassed by their ship's name that they avoid all contact with friends and foes.

column12: Schooner. Forts cannot hit this ship.
column13: The fastest ship in Rogers' fleet, the Greyhound is tasked with testing the defenses of pirate havens, French outposts and American coastal positions.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against forts within S of her. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: Few know that Rogers began his career as a privateer under the English flag. His new status angers the French and Spanish—his former victims—and earns him the begrudging respect of the pirates.

column12: Marine. This crew gets +1 to its gun rolls against American ships, forts, and crew.
column13: A veteran of the European wars, Hardwicke uses his land-based skills at sea to crush the American revolutionaries. He believes he will be the one to plant the Union Jack in Philadelphia.

column12: This ship ignores terrain when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain).
column13: Sir Watkins spends so much time aboard his ship that he is uncomfortable on land. He reads the sea as easily as a mother understands the cries of her baby.

column12: Always place this crew face up; it cannot be eliminated unless its ship sinks. Crew placed on this ship cost no points, but they always each take up one cargo space. When this ship is hit, roll a d6. On a result of 5 or 6, move the crew on this ship with the highest point cost to a wild island chosen by the player to your left.
column13: Found on an uncharted island, Robinson can't remember the name of his ship, its fate, or the reason he was left behind. Woe betide the crew that rescues him!

column12: You may reveal Raft immediately after one of your ships sinks. Place all crew and gold on that ship onto the nearest wild island. Remove Raft from the game.
This fort has one 2 L-range cannon. When placing this fort, indicate this cannon by placing two flags side by side.
column13: The first fort that Rogers commissioned boldly declares this message: "This land and the sea around it belong to the English Crown."

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the ship's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a 6 remove the fire mast; on a 1-3 the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or at a fort, remove all fire masts as a free action.
Schooner. One of this ship's treasures is worth +2 gold when unloaded at your home island.
column13: With her gilded hull and polished cannons, La Santa Isabel is a throwback to the days when Spain ruled the seas. Now, she is reduced to trading between the colonies and Spain.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: Capitan Oloma has developed a new strategy for La Cazador, using the aggressive huntress as a battering ram to discourage ships that attempt to raid Spanish holdings.

column12: After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Don Sanchez teaches his crew to defeat pirates by acting like pirates. He encourages them to trade, even with the Crown's enemies, to get what they want.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, this ship may move S after loading treasure.
column13: Having lost two ships while docked, Alfonso Vargas, first mate of La Monarca, has taught his crew to load and unload so quickly that some say they never even drop anchor.

column12: Marine. This crew gets +1 to its gun rolls against Pirate ships, forts, and crew.
column13: Haunted by the abuse he suffered when captured by pirates on his first tour of duty, Olano has vowed to hunt down every pirate on sea or land and exact his revenge.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this fort.
column13: The Spanish claim it doesn't exist. Yet natives can be persuaded to speak of the "Golden Fortress," the apparent source of the Spanish gold flowing along the Crimson Coast.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the ship's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a 6 remove the fire mast; on a 1-3 the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or at a fort, remove all fire masts as a free action.
Other ships do not block this ship's line of fire.
column13: The women of France cried the day their men sailed on Le Superbe. They knew they had lost them forever, for no woman could live up to such a perfect vessel.

column12: Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Capitain DeZay has assigned each of his cannonneers a specific color of cannonball, so that they get the credit they deserve in battle.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: In her last conflict with the English, La Vengeance lost all but five crewmembers. Those five make all new sailors swear a blood oath of revenge before coming aboard.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Le Lyon sailed out of Quebec, raiding English and American ports all along the Atlantic Coast. She remained successful to New Orleans; a new crew will make the return trip.

column12: This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her masts.
column13: Guy LaPlante expertly captains Le Courageux; he makes sure the enemy can see his face, and know that both her guns and his sword are pointed at their heart.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against forts within S of her.
column13: Madame LaFontaine's girls dote on the crew of L'Atalante, and no wonder: after every successful mission, the crew spends its reward at Chateau Fontainebleu.

column12: Schooner. When this ship hits an enemy ship, you may also eliminate one cargo from that ship.
column13: The cannonneers aboard La Belle Etoile pack their cannons with double the usual amount of gunpowder in order to penetrate both sides of a ship with one shot.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: When Capitan Coupet removed the ship's masthead, his crew nearly mutinied. He replaced it with a bayonet, the ship's namesake, and success in their first battle proved the old man was right.

column12: Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: La Danae was captured by Jean Lafitte, but was returned to France after a private audience with Madame LaFontaine. The crew doesn't care what flag flies as long as they get paid.

column12: Schooner. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: Owned by Vicomtesse de Richelieu, La Favori has become a favorite of Michel Bordeaux, who is searching for a ship swift and nimble enough to land raiding parties.

column12: Schooner. All of this ship's cannons have L range.
column13: Trained by Amiral Dupuy, the crew of La Félicité know that they must perform at the highest level to honor their country and flag.

column12: You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6  to hit.
column13: Guy Laplante retrieved this ship from the English and returned it to France. It's guns were upgraded by its English captors, and the current crew is learning how to fire them effectively.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
column13: Phillipe Amqui once piloted Le Bon Marin through the bayou around New Orleans and into Jean Lafitte's hideout on a bet from Lady Baptiste.

column12: Limit. Ransom. Choose one French crew during setup; this crew is linked to that crew. Reroll any die roll, you must use the second result.
column13: Madame LaFontaine is proprietress of Chateau Fontainebleu, a burlesque house in New Orleans. Her girls report everything they hear to Madame, and she passes that information to Amiral Dupuy.

column12: This ship ignores terrain when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain).
column13: Amqui claims that Native Americans taught him how to talk to the water. His uncanny ability to accurately read the sea has made him worth his weight in gold.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against forts within S of her. She gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Born in New Orleans, he has never seen the France he defends. Both Madame LaFontaine and Viscomtesse Richelieu covet his new-world attitude, but he desires only one treasure: Lady Baptiste.

column12: Marine. This crew gets +1 to its gun rolls against English ships, forts, and crew.
column13: At Viscomtesse Richelieu's request, Bordeaux's task is to shore up the defenses of France's New World holdings. He feels obligated to protect her holdings first, then hunt down the English.

column12: Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns and place its token on a non-docked enemy ship. That ship may not be given an action for a number of turns equal to the number of crew on her when Mermaids was revealed. After those turns have elapsed, remove Mermaids from the game.
When another face-up crew on this ship would be eliminated, turn it face down instead.
column13: As Dr. Rene Bordeaux healed men's bodies, he saw the true disease in their souls. Where Michel is sent, Father Bordeaux follows, as blood will flow, and souls need to be saved.

column12: You may reveal Raft immediately after one of your ships sinks. Place all crew and gold on that ship onto the nearest wild island. Remove Raft from the game.
The first time this fort is shot at each turn, roll a d6. The result is the number of times this fort must be hit that turn before any of its cannons can be eliminated.
column13: The Paradise of the Sea is now home to second-generation French settlers, who will fight to the death to keep their island safe from outsiders.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the ship's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a 6 remove the fire mast; on a 1-3 the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or at a fort, remove all fire masts as a free action.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: From the deck of the Bonhomme Richard, John Paul Jones shouted to the the English captain of the Serapis, "I have not yet begun to fight."

column12: Two hits from the same shoot action are required to eliminate one of this ship's masts.
column13: Sailors nicknamed her "Old Ironsides" because she could take a full broadside attack without a chip to her hull—and her crew are the best-trained navy men in America.

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: The "Old War Wagon" is the slowest ship in the American navy, but when she catches you in her devastating guns, speed doesn't matter.

column12: Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: Members of seasoned merchant-vessel crews familiar with the North Atlantic give the Enterprise an advantage in northern waters.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: Sent to establish an American presence against the pirates, David Porter chose the Freedom as his flagship: the first, and last, American ship pirates would ever encounter.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Captain Anson, once a French privateer, has taught his crew to spot and aim for the weakest points in an enemy ship, in order to do the most damage.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Captain Oswald "recruited" his crew from the Baltimore jailhouse and gave them one law: when you hit the deck of the enemy ship, the survivor goes home a free man.

column12: Schooner. This ship cannot be pinned.
column13: The captain of the Yankee sailed her into the middle of a formation of three English ships and maneuvered so quickly that the enemy ships rammed each other. Score: Yankee 3, English 0.

column12: Schooner. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: Jarvis was built by the David family to hunt pirates plaguing Charleston. Moored near shore to lure ships onto the rocky coast, if the cannons don't destroy the enemy, the rocks will.
Ruth Lee pulled the Carolina out of dry dock to sell it to an old sea salt named "Captain" Henry, who claimed he was put in charge of hunting Redcoats.

column12: Schooner. Forts cannot hit this ship.
column13: The Boston's first mate has gathered a veteran crew. Each member must describe the forts and islands they have encountered so he can add to his strategic plans.

column12: Schooner. Broadsides Attack.
column13: With new guns and Haraden at the helm, the crew of the Julius Caesar have declared that they will become the new flagship of the American fleet.

column12: English ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: Originally an English ship, the Rattlesnake's American crew mutinied and forced the English officers into a rowboat. In response, Woodes Rogers issued a general order to sink the Rattlesnake.

column12: Friendly ships within S of this ship get +1 to their cannon rolls.
column13: Hannah takes advantage of an unusually tall mast and a two-man crow's nest to spy out enemy positions and report its findings to the fleet's larger, slower ships.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: Crenshaw openly defies Porter's orders to concentrate on pirates and uses the Hornet to attack English ships, claiming they are the true enemy.

column12: You own any derelict this ship explores; both ships become docked at your home island.
column13: A familiar sight near New Orleans is Ruth Lee at the helm of the Philadelphia, with a derelict pirate ship in tow.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: Originally part of Ralph David's privateer fleet, the Flying Fish was given to Porter so that experienced pirate hunters could teach his sailors the ins and outs of the pirate mind.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, this ship may move S after loading treasure.
column13: Ever-changing alliances  taught the Wasp's crew to unload their goods quickly and move out before they were declared an "unfriendly presence" in port.

column12: Schooner. This ship cannot be pinned.
column13: Jean Lafitte has tried to steal and capture the Peacock. Now he's been reduced to trying to buy the ship to gain her advantage in tight battles.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Chesapeake's crew of veteran privateers possess a letter of marque to fight for America. They have learned to gut enemy ships, leaving no survivors to reveal their role in the massacre.

column12: When this ship carries no cargo, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: Once a ship sailing with Don Perdo, the Lynx was one of the first ships captured on Porter's watch.

column12: Schooner. All of this ship's cannons have L range.
column13: Devereaux traded the captain of the Harlequin a powerful English-built cannon for an old Spanish map found in a New Orleans trinket shop.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice. This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks.
column13: A hero of the new revolution, but considered a pirate by the English, John Paul Jones took the fight directly to the king, even sinking ships within European waters.

column12: Broadsides Attack. This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
column13: Backed by the power of the new American government, David Porter was tasked with ridding the area of pirates, using the efficiency of a military operation.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, reroll any die roll made for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Using any means necessary, from purely tactical maneuvers to sneak attacks, and once facing down an opponent with a single cannon, Haraden has captured or sunk more than one thousand cannons in his career.

column12: This ship ignores terrain when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain).
column13: Kikowa sets up camp at the bow of every ship on which he serves. He never leaves that spot; eating, sleeping and, most importantly, watching the sea from his unique vantage point.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: As a merchant sailor in New England, Carl fought his share of pirates, privateers, and ships of foreign crowns. Now he sails the Atlantic Coast fighting for freedom.

column12: Once per turn, if this ship carries treasure and is within S of an enemy ship, you may randomly trade one treasure with that ship.
column13: Wherever Turner shows up, someone will make money, and someone will lose it. "Diamond" nearly always wins. The list of losers is a who's who of powerful New Orleans personalities.

column12: All of this ship's cannons have L range.
column13: Crenshaw would rather fight the Redcoats than pirate scum, and so he has begun a private war on the Crimson Coast to keep his personal agenda alive.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: Found by Carl Smith, he was named King George for the only other cur Smith knew. In boarding attacks, K.G. heads for the officers' quarters to grab whatever fits in his mouth.

column12: Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns and place its token on a non-docked enemy ship. That ship may not be given an action for a number of turns equal to the number of crew on her when Mermaids was revealed. After those turns have elapsed, remove Mermaids from the game.
When another face-up crew on this ship would be eliminated, turn it face down instead.
column13: Most sailors consider a visit from "Hacksaw" a blessing and curse. He keeps them alive, but they'll likely end up with one less limb.

column12: Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns and place its token anywhere on the play area (except on an island or a ship). Any ship (except docked ships) within L of the token is moved L in one direction chosen by the player to the left of that ship's controller. If a ship touches an island, eliminate one of her masts. Remove Foul Winds from the game.
One of this ship's treasures is worth +2 gold when unloaded at your home island.
column13: The David family is said to own Charleston, and Ralph has used his family's power and prestige to achieve his goal of owning the shipping lanes to the Crimson Coast as well.

column12: Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns and place its token anywhere on the play area (except on an island or a ship). No ship within L of the token may be given a move action unless she can move when derelict. Remove Becalmed from the game at the beginning of your next turn.
Place this crew face up during setup. Reduce the cost of all other crew placed on this ship by 1.
column13: Born and raised at sea and respected by everyone, even pirates, she has forgotten more about ships, sailors and the sea than most of the so-called professionals have ever known.

column12: Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns and place its token anywhere on the play area (except on an island or a ship). Any ship (except docked ships) within L of the token is moved L in one direction chosen by the player to the left of that ship's controller. If a ship touches an island, eliminate one of her masts. Remove Foul Winds from the game.
After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: His name opens doors for him: an honest name for an honest man. But Jefferson treats everything as currency—even human life.

column12: Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns and place its token anywhere on the play area (except on an island or a ship). No ship within L of the token may be given a move action unless she can move when derelict. Remove Becalmed from the game at the beginning of your next turn.
This fort gets +1 to its cannon rolls when a ship is docked at it.
column13: As the westernmost island in a string of dangerous, rocky atolls, controlling Thompson's Island is the key to controlling the Crimson Coast.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the ship's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a 6 remove the fire mast; on a 1-3 the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or at a fort, remove all fire masts as a free action.
This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls for every crew on her.
If this ship loads Scurvy, it has no effect; remove it from the game. Fruit takes up 2 cargo spaces and cannot be unloaded.
This ship ignores terrain when given move actions (islands are not terrain).
The ship that reveals Natives may not be given actions for a number of rounds equal to number of crew on her when Natives is revealed. Leave Natives face down on its island.
You may load this treasure face down. If one of this ship's masts would be eliminated, you may reveal Cross of Coronado and remove it from the game instead.
Place any one crew with point cost 3 or less on this ship, using standard cargo capacity rules. That crew assumes this ship's nationality. Remove Castaway from the game.
Remove all crew on this ship from the game and then remove Missionary from the game.
Load this treasure face down. You may reveal it when this ship rams or pins a ship. Roll a d6. On a result of 4–6, both ships sink. Remove Explosives from the game.

Galley. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: American sailors returning from the Barbary Coast say that this galley, captianed by kal Bhed and his cutthroats, delivers a lethal bite to anyone who stands in her way.

column12: Galley.
column13: The Star of Siam had just raided an American ship leaving the Barbary Coast for the Americas when Wesley captured her, claiming the ship and her swollen cargo holds for himself.

column12: As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship within S of her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses she may have.
column13: As an English privateer, Wesley raided ships and ports along the Barbary Coast. But a chance meeting with Jack Hawkins in Tangier convinced Wesley that he was fighitng on the wrong side.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a chainshot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the chainshot before rolling the d6. If the chainshot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target cannot move next turn.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against American ships.
column13: Porter sacked Captian Blackeart's hideout and all he has left is the Hangman's Noose. He vows will destroy the American fleet in revenge.

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: The Red Curse is feared in small towns and ports from Boston to New Orleans and all the islands of the Crimson Coast.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: David Porter has given the Concord one order: "Hunt and destroy all Pirates no matter where they are!"

column12: If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: The newest American ship has a very young crew. Only an experienced Captain can whip these recruits into a fighting machine.

column12: Galley. This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: Rais Abba Quilon modified the Nubian Prince to draft deep, making her almost invisible in the water—and an impossible target for nearby ships.

column12: Galley. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The Ivory Star's hull is covered with polished ivory. From a distance, she looks like a cresting wave, entrancing opponents into a state of vulnerability.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: During boarding attacks, the crew of the Jackal's Teeth howl like ghostly dogs, striking fear in the hearts of even the most stalwart defenders.

column12: Galley. Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Crewed by outcasts of Europe and the New World, the Terror of Gibraltar plies her unique brand of piracy in the waters near its eponymous outcropping.

column12: Galley. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: The devout captain of the Crescent Moon demands that his compass be accurate so that he can face Mecca when praying, no matter the ship's heading.

column12: Galley. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: The crew of Janissaries' Blood has been culled entirely from the Barbary Coast, and Rais Murat makes sure their hatred for Europeans is matched only by their loyalty to him.

column12: Galley. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Equipped with boarding hooks and ramps, the Fire Djinn strikes with the speed of a sandstorm and the deadliness of a demon.

column12: Galley. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Uluj Ali has trained the crew of the Sea Dragon specifically to fight Spanish vessels: to board them, take prisoners, and then use the information they provide to attack their ports.

column12: Galley. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Inspired by the ancient navies of Xerxes the Great, the Persian Victory and her crew oppose any foreign power attempting to control the Barbary Coast.

column12: Galley. Eliminate one of this ship's masts when she rolls a 1 on any cannon roll.
column13: Mocked by other Barbary Corsairs, the crew of the Winds of Vengeance always press their attack—even if means the loss of ship and life.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against American ships.
column13: Rais Al-Kazar has decided that American ships are easy pickings, so he focuses the attacks of the Wicked Kareen almost exclusively on their merchant ships.

column12: Galley. After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Wesley has taken command of the Algiers, which has become the most successful Barbary Corsair ship because of his uncanny ability to turn a small supply of gold into a large one.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against French ships.
column13: Capitan Marcel, a former French privateer with a crew of ex-slaves, hunts the waters around French colonies, viciously attacking their naval support and merchant ships.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against Spanish ships.
column13: The Moorish captain of Divan's Punishment is a former prisoner of Spain who directs his attacks against their gold-bloated ships returning from the New World.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Rumor says that Rais Jaziri doesn't even load the cannons of the Sultan's Sword, so confident is he in the ship's swift attacks and even swifter swords.

column12: Galley. Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: The captain of the Splendor cares little for captives, preferring to fill his hold with what really matters: gold.

column12: Galley. Spanish ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: So great is their fear of Spain, this crew of former slaves has been known to panic when faced with a ship flying the colors of Spain.

column12: Galley.
column13: Her distinct golden sails—a gift from the pasha in Constantinople—make the Golden Peacock a glorious vision on the Barbary Coast.

column12: Galley. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The superstitious first mate of the Tiger's Eye keeps on his person a gem that he claims protects his ship from harm, and no one is willing to risk finding out if it's true.

column12: Galley. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: The Silent Death and her crew have honed the fine art of sneaking up on an unsuspecting enemy and personally waking her captain from his bunk with a sword at his throat.

column12: Galley. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: In Rais Haddou's eyes, the crew of the Bey's Revenge earn their pay only if they take down larger ships. Anything else is an insult and an embarrassment.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Trained by Sicilian sailors and taught warfare by the pasha's soldiers, Rais Baha can estimate how long it will take to capture a ship, down to the minute.

column12: Galley. Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The crew of the Gallows are outcast pirates from the Caribbean who escaped a hanging to try their fortunes on the Barbary Coast. They named their ship so as to never forget life's quirks.

column12: Galley. This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: The galley master has been told it will be his life if the ship's oarsmen ever miss a beat, thus the uncanny ability of the Desert Wind to close on ships even in battle.

column12: Galley. Spanish ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: Nothing is known of the captain of this vessel except that the king of Spain himself put an enormous price on his head.

column12: Galley. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The colors flown by the Pasha's Delight imply that she's nothing more than a harmless merchant vessel—allowing her crew to take advantage of opponents not cunning enough to see through her deception.

column12: Galley. Eliminate one of this ship's masts when she rolls a 1 on any cannon roll.
column13: This once-great warship has started to show her age—it is a rare day when she enters port with plunder.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against English ships.
column13: After his old ship was sunk by the English, Rais Yahia vowed to pay the widows of his lost crew twice—once with England's blood and once with her gold.

column12: Galley. This ship's base move becomes S when she reaches her cargo limit.
column13: The crew of the Dervish prefers to grab what it can and then flee, even if means leaving other treasure behind. After all, gold never helped a dead man.

column12: Galley. Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down treasure on any island.
column13: With contacts in every port along the Barbary Coast, Rais Oudah seems to know more about what ships are carrying than their own captains do.

column12: Galley. American ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: The Griffin was the first ship to capture an American crew—and then sell them back to their own. American sailors have thus made the ship their number-one target.

column12: Galley. This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: The Tripoli's captain keeps a captured noble on board at all times. He uses them as an excuse for trade, getting close enough to bigger ships to surprise them with an attack.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: This tiny vessel was actually named by the English for her ability to attack larger ships and leave them in disarray while she escapes.

column12: Galley. When this ship carries no cargo, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: The greedy crew of the Whisper has been known to fill the ship's holds with anything and everything they can get, even if it means crawling back to port.

column12: Galley. Friendly ships within S of this ship get +1 to their cannon rolls.
column13: The Majestic has survived as long as she has by scouting for other Barbary Corsairs. The pay is so good that the crew doesn't even need to fight.

column12: Galley. This ship may not be shot at while docked.
column13: By having their oarsmen row the Carthage onto shore, the crew ensures that she is ignored by both sea and coastal cannons.

column12: Galley. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Rais Zaci is well aware of the Nimcha's shortcomings, so he trained her oarsmen to fire cannons while rowing, all without missing a beat.

column12: Galley. This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
column13: The value of knowing where treasure may be hidden is more valuable to Rais Taha than any shipping chart.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. If this ship wins a boarding party, she may capture the crew with the highest point cost instead of eliminating it. This captured crew becomes cargo worth its point cost in gold when unloaded at your home island.
column13: Known for his red beard, Aruj is credited with the creation of the first Barbary Corsair fleets. Under his leadership, they began their domination of the Barbary Coast by proving that the galley could take on the biggest European ships.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Rumors persist that Wesley is an English noble who has been denied his birthright because of his common mother. Taking to piracy, he has decided that he will buy his place with the gold of those who denied him.

column12: Once at the beginning of each of your turns, roll a d6. On a result of 6, any ship in your fleet may be given two actions that turn.
column13: Kheir-ed-din (gift of God) is the strategic half of his partnership with his charismatic brother, Aruj. He leads the fleets of the Barbary Corsairs and works both for the emir of Ottoman Empire and the sultan of Tunis.

column12: Marine. This crew gets +1 to its gun rolls against Spanish ships, forts, and crew.
column13: An Italian by birth and a sailor by profession, Uluj rose to command Barbary Corsairs by ceaselessly attacking Spanish ships, holdings, and nobility.

column12: Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship. Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Because pirate hunting had become the priority of both the Americans and English in the New World, Jack decided to seek his fortune elsewhere. After landing at Tangier, he saw the piles of gold—and he knew he was home.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non–Barbary Corsair ship.
column13: Rais Murat was once a prisoner of the Barbary Corsairs, but he has since been granted his freedom and a ship. To make himself known to every sailor on the Mediterranean, Murat hunts every ship that does not fly the Barbary Corsair flag.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against forts within S of her. She gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Dragut retook Tripoli from the Spanish after a bloody and bitter battle. He learned that there was more to life than just sailing, and that any man who sailed with him had to be able to fight both on land and on sea.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: Described by his former English commander as “a drunk, a fool, and an idiot,” Ward decided that stealing for himself was better than serving as a “slave” on an English warship.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
column13: Haunted by the abuse he suffered when captured by pirates on his first tour of duty, Olano has vowed to hunt down every pirate on sea or land and exact his revenge.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against Barbary Corsair ships.
column13: Captured by Robert Blake and then turned over to the Knights of Malta, the Alexandria is feared by the Barbary Corsairs for both her firepower and the ferocity of her crew.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Lawrence has tuned the crew of HMS Durham to perfection using both the tactics of the Barbary Corsairs and the training of the Royal Navy.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Commodore Owen fills the cannons of the fearsome Granville with grapeshot so that they can take out as many Barbary Corsairs as possible.

column12: Schooner. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: Captain Hawley flies the flags of over 30 nations from HMS Westminster in an effort to confuse enemies and give his crew the upper hand in combat.
Small, fast, and perpetually leaky, HMS Antelope is crewed by Barrett's Privateers, and she is charged with harassing anyone not flying the Union Jack.

column12: Two hits from the same shoot action are required to eliminate one of this ship's masts.
column13: Financed privately and constructed of the hardiest materials, HMS Lord Kenyon prowls the profitable Barbary Coast, preying upon those who underestimate her.

column12: Galley. This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: The Knights of Malta were trained by the Royal Navy to dodge cannon fire at close range, allowing the St. George to get up close and personal.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Barbary Corsair ships. Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Given the title “General of the Sea” by the Crown, Admiral Blake is the supreme commander of the English fleets. With a selfless sense of duty, he has created the greatest naval force the world has seen, and yet he is still considered a gentleman, a sailor, and a scholar.

column12: Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.
column13: After going “native,” Ethan Lawrence was stripped of his commission in the Royal Navy. But his very public exploits as “England's Own Corsair,” coupled with his rescue of HMS Durham from a Barbary Corsair sneak attack, forced the Crown to give him back his command.

column11: Don Rafael Y de Teresa, Benoit de Marseilles
column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: With rumors of a crime of passion swirling around him, Roderick left England as a sailor. Fighting alongside the Knights of Malta, he came to see them as the true protectors of the kingdoms of Europe. So he left the Royal Navy to become a warrior in the fight against the Barbary Corsair scourge.

column12: Limit. Ransom. Choose one English crew during setup; this crew is linked to that crew. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Being given a new command on the Barbary Coast would seem like a promotion to any other naval officer, but Owen feels that he is being punished. Did he learn too much about Countess Doone or question the commands of Woodes Rogers too often? The only directive he gets is to destroy the Corsairs at all costs.

column12: This ship gets +1 cargo spaces. This crew takes up no cargo space.
column13: Egyptian by birth, but schooled and trained in colonial schools in Cairo, Ismail realized that the Royal Navy was his ticket out of the slums. His ability to deal with locals gets his ships the best deals and the fastest cargo turnovers.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
column13: Trained by Amiral Dupuy, the crew of La Félicité know that they must perform at the highest level to honor their country and flag.

column12: Galley. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: La Espada del Dios is a captured galley disguised as a Barbary Corsair ship, and her capitan is happy to let them take the blame for his plunders.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against Barbary Corsair ships.
column13: The mighty Granada is Admiral Castro's flagship in the Mediterranean. She is known for ruthlessly hunting Corsairs to the very ends of the Earth.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Capitan Carral won the Pamplona in a game of dice, and he feels that with the goddess of luck on his side, he and his crew can meet any challenge.

column12: Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.
column13: The crew of El Paso come from all over the Barbary Coast, and Capitan Carrillo's contacts range from the throne rooms of Europe to the lowliest taverns.

column12: You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: La Serpiente's crew are the finest cannoneers on the Barbary Coast. It is said they can hit a ship docked in Morocco from Barcelona.

column12: This ship's cannons may not be eliminated (masts still may be). If derelict, she cannot shoot.
column13: El Toro, like a bull on a rampage, is sent into fleets of Barbary Corsairs with one purpose: to destroy galleys.

column12: Galley. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: The crew of El Alonso de Orozco must swear loyalty to the Knights of Malta over Spain.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Barbary Corsair crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Tariq the Black uses his Moorish heritage to recruit Barbary Corsairs to sail for Spain as part of a deal he brokered with the Crown. He has been promised the kingship of Morocco as a reward for destroying the Corsairs.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Barbary Corsair ships. Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Freda is an experienced sailor who once owned a large shipping fleet in Naples—before it was all destroyed by Barbary Corsairs. He has agreed to work with Spain in exchange for a fleet to liberate his home from Barbarossa.

column11: Roderick the Pure, Benoit de Marseilles
column12: When another face-up crew on this ship would be eliminated, turn it face down instead.
column13: As a doctor to the Crown, Don Rafael had all the prestige a man could want. But he knew that his skills were needed for a higher calling. He became a Knight of Malta, and now he uses his gifts to ease the pain of those fighting the Corsair scourge.

column12: Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: Promoted and transferred to the Barbary Coast, Admiral Castro's plans to destroy every Castilian who opposed him has softened, as he has become a welcome fixture in the royal court and drawing rooms of a new Spain.

column12: Limit, Ransom. Choose one Spanish crew during setup; this crew is linked to that crew. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Duque Vaccaro, also known as the “Golden Tongue,” is Spain's most important negotiator. He alone can interrupt the king at any hour, and his imperatives often become reality. He has been dispatched to the Italian city-states, the Knights of Malta, and even to England and France.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
Galley. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: The Knights of Malta recruit French Corsairs to crew Le St. Denis so that they can fight the Barbary Corsairs on equal footing.

column12: Schooner. If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: L'Ange de la Mer survived battles with the English that sent many of her sister ships to the bottom of the sea. She has earned the distinction of flagship on the Barbary Coast.

column12: Schooner. Ghost Ship.
column13: Barbary Corsairs speak of this ship only in whispers, fearing that saying “Le Loup-Garou” aloud will rouse the dark forces that power her to steal their souls.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against American ships.
column13: An undeclared war exists between French and American ships, but the crew of La Martinique treats it as if it is the war to end all wars.

column12: This ship gets +L to her base move if she has all of her masts.
column13: L'Afrique's speed is a weapon. The crew acts as if she is running away, but then they double back to help flank her enemies.

column12: This ship cannot sink, but she can be scuttled.
column13: Murat Rais swears he has sunk La Republique three times, and the English claim two victories—and yet she still floats and fights.

column12: Galley. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: This ship's crew swears that Joan of Arc herself protects her. Not even the Knights of Malta dare to claim otherwise.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: A French hero, Surcouf is the quintessential Corsair. His knack for hitting ships laden with treasure has ensured him the best crews, the best ships, and the wrath of every other nation.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: No one denies that Dumas has a past: advisor to the king of France, minister, merchant, thief, priest, even spy. But it is his current occupation as captain of Le Loup-Garou that makes people wonder if he has any soul left.

column11: Don Rafael Y de Teresa and Roderick the Pure
column12: Marine.
column13: As soldier for the Crown, Benoit followed orders. After being deemed too old to fight on the front lines, he found that the Knights of Malta greatly appreciated his expertise.

column12: Once at the beginning of each of your turns, roll a d6. On a result of 6, any ship in your fleet may be given two actions that turn.
column13: Made an amiral because of his victories over the English in the New World, Gaston was transferred to the Barbary Coast, where he has established his presence with the ladies in court as well as with France's enemies at sea.

column12: After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Moroccan by birth but raised in Marseilles, Youssef has the ability to blend in wherever he is, allowing him to make deals that would get anyone else the guillotine.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
column13: Crenshaw openly defies Porter's orders to concentrate on pirates and uses the Hornet to attack English ships, claiming they are the true enemy.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Since the President came to the Barbary Coast, she has become a target of the Corsairs—and a welcome sight to American merchants.

column12: Schooner. If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: Decatur has the Intrepid's crew in their dress whites at all times. He wants the Old World to see that the New World always means business.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against Barbary Corsair ships.
column13: The Minuteman's crew is exclusively made up of former Barbary Corsair captives—especially those with experience rowing their galleys.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The Concord shipped the first wave of marines to the Barbary Coast, and her crew has learned the art of close-quarters warfare from them.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against French ships.
column13: Captain Carter has yet to find proof that France is supporting some Barbary Corsair captains, but he plans to continue his raids on French ships until he does.

column12: This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: The diminutive Delaware is known as the “Sailing Fortress” because of the huge fort cannons installed on her deck.

column12: This ship's cannons may not be eliminated (masts still may be). If derelict, she cannot shoot.
column13: Appropriately tagged “Fish Food,” cannonneers of the Niagara are flogged if they ever leave their posts, even if the ship were to go down.

column12: This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks. Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: Commander of the American forces on the Barbary Coast, Decatur has vowed that no ship shall be taken by pirates. He has even gone to the extreme of sinking his own ships rather than allow them to be captured.

column12: Marine. This crew gets +1 to its gun rolls against Barbary Corsair ships and crew.
column13: Eaton was the American counsel to the Barbary States, and while Preble and Decatur lead the American forces at sea, he has begun his plan to invade the land at Tripoli.

column12: Limit, Ransom. Choose one American crew during setup; this crew is linked to that crew. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Young, trained in modern naval combat, and given orders to follow Preble and learn from him, Nolan carries with him the weight of a new county and a modern military organization.

column12: Once at the beginning of each of your turns, roll a d6. On a result of 6, any ship in your fleet may be given two actions that turn.
column13: Respected as a commander and teacher, Preble felt the only way to defeat the Barbary Corsairs was to take the battle to them. Whether on sea or land, he commands his forces to continually press the attack.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-American ship or fort.
column13: No one knows when Rice signed on with the American Navy; he's just always been there. Although he has no rank, his stories of ship engagements are so exact, and his knowledge of naval strategy so advanced, even Preble consults with him.

Double the value of one non-unique treasure on this ship when unloaded at your home island or fort, and then remove Spices from the game.
When revealed, turn all treasure on all wild islands face up for the remainder of the game. Remove Maps of Alexandria from the game.
If one of this ship's masts or crew would be eliminated by a ship, you may give Relics to the attacker instead, ending that ship's turn.
No treasure may be loaded from this wild island until Wolves is eliminated. Wolves is eliminated if successfully hit once by either a Musketeer or a crew with the Marine keyword.

This ship may dock at an opponent's home island or fort; while there, you may exchange Wine for one treasure there of your choosing. This ship cannot shoot or be shot at if it is within S of an opponent's home island or fort.
Each non-unique treasure on this ship is worth 1 fewer gold when unloaded. Rats cannot be unloaded.

column13: The Black Lotus has been seen near the Barbary Coast chasing English merchant ships loaded with goods from the Far East.

column12: Junk. This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
column13: The Tiger's Breath sails only at night, and yet even by lantern light her crew can find gold other ships can't see even in the day.

column12: After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Considered a hero by the poor, Zheng is hunted by the Ming emperor for his smuggling operation, by the English for his sinking of their ships and stealing of their goods, and by the Manchu Dynasty because of his total lack of respect for them.

column13: Young Aramis is a contradiction: both a daring musketeer defending the honor of himself, his county, and every woman in France and a philosophical and contemplative scholar. Talk of his true love only makes him fight harder.

column13: Porthos is a giant of a man who loves  wine, food, women, and gambling—in that order. He isn't one to worry about planning or strategy; just point him at the fight and let the big man go at it.
