column13: Driven by love and fueled by chivalry, the honest D'Artagnan, an outsider with no money and the sole wish to be the king's musketeer, must prove his worth to his companions and the king.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.  This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.  To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #030 from Pirates of the Spanish Main with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: Now that Blackheart has carved out an empire based on fear and terror, he can concentrate on his biggest goal: destroying the other pirates of the Spanish Main, starting with Jack Hawkins and his accursed monkey.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.  This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.  To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #033 from Pirates of the Spanish Main with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: Genny's need for vengeance against the English has only worsened since Woodes Rogers and the English military deemed her irrelevant. She is determined to make them rue their misjudgment.

column12: Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.   To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #035 from Pirates of the Spanish Main with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: Wiley's skull dice told him to secure the Sea Nymph at any cost, and he has sailed on her ever since. The ship and his dice have kept him alive, his crew showered in gold, and his named feared all over the Spanish Main.

column12: Broadsides Attack.  To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #068 from Pirates of the Spanish Main with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: Temple discovered Doone's little secret from a drunken sailor in Barbados. He has promised to keep it a secret if she will accept his hand, and now he's doing all he can to get promoted, including anything Rogers asks of him.

column12: Limit. Ransom. Choose one English crew during setup; this crew is linked to that crew. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.  To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #062 from Pirates of the Spanish Main with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: Her secret known by Commander Temple, the countess is now looking for a way out of her engagement. If it means aligning herself with America, France, Spain, or even pirates, Diana will find a way.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non–Spanish ship or fort.  To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #090 from Pirates of the Spanish Main with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: While he hunted pirates, Spain lost ground to all the other nations on the Crimson Coast. Now Del Nero has expanded his personal crusade to include any who oppose Spain—not only pirates.

column12: Broadsides Attack.   To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #096 from Pirates of the Spanish Main with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: After De Silva learned how to use cannons, he devised several clever, cannon-only strategies. At the request of the Crown, he has dedicated himself to teaching these methods to the entire Spanish fleet.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #030 from Pirates of the Crimson Coast with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: Some say Bloody Jake's lost his touch since an extended stay with some missionaries on what was thought to be a deserted island. Havana Black still stands by him…for now.

column12: Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.  To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #046 from Pirates of the Crimson Coast with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: With his civil-servant demeanor and uncanny ability to blend into a crowd, Bratley can learn all sorts of things, without anyone ever knowing who or what he is.

column5: El Duque Rafael de Moreno y Rivera
column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Barbary Corsair ships.  To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #059 from Pirates of the Crimson Coast with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: El Duque took it upon himself to sail back to the Barbary Coast, despite the Crown's objections. He is focused on fighting only Barbary Corsairs—even if it means being stripped of title, land, and even his freedom.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.  To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #018 from Pirates of the Revolution with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: Lady Baptiste knows that those who “want” her only want to use her or get her out of the way. Her personal revolution is against oppressors, whether they fly a flag of Europe, the New World, or the Jolly Roger.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against forts within S of her. She gets +1 to her boarding rolls.  To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #093 from Pirates of the Revolution with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: His heroics in battle against the English along the Atlantic Coast gained Smith the respect of the professional fighters of the new American navy. They have sent him to train at Thompson's Island so that he can continue the fight against America's enemies.

column12: Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.  To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #094 from Pirates of the Revolution with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: In his travels along the Crimson Coast, Turner made both friends and enemies. But no matter the relationship, he always walks away with more information than he had when he arrived.

column12: Ghost Ship.  To use this card, replace the ability and point cost of card #098 from Pirates of the Revolution with this card's ability and point cost.
column13: David's family gave him up for dead after Blackheart sank his ship off the Carolina coast. Yet sailors swear they still see a ship flying the David family crest and can hear his voice giving commands across the shoals when the wind is soft and the moon is high.

column12: Galley. This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: Rais Abba Quilon modified the Nubian Prince to draft deep, making her almost invisible in the water—and an impossible target for nearby ships.

column12: Galley. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The Ivory Star's hull is covered with polished ivory. From a distance, she looks like a cresting wave, entrancing opponents into a state of vulnerability.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: During boarding attacks, the crew of the Jackal's Teeth howl like ghostly dogs, striking fear in the hearts of even the most stalwart defenders.

column12: Galley. Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Crewed by outcasts of Europe and the New World, the Terror of Gibraltar plies her unique brand of piracy in the waters near its eponymous outcropping.

column12: Galley. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: The devout captain of the Crescent Moon demands that his compass be accurate so that he can face Mecca when praying, no matter the ship's heading.

column12: Galley. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: The crew of Janissaries' Blood has been culled entirely from the Barbary Coast, and Rais Murat makes sure their hatred for Europeans is matched only by their loyalty to him.

column12: Galley. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Equipped with boarding hooks and ramps, the Fire Djinn strikes with the speed of a sandstorm and the deadliness of a demon.

column12: Galley. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Uluj Ali has trained the crew of the Sea Dragon specifically to fight Spanish vessels: to board them, take prisoners, and then use the information they provide to attack their ports.

column12: Galley. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Inspired by the ancient navies of Xerxes the Great, the Persian Victory and her crew oppose any foreign power attempting to control the Barbary Coast.

column12: Galley. Eliminate one of this ship's masts when she rolls a 1 on any cannon roll.
column13: Mocked by other Barbary Corsairs, the crew of the Winds of Vengeance always press their attack—even if means the loss of ship and life.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against American ships.
column13: Rais Al-Kazar has decided that American ships are easy pickings, so he focuses the attacks of the Wicked Kareen almost exclusively on their merchant ships.

column12: Galley. After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Wesley has taken command of the Algiers, which has become the most successful Barbary Corsair ship because of his uncanny ability to turn a small supply of gold into a large one.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against French ships.
column13: Capitan Marcel, a former French privateer with a crew of ex-slaves, hunts the waters around French colonies, viciously attacking their naval support and merchant ships.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against Spanish ships.
column13: The Moorish captain of Divan's Punishment is a former prisoner of Spain who directs his attacks against their gold-bloated ships returning from the New World.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Rumor says that Rais Jaziri doesn't even load the cannons of the Sultan's Sword, so confident is he in the ship's swift attacks and even swifter swords.

column12: Galley. Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: The captain of the Splendor cares little for captives, preferring to fill his hold with what really matters: gold.

column12: Galley. Spanish ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: So great is their fear of Spain, this crew of former slaves has been known to panic when faced with a ship flying the colors of Spain.

column12: Galley.
column13: Her distinct golden sails—a gift from the pasha in Constantinople—make the Golden Peacock a glorious vision on the Barbary Coast.

column12: Galley. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The superstitious first mate of the Tiger's Eye keeps on his person a gem that he claims protects his ship from harm, and no one is willing to risk finding out if it's true.

column12: Galley. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: The Silent Death and her crew have honed the fine art of sneaking up on an unsuspecting enemy and personally waking her captain from his bunk with a sword at his throat.

column12: Galley. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: In Rais Haddou's eyes, the crew of the Bey's Revenge earn their pay only if they take down larger ships. Anything else is an insult and an embarrassment.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Trained by Sicilian sailors and taught warfare by the pasha's soldiers, Rais Baha can estimate how long it will take to capture a ship, down to the minute.

column12: Galley. Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The crew of the Gallows are outcast pirates from the Caribbean who escaped a hanging to try their fortunes on the Barbary Coast. They named their ship so as to never forget life's quirks.

column12: Galley. This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: The galley master has been told it will be his life if the ship's oarsmen ever miss a beat, thus the uncanny ability of the Desert Wind to close on ships even in battle.

column12: Galley. Spanish ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: Nothing is known of the captain of this vessel except that the king of Spain himself put an enormous price on his head.

column12: Galley. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The colors flown by the Pasha's Delight imply that she's nothing more than a harmless merchant vessel—allowing her crew to take advantage of opponents not cunning enough to see through her deception.

column12: Galley. Eliminate one of this ship's masts when she rolls a 1 on any cannon roll.
column13: This once-great warship has started to show her age—it is a rare day when she enters port with plunder.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against English ships.
column13: After his old ship was sunk by the English, Rais Yahia vowed to pay the widows of his lost crew twice—once with England's blood and once with her gold.

column12: Galley. This ship's base move becomes S when she reaches her cargo limit.
column13: The crew of the Dervish prefers to grab what it can and then flee, even if means leaving other treasure behind. After all, gold never helped a dead man.

column12: Galley. Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down treasure on any island.
column13: With contacts in every port along the Barbary Coast, Rais Oudah seems to know more about what ships are carrying than their own captains do.

column12: Galley. American ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: The Griffin was the first ship to capture an American crew—and then sell them back to their own. American sailors have thus made the ship their number-one target.

column12: Galley. This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: The Tripoli's captain keeps a captured noble on board at all times. He uses them as an excuse for trade, getting close enough to bigger ships to surprise them with an attack.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: This tiny vessel was actually named by the English for her ability to attack larger ships and leave them in disarray while she escapes.

column12: Galley. When this ship carries no cargo, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: The greedy crew of the Whisper has been known to fill the ship's holds with anything and everything they can get, even if it means crawling back to port.

column12: Galley. Friendly ships within S of this ship get +1 to their cannon rolls.
column13: The Majestic has survived as long as she has by scouting for other Barbary Corsairs. The pay is so good that the crew doesn't even need to fight.

column12: Galley. This ship may not be shot at while docked.
column13: By having their oarsmen row the Carthage onto shore, the crew ensures that she is ignored by both sea and coastal cannons.

column12: Galley. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Rais Zaci is well aware of the Nimcha's shortcomings, so he trained her oarsmen to fire cannons while rowing, all without missing a beat.

column12: Galley. This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
column13: The value of knowing where treasure may be hidden is more valuable to Rais Taha than any shipping chart.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. If this ship wins a boarding party, she may capture the crew with the highest point cost instead of eliminating it. This captured crew becomes cargo worth its point cost in gold when unloaded at your home island.
column13: Known for his red beard, Aruj is credited with the creation of the first Barbary Corsair fleets. Under his leadership, they began their domination of the Barbary Coast by proving that the galley could take on the biggest European ships.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Rumors persist that Wesley is an English noble who has been denied his birthright because of his common mother. Taking to piracy, he has decided that he will buy his place with the gold of those who denied him.

column12: Once at the beginning of each of your turns, roll a d6. On a result of 6, any ship in your fleet may be given two actions that turn.
column13: Kheir-ed-din (gift of God) is the strategic half of his partnership with his charismatic brother, Aruj. He leads the fleets of the Barbary Corsairs and works both for the emir of Ottoman Empire and the sultan of Tunis.

column12: Marine. This crew gets +1 to its gun rolls against Spanish ships, forts, and crew.
column13: An Italian by birth and a sailor by profession, Uluj rose to command Barbary Corsairs by ceaselessly attacking Spanish ships, holdings, and nobility.

column12: Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship. Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Because pirate hunting had become the priority of both the Americans and English in the New World, Jack decided to seek his fortune elsewhere. After landing at Tangier, he saw the piles of gold—and he knew he was home.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non–Barbary Corsair ship.
column13: Rais Murat was once a prisoner of the Barbary Corsairs, but he has since been granted his freedom and a ship. To make himself known to every sailor on the Mediterranean, Murat hunts every ship that does not fly the Barbary Corsair flag.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against forts within S of her. She gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Dragut retook Tripoli from the Spanish after a bloody and bitter battle. He learned that there was more to life than just sailing, and that any man who sailed with him had to be able to fight both on land and on sea.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: Described by his former English commander as “a drunk, a fool, and an idiot,” Ward decided that stealing for himself was better than serving as a “slave” on an English warship.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
column13: Haunted by the abuse he suffered when captured by pirates on his first tour of duty, Olano has vowed to hunt down every pirate on sea or land and exact his revenge.

column12: Galley. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against Barbary Corsair ships.
column13: Captured by Robert Blake and then turned over to the Knights of Malta, the Alexandria is feared by the Barbary Corsairs for both her firepower and the ferocity of her crew.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Lawrence has tuned the crew of HMS Durham to perfection using both the tactics of the Barbary Corsairs and the training of the Royal Navy.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Commodore Owen fills the cannons of the fearsome Granville with grapeshot so that they can take out as many Barbary Corsairs as possible.

column12: Schooner. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: Captain Hawley flies the flags of over 30 nations from HMS Westminster in an effort to confuse enemies and give his crew the upper hand in combat.
Small, fast, and perpetually leaky, HMS Antelope is crewed by Barrett's Privateers, and she is charged with harassing anyone not flying the Union Jack.

column12: Two hits from the same shoot action are required to eliminate one of this ship's masts.
column13: Financed privately and constructed of the hardiest materials, HMS Lord Kenyon prowls the profitable Barbary Coast, preying upon those who underestimate her.

column12: Galley. This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: The Knights of Malta were trained by the Royal Navy to dodge cannon fire at close range, allowing the St. George to get up close and personal.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Barbary Corsair ships. Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Given the title “General of the Sea” by the Crown, Admiral Blake is the supreme commander of the English fleets. With a selfless sense of duty, he has created the greatest naval force the world has seen, and yet he is still considered a gentleman, a sailor, and a scholar.

column12: Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.
column13: After going “native,” Ethan Lawrence was stripped of his commission in the Royal Navy. But his very public exploits as “England's Own Corsair,” coupled with his rescue of HMS Durham from a Barbary Corsair sneak attack, forced the Crown to give him back his command.

column11: Don Rafael Y de Teresa, Benoit de Marseilles
column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: With rumors of a crime of passion swirling around him, Roderick left England as a sailor. Fighting alongside the Knights of Malta, he came to see them as the true protectors of the kingdoms of Europe. So he left the Royal Navy to become a warrior in the fight against the Barbary Corsair scourge.

column12: Limit. Ransom. Choose one English crew during setup; this crew is linked to that crew. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Being given a new command on the Barbary Coast would seem like a promotion to any other naval officer, but Owen feels that he is being punished. Did he learn too much about Countess Doone or question the commands of Woodes Rogers too often? The only directive he gets is to destroy the Corsairs at all costs.

column12: This ship gets +1 cargo spaces. This crew takes up no cargo space.
column13: Egyptian by birth, but schooled and trained in colonial schools in Cairo, Ismail realized that the Royal Navy was his ticket out of the slums. His ability to deal with locals gets his ships the best deals and the fastest cargo turnovers.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
column13: Trained by Amiral Dupuy, the crew of La Félicité know that they must perform at the highest level to honor their country and flag.

column12: Galley. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: La Espada del Dios is a captured galley disguised as a Barbary Corsair ship, and her capitan is happy to let them take the blame for his plunders.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against Barbary Corsair ships.
column13: The mighty Granada is Admiral Castro's flagship in the Mediterranean. She is known for ruthlessly hunting Corsairs to the very ends of the Earth.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Capitan Carral won the Pamplona in a game of dice, and he feels that with the goddess of luck on his side, he and his crew can meet any challenge.

column12: Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.
column13: The crew of El Paso come from all over the Barbary Coast, and Capitan Carrillo's contacts range from the throne rooms of Europe to the lowliest taverns.

column12: You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: La Serpiente's crew are the finest cannoneers on the Barbary Coast. It is said they can hit a ship docked in Morocco from Barcelona.

column12: This ship's cannons may not be eliminated (masts still may be). If derelict, she cannot shoot.
column13: El Toro, like a bull on a rampage, is sent into fleets of Barbary Corsairs with one purpose: to destroy galleys.

column12: Galley. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: The crew of El Alonso de Orozco must swear loyalty to the Knights of Malta over Spain.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Barbary Corsair crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Tariq the Black uses his Moorish heritage to recruit Barbary Corsairs to sail for Spain as part of a deal he brokered with the Crown. He has been promised the kingship of Morocco as a reward for destroying the Corsairs.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Barbary Corsair ships. Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Freda is an experienced sailor who once owned a large shipping fleet in Naples—before it was all destroyed by Barbary Corsairs. He has agreed to work with Spain in exchange for a fleet to liberate his home from Barbarossa.

column11: Roderick the Pure, Benoit de Marseilles
column12: When another face-up crew on this ship would be eliminated, turn it face down instead.
column13: As a doctor to the Crown, Don Rafael had all the prestige a man could want. But he knew that his skills were needed for a higher calling. He became a Knight of Malta, and now he uses his gifts to ease the pain of those fighting the Corsair scourge.

column12: Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: Promoted and transferred to the Barbary Coast, Admiral Castro's plans to destroy every Castilian who opposed him has softened, as he has become a welcome fixture in the royal court and drawing rooms of a new Spain.

column12: Limit, Ransom. Choose one Spanish crew during setup; this crew is linked to that crew. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Duque Vaccaro, also known as the “Golden Tongue,” is Spain's most important negotiator. He alone can interrupt the king at any hour, and his imperatives often become reality. He has been dispatched to the Italian city-states, the Knights of Malta, and even to England and France.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
Galley. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: The Knights of Malta recruit French Corsairs to crew Le St. Denis so that they can fight the Barbary Corsairs on equal footing.

column12: Schooner. If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: L'Ange de la Mer survived battles with the English that sent many of her sister ships to the bottom of the sea. She has earned the distinction of flagship on the Barbary Coast.

column12: Schooner. Ghost Ship.
column13: Barbary Corsairs speak of this ship only in whispers, fearing that saying “Le Loup-Garou” aloud will rouse the dark forces that power her to steal their souls.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against American ships.
column13: An undeclared war exists between French and American ships, but the crew of La Martinique treats it as if it is the war to end all wars.

column12: This ship gets +L to her base move if she has all of her masts.
column13: L'Afrique's speed is a weapon. The crew acts as if she is running away, but then they double back to help flank her enemies.

column12: This ship cannot sink, but she can be scuttled.
column13: Murat Rais swears he has sunk La Republique three times, and the English claim two victories—and yet she still floats and fights.

column12: Galley. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: This ship's crew swears that Joan of Arc herself protects her. Not even the Knights of Malta dare to claim otherwise.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: A French hero, Surcouf is the quintessential Corsair. His knack for hitting ships laden with treasure has ensured him the best crews, the best ships, and the wrath of every other nation.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: No one denies that Dumas has a past: advisor to the king of France, minister, merchant, thief, priest, even spy. But it is his current occupation as captain of Le Loup-Garou that makes people wonder if he has any soul left.

column11: Don Rafael Y de Teresa and Roderick the Pure
column12: Marine.
column13: As soldier for the Crown, Benoit followed orders. After being deemed too old to fight on the front lines, he found that the Knights of Malta greatly appreciated his expertise.

column12: Once at the beginning of each of your turns, roll a d6. On a result of 6, any ship in your fleet may be given two actions that turn.
column13: Made an amiral because of his victories over the English in the New World, Gaston was transferred to the Barbary Coast, where he has established his presence with the ladies in court as well as with France's enemies at sea.

column12: After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Moroccan by birth but raised in Marseilles, Youssef has the ability to blend in wherever he is, allowing him to make deals that would get anyone else the guillotine.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
column13: Crenshaw openly defies Porter's orders to concentrate on pirates and uses the Hornet to attack English ships, claiming they are the true enemy.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Since the President came to the Barbary Coast, she has become a target of the Corsairs—and a welcome sight to American merchants.

column12: Schooner. If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: Decatur has the Intrepid's crew in their dress whites at all times. He wants the Old World to see that the New World always means business.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls and boarding rolls against Barbary Corsair ships.
column13: The Minuteman's crew is exclusively made up of former Barbary Corsair captives—especially those with experience rowing their galleys.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The Concord shipped the first wave of marines to the Barbary Coast, and her crew has learned the art of close-quarters warfare from them.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against French ships.
column13: Captain Carter has yet to find proof that France is supporting some Barbary Corsair captains, but he plans to continue his raids on French ships until he does.

column12: This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: The diminutive Delaware is known as the “Sailing Fortress” because of the huge fort cannons installed on her deck.

column12: This ship's cannons may not be eliminated (masts still may be). If derelict, she cannot shoot.
column13: Appropriately tagged “Fish Food,” cannonneers of the Niagara are flogged if they ever leave their posts, even if the ship were to go down.

column12: This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks. Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: Commander of the American forces on the Barbary Coast, Decatur has vowed that no ship shall be taken by pirates. He has even gone to the extreme of sinking his own ships rather than allow them to be captured.

column12: Marine. This crew gets +1 to its gun rolls against Barbary Corsair ships and crew.
column13: Eaton was the American counsel to the Barbary States, and while Preble and Decatur lead the American forces at sea, he has begun his plan to invade the land at Tripoli.

column12: Limit, Ransom. Choose one American crew during setup; this crew is linked to that crew. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Young, trained in modern naval combat, and given orders to follow Preble and learn from him, Nolan carries with him the weight of a new county and a modern military organization.

column12: Once at the beginning of each of your turns, roll a d6. On a result of 6, any ship in your fleet may be given two actions that turn.
column13: Respected as a commander and teacher, Preble felt the only way to defeat the Barbary Corsairs was to take the battle to them. Whether on sea or land, he commands his forces to continually press the attack.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-American ship or fort.
column13: No one knows when Rice signed on with the American Navy; he's just always been there. Although he has no rank, his stories of ship engagements are so exact, and his knowledge of naval strategy so advanced, even Preble consults with him.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll a d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
Double the value of one non-unique treasure on this ship when unloaded at your home island or fort, and then remove Spices from the game.
When revealed, turn all treasure on all wild islands face up for the remainder of the game. Remove Maps of Alexandria from the game.
If one of this ship's masts or crew would be eliminated by a ship, you may give Relics to the attacker instead, ending that ship's turn.
No treasure may be loaded from this wild island until Wolves is eliminated. Wolves is eliminated if successfully hit once by either a Musketeer or a crew with the Marine keyword.

This ship may dock at an opponent's home island or fort; while there, you may exchange Wine for one treasure there of your choosing. This ship cannot shoot or be shot at if it is within S of an opponent's home island or fort.
Each non-unique treasure on this ship is worth 1 fewer gold when unloaded. Rats cannot be unloaded.

If loaded by a Barbary Corsair ship, Knights of Malta Banner is worth 5 gold when unloaded at your home island. If loaded by another nation's ship, it is worth 1 gold for every mast that ship eliminates while Knights of Malta Banner is aboard.

If loaded by a Barbary Corsair ship, Barbary Banner is worth 1 gold for every mast that ship eliminates while Barbary Banner is aboard. If loaded by another nation's ship, it is worth 5 gold when unloaded at your home island.
This ship cannot be given shoot actions. Wet Gunpowder cannot be unloaded from this ship, but you may give this ship a repair action to eliminate Wet Gunpowder instead of repairing a mast.

Load this treasure face down. When this ship is given a move action, you may reveal Poseidon's Breath: This ship may move her base move as many times as she has masts; no other special abilities may affect her movement. When the movement action ends, eliminate one of this ship's masts, and then remove Poseidon's Breath from the game.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, you may declare that one of her cannons is shooting a smokepot instead of a cannon; you do not need to target a ship. Simply place the center of a fog bank within S of this ship; it may not touch an island or any ship docked at an island. Remove the fog bank at the beginning of your next turn.

Simply place the center of a fog bank within S of this ship; it may not touch an island or any ship docked at an island. Remove the fog bank at the beginning of your next turn.

Simply place the center of a fog bank within S of this ship; it may not touch an island or any ship docked at an island. Remove the fog bank at the beginning of your next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, you may declare that one of her cannons is shooting a smokepot instead of a cannon; you do not need to target a ship. Simply place the center of a fog bank within S of this ship; it may not touch an island or any ship docked at an island. Remove the fog bank at the beginning of your next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, you may declare that one of her cannons is shooting a smokepot instead of a cannon; you do not need to target a ship. Simply place the center of a fog bank within S of this ship; it may not touch an island or any ship docked at an island. Remove the fog bank at the beginning of your next turn.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gains one S range cannon, with a rank of 3 that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a chainshot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the chainshot before rolling the d6. If the chainshot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target cannot move on her next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a stinkpot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the stinkpot before rolling the d6. If the stinkpot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target's crew cannot use their abilities on the target's next turn.
This ship may repair at sea or at any island.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, you may declare that one of her cannons is shooting a smokepot instead of a cannon; you do not need to target a ship. Simply place the center of a fog bank within S of this ship; it may not touch an island or any ship docked at an island. Remove the fog bank at the beginning of your next turn.
This ship gains one S range cannon, with a rank of 3 that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gains one S range cannon, with a rank of 3 that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gains one S range cannon, with a rank of 3 that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).

Junk. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: The Black Lotus has been seen near the Barbary Coast chasing English merchant ships loaded with goods from the Far East.

column12: Junk. This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
column13: The Tiger's Breath sails only at night, and yet even by lantern light her crew can find gold other ships can't see even in the day.

column12: After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Considered a hero by the poor, Zheng is hunted by the Ming emperor for his smuggling operation, by the English for his sinking of their ships and stealing of their goods, and by the Manchu Dynasty because of his total lack of respect for them.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
Junk. If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: Ms. Cheng's flagship is known as a symbol of the Jade Rebellion's ruthlessness and desperation. She will often hunt previously-damaged ships to sink them once and for all.

column12: Junk. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Captain Xuang has turned his ship into a floating temple for Sensei Xu who thus inspiring his crew to push themselves harder to achieve things normal crews cannot.

column12: Junk. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: The Grand Mountain was commissioned with one single-minded purpose: to hunt down and destroy the English colonists invading the South China Seas.

column12: Junk. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: The Great Wind is so named because of her unnatural ability to sail under even the slightest breeze, or for her cannons to hit even the smallest target. It is said the wind itself loves her so much that it assists her at every opportunity.

column12: Junk. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The Grand Path is crewed by those who adhere to the old warrior codes. Her crew has gained a reputation for fierceness in battle, and many captains stay away so they do not have to face her skilled warriors.

column12: Junk. If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: Captained by the turncoat Englishman named Warlord Cavendish, the Divine Wind preys on the weakest ships – no matter what flag they sail under.

column12: Junk. After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: The crew of the East Wind made a fortune trading silks and spices before the European colonization. They continue in their old trade, but in secrecy rather than in the open, having established a network of secret island ports.

column12: Junk. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls for every friendly ship within S of her.
column13: Admiral Hwong's forceful presence on the Sea Wind is an inspiration to all other members of the Jade Rebellion, inspiring them to great acts whenever they sail together against the European colonists.

column12: Junk. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: The Typhoon had no name until the mysterious Dragon Eyes saw it survive the great spring storm that batter the Japanese coast. After killing it's captain and crew Dragons Eyes assumed command and no considers himself a force of nature.

column12: Junk. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: The sailors crewing the Wind of Virtue have built a shrine honoring their ancestors and imploring their guidance. They attribute their skill at stealing plunder from under their enemies noses to the helping hand of their forefathers.

column12: Junk. If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: The captain of the Clear Wind, a mysterious man who calls himself Xiu, claims to have lived in the Spanish colonies in the new world and learned the secrets of European naval tactics. Whether this is true or not, the Clear Wind often takes advantage of weaknesses in her enemies with startling precision.

column12: Junk. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: The Sea Dragon was built for speed, and can outrun and outmaneuver many European and American ships intent on colonizing the South China Seas. She has taken many larger prizes and is a constant thorn in the side of European powers.

column12: Junk. When this ship is docked at your home island, you may eliminate one treasure. It becomes a 3S cannon that can be eliminated only when the ship sinks.
column13: The Sea Lion's crew contains captured European metalworkers, who are made to continually upgrade the ship's weapons. Rumors abound that these men are not prisoners but defectors, and both Spain and France have issued enormous bounties for the capture of this ship.

column12: Junk.
column13: The Sea Tiger first honed her skills against the Europeans off the coast of India and Ceylon before returning home to join the Jade Rebellion against the growing threat of colonization in the South China Sea.

column12: Junk. One of this ship's treasures is worth +1 gold when she docks at your home island.
column13: Captain Yuong of the Sea Crane is as shrewd a businessman as he is a sailor, and can often fence his ill-gotten goods at prices other pirates can only dream of – although he has been forced to beat a hasty retreat when the other side realized they'd been had!

column12: Junk. Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: The captain of the Sea Phoenix, Suong, studied naval tactics at several schools in Europe. He has turned his knowledge of the ins and outs of European ships into a lucrative business of stealing cargo without actually engaging the enemy.

column12: Junk. You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: The Sea Duck's guns are legendary on the South China Seas. The Calico Cat once claimed that the Sea Duck's gunners blew her crow's nest off from five miles away.

column12: Turtle Ship. If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: The Admiral Yi is so unusual, it is rumored that Captain Jack Hawkins considered making the journey to the South China Seas just to take a shot at capturing her.

column12: Turtle Ship. This ship cannot be pinned.
column13: Although covered in metal, the crew of the Hansan Island have found ways to maneuver their ship out of situations others would deem hopeless and has survived more encounters with the French navy than any other ship.

column12: Turtle Ship. On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew and one mast from the enemy ship.
column13: The Glorious Treasure was so named when the crew - a bunch of theives and murders -  found that that the name itself will attach larger ship and more stupid captains to investigate her.

column12: Turtle Ship. Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: The Noble Swan was constructed of the hardest iron and oak. Ships that attempt to ram her find themselves splintering, while the Noble Swan's jeering crew prepare to turn the hunter into the hunted.

column12: Turtle Ship. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The Proud Tortoise is festooned with the aphorisms of Kong Tzu, inspiring its crew not only to great deeds in battle, but to remind them of their place in the grand scheme of the universe.

column12: Once per turn, you may eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action. After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Ever since England teamed up with Hong Kong merchants to sink his first ship, Kwan has lived by one edict: Destroy each and every enemy you face. Only their deaths will bring you peace.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: With over 100 junks at his disposal and bases hidden along the Chinese coast, Tsai claims that he will be the one to topple the English empire.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Some say that Katsura-chan was a member of a secret warrior caste that trained women in the art of deception and espionage. Since falling in love with an American sailor, however, she has taken to the sea to follow her heart.

column12: Limit. Ransom. Choose one Jade Rebellion crew during setup; this crew is linked to that crew. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: When her husband died, Ms. Cheng found herself in charge of the largest pirate network in the South China Seas. Now she and her new lover, Chang Pao, run the fleet even better than her husband did.

column12: When this ship hits an enemy ship, you may also eliminate one cargo from that ship.
column13: Kian Ng is a pyrotechnic savant. He can not only blow up an enemy ship, but also do it with colorful patterns and with such style that even other enemy ships will sit and watch rather than continue their attacks.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non–Jade Rebellion ship.
column13: Once just another Jade Rebellion sailor, Pao was handpicked by Ms. Cheng to be her personal captain. He now leads her fleet with an iron hand, demanding allegiance of all who sail for him.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. If this ship wins a boarding party, she may capture the crew with the highest point cost instead of eliminating it. This captured crew becomes cargo worth its point cost in gold when unloaded at your home island.
column13: The real name of Dragon Eyes is kept by the sea. Those who survive his attacks claim that he is really a dragon in human form…and the captives he takes, well, they are just food.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Dragon Eyes' crew is a group as soulless as he. They never speak, they never get captured—and they never lose.

column12: Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship. Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: English by birth, Lloyd Stephen Cavendish was sent by the East Indian Trading Company to open up more Chinese ports. After a jungle encounter, he gained the allegiance of the Jade Rebellion, who call him “warlord.”

column12: This crew takes up no cargo space when revealed. When revealed, put a crew with point cost 2 or less from outside of the game onto this ship.
column13: It is every captain's honor to have Sensei Xu on his ship. Many have even given up their own quarters to make him comfortable. His longevity and wisdom are legend, and he seems to offer protection to any ship on which he sails.

column12: Limit, Ransom. Place this crew face up during setup. You may build your fleet using 5 more points than the game's build total. This crew cannot leave this ship unless captured or eliminated.
column13: A Hong Kong trader and middleman, Li Quin knows everyone, from the lowliest dock worker to England's royal ambassador. Nothing is out of his reach, and if he hasn't heard about it, then it just doesn't exist.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
Broadsides Attack.
column13: Calico Cat has outfitted the Lady's Scorn with the largest cannons she can carry, and has been reported in the South China Seas hunting for someone who crossed her. Everyone agrees that whomever Calico Cat seeks, that person will not live to tell about the encounter.

column12: Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Captain Rontacourt collects sailors from different nations like other pirates collect coins, taking great pains to protect “rare” crew from harm.

column12: Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Under the command of Headhunter, this ship—the former HMS Conrad—was painted black from stern to sails to reinforce her “heart of darkness” mystique.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Commanded by an imposing giant who calls himself Commodore Brumwell, the Bloody Spear is known for sailing directly at enemy ships—ignoring cannon fire and swarming the decks!

column12: This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks.
column13: With a crew of convicts the Accused loves the irony of her name. Gray's crew would rather die freemen at sea than spend another second in the Australian penal colonies.

column12: After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Making its home port on the pirate haven for which it's named, the Madagascar plies the South China Seas each spring, plundering the silk routes, before returning home each fall laden with booty.

column12: One of this ship's treasures is worth +2 gold when unloaded at your home island.
column13: The captain of Greed's Hammer struck a deal with his crew that so long as a single breath remained in his body, he would get them more gold than they weigh. So far he has lived up to that promise.

column12: Once per turn, if this ship carries treasure and is within S of an enemy ship, you may randomly trade one treasure with that ship.
column13: The Plague of the East and her crew go out of their way to attack American ships. Some say that she is merely the pawn a European power that does not wish to claim responsibility for the attacks.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: Fleeing an insult to his honor in New Orleans, Yarborgh renamed he ship found a new crew and left for the South China Seas to prove his worth.

column12: When this ship carries no cargo, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: Captain de la Cruz  insists that he is the son of a Spanish Count. His crew do not dispute this as long as de la Cruz continues to bring them the fat prizes of French and English merchants on the silk routes.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Pirate ship. Once per turn, you may eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action.
column13: The Headhunter does not heed the call of civilization. His appearance—the human bones that hang from his neck and decorate his ship—and tribal crew put him in a different category of pirate: the soulless.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Too successful in the Atlantic, the Cat became a target of every nation that sailed there.  But it was treachery by her own crew that nearly led her to the gallows.  Disguised as a widowed Puritan, she escaped to the Pacific, where she has but one goal: to amass enough power to return for her revenge.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Kanhoji Angria watched as the English came to his small village and established themselves as masters. Taking the fight to the English, he strives to steal back the wealth taken from his beloved country.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non–Pirate ship.
column13: En route to an Australian penal colony, Bruce Grey led a mutiny aboard the ship. Taking his newly renamed ship to the South China Seas, Grey has only one agenda: never to be chained again. His men are loyal because Grey means their freedom.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Jade Rebellion ships.
column13: The Lord Kettering has been charged with keeping the peace in England's fledgling colonies in the South China Seas.

column12: As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Dampier has given his crew the right to attack without regard - if there is to be a price to pay he will accept it. Hs crew has responded with the will to attack everyone with gusto.

column12: Schooner. When touching a Jade Rebellion ship, this ship may load as much of that ship's treasure as she can carry.
column13: Captain Griffin has accepted Ken Wang Cho on his ship as a naval apprentice. With a native on his ship, Griffin discovered that the key to  taking goods is to show your enemy that you are really a friend.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +L to her base move if she has all of her masts.
column13: A converted whaling ship, the Galapagos is one of the fastest vessels in the South China Sea, and acts as an interdictor when the Jade Rebellion tries to move goods without the proper interference of English taxation.

column12: After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: The HMS Cheshire is one of the oldest ships in England's fleet, but even after countless careenings and refittings she looks as good as the day she was launched.

column12: This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: Captain Merimount commands the Prince of Chichester with exceptional skill reflective of his studies at England's Naval Academy.

column12: This ship's cannons may not be eliminated (masts still may be). If derelict, she cannot shoot.
column13: The Hibernia developed a reputation for speed, but even so enemies often underestimate her quickness in naval combat – something Captain Kenyon uses to his advantage.

column12: Jade Rebellion crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Captain Lucius has taken a different tack in his struggle against the Jade Rebellion: make friends of them first, so they cannot resist the lure of English gold.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The Resolute patrols England's many penal colonies in the South China Seas, offering protection when necessary and occasionally pressing the most bloodthirsty murderers into service.

column12: Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: When the science crew abourd the Discovery saw the riches of man - jade, gold, and gems - the riches of nature became the last thing they cared for.

column12: Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship. Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Is Dampier a pirate? The Spanish whose ships he sank claim so. What about a loyal vassal of the Crown? He did twice circumnavigate the globe under the English flag. Or is he just a lucky wag whose journals captured the imaginations of the English and made him a household name?

column12: Once per turn, if this ship is within S of an island, you may mark the island as explored without docking at it. The island becomes unexplored in regards to all other players.
column13: James Cook opened up the Pacific Ocean to the English, and his uncanny ability to map each and every piece of land he has encountered means that the sun never sets on the English empire.

column12: Jade Rebellion crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Recruited from a successful Hong Kong trading family to learn the ways of the English navy, Ken Wang Cho offers England a unique benefit: unlimited sailors without consideration of loyalty.

column12: Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns: As a free action, dock one of your ships at the nearest unexplored wild island or the nearest wild island with no treasure on it.
Once per turn, if this ship carries treasure and is within S of an enemy ship, you may randomly trade one treasure with that ship.
column13: Colin Maberly's success can be directly attributed to his appetite for linguistic clarity: He learned Mandarin, Cantonese, and even Japanese, not only always to be understood, but also always to understand.

column12: Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns: Remove all events from the game.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
Broadsides Attack.
column13: Superstitious Spanish sailors renamed Spain's flagship the “Voice of God” because of the thunderous noise her many cannons make when she attacks.

column12: Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: Admiral del Gato himself has made the Santa Anna his personal ship, and the precision of command and motivation he lends the sailors make her a formidable opponent in any battle.

column12: Schooner. If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: The Prince de Asturias was reassigned to the South China Seas after leading several successful campaigns against the Barbary Corsairs in the Mediterranean. Now, her crew uses their considerable experience against the Jade Rebellion.

column12: You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: Crewed by a mix of Aztec and Incan Indians from the Caribbean, La Habana has been charged with hunting English and French merchants.

column12: One of this ship's treasures is worth +2 gold when unloaded at your home island.
column13: El Alquimista's capitan, Cesar Bonilla, has developed a reputation for finding the most lucrative prizes in the South China Seas. Some say he can even convert silk to gold!

column12: Jade Rebellion crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Although she flies the Spanish flag, La Anunciada is all but a renegade ship, freely mingling with the Jade Rebellion and her capitan openly expressing sympathy for the Jade Rebellion's cause.

column12: After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: The San Agustin and her crew have been charged with exploring the Philippine archipelago and rooting out any banditry there.

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Capitan Vencinia of El Algeciras is a crafty swashbuckler, often offering to destroy English and French ships for the ability to dock at the other's ports. While there he steals their treasure before they can discover his deception.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: One of the few female captains in the Spanish Fleet, Elisa Vega instructs the San Leandro to feign ignorance when dealing with other ships - and then striking at the last instant.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Headquartered in Manila with a fleet of older ships, the almirante has found himself increasingly detached from the court in Madrid. His goal is to visit each island in the Philippines to make sure they are loyal to him—and possibly also to Spain.

column12: Jade Rebellion crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Discovered sleeping in the hull of a Spanish merchant ship, Horacio was granted a choice: death or servitude. He has since worked for Spain as a lesson to the rebellious Filipino factions.

column12: Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns and choose an enemy ship. Remove any treasure printed with a gold value on that ship from the game, and then remove False Treasure from the game.
This crew takes up no cargo space when revealed. When revealed, put a crew with point cost 2 or less from outside of the game onto this ship.
column13: Sent to convert the Filipinos, Padre Francisco discovered that although it is his job to save souls, others would rather buy and sell them. It is this conflict that the good padre has not yet resolved in his heart.

column12: Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns and place its token on a fog bank: At the beginning of each of your turns, roll one d6 and move the fog bank 1S in the direction that matches the die result.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non–French ship.
column13: In a race to control the Pacific, the French have pinned their hopes on the Gaule; a ship that lost crew to the English in the Barbary Coast and the Americans in the Atlantic and has no intention of losing anything ever again.

column12: Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: La Scipion began her voyages on the Spanish Main before journeying to the South China Seas. Along the way, she has picked up a colorful crew comprising almost every conceivable nationality.

column12: Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: This fast, sleek ship seems to stay ahead of everyone in her quest to create maps of unexplored areas and to track the enemy for her country.

column12: Schooner. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Le Pluton makes her home port in Fiji, but she plies the Pacific looking for easy merchant prizes. Her crew has been known to board ships much larger than she, earning them a reputation for bravery—or stupidity.

column12: After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: La Corse sports massive 20-pound cannons, and her crew has been specially trained to fire them. She first used them at Trafalgar, and has since enjoyed a long and lucrative tour in the South China Seas.

column12: This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: La Mont Blanc's captain, Jacque LeDeux, insists that his crew go through a series of drills three times a day. As a result, they are one of the most frighteningly effective crews in the South China Seas.

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: L'Heros sails with unofficial orders to find and sack enemy ports. She is often spotted sailing out of a harbor at night, laden with ill-gotten loot.

column12: This ship's base move becomes S when she reaches her cargo limit.
column13: The crew of La Fureur-a captured English ship-claim she still stinks of blood pudding and limes. That has not stopped them from disrupting English shipping throughout the South China Seas.

column12: This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: Calico Cat lost L'Argus in a game of dice with a Frenchman in New Orleans. Calico Cat has offered a bounty to anyone who can reclaim her.

column12: Once per turn, if this ship is within S of an island, you may mark the island as explored without docking at it. The island becomes unexplored in regards to all other players.
column13: A sailor, scientist, botanist, and geographer, Baudin discovered a way to safely transport plants and animals to France from the South China Seas. Even as he sends one ship back, he buys another to keep mapping and exploring.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-French ship.
column13: After raiding and plundering holdings along the west coast of South America, Barbinais found himself in the South China Seas. The wealth of the English ships there has taken his plundering to a whole new level.

column12: Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns and place its token anywhere on the play area (except on an island or terrain): Any die rolls made for ships within L of the token get -2 to their results.

Always place this crew face up; it cannot be eliminated unless its ship sinks. Crew placed on this ship cost no points, but they always each take up one cargo space. When this ship is hit, roll a d6. On a result of 5 or 6, move the crew on this ship with the highest point cost to a wild island chosen by the player to your left.
column13: Arii Auraa was captured by a lecherous captain who planned to keep her forever.  After her father prayed to the sea gods to avenge his daughter, the captain was struck dead after eating bad dates.  Since then, ships carrying the princess have been beset by strange events.

column12: Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns: Choose one of your crew and one enemy crew. For each chosen crew, roll a d6 and add the result to the crew's point cost. The crew with the lowest result is removed from the game. In case of a tie, remove both crew from the game. Then remove Duel from the game.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: The Thomas Jefferson is the symbol of America's growing military might in the South China Seas. Made of the finest New England oak and crewed by men who believe that nothing shall stop this new country-be it friend or foe.

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: Captain Mason outfitted the Appalachian with cannons he purchased himself and his claims that those cannons are used to protect American merchants seem to mean he can fire on enemy ships without provocation.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Captain Harper commands the Hudson with an iron fist. His crew often grumble about their tasks, but are fiercely loyal and would follow him to Hell and back if he were to ask it.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
column13: Captain Dunne has made contacts throughout the South China Seas, and at any one time he knows the location of a half-dozen valuable prize ships, making him a favorite among his men.

column12: Other ships do not block this ship's line of fire.
column13: USS Montezuma's stacked guns represent an American innovation in ship design. After they were used to defeat the Barbary Corsairs, all enemies now seem like a piece of cake.

column12: When this ship hits another ship, you choose which mast is eliminated.
column13: USS Valley Forge patrols the waters around Manila, preying on Spanish merchants hauling spice and rubber over the long trek through the Pacific.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-American ship or fort.
column13: Captain Hughes hand-picked the worst rejects of the American Navy for his crew – not because of their sailing ability, but because they will fight with a ferocity that makes them worth a half-dozen of their better-trained peers.

column12: Friendly ships within S of this ship get +1 to their cannon rolls.
column13: The Springfield has been painted in shades of Red, White, and Blue, making her an inspiration to American sailors so far from home and family on the South China Seas.

column12: You own any derelict this ship explores; both ships become docked at your home island.
column13: When Captian Arnaud was given his orders to sail to the South China Sea - included were secret orders, capture as many ships as you can, any way you can.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
column13: The Annapolis is used as a training vessel for the American Navy, but was assigned to regular duty suppressing native rebellions in the South China Seas.

column12: Limit. Ransom. Place this crew face up during setup. You may build your fleet using 5 more points than the game's build total. This crew cannot leave this ship unless captured or eliminated.
column13: Commodore Perry docked near Tokyo and demanded an audience with the emperor, opening up Japan to the West.  But it also earned the wrath of the Jade Rebellion, who saw only more imperial trouble.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: No one knows much about Gus Schultz.  He doesn't discuss his past, even when you can get him to talk.  Some claim he's not even American.  But despite his anonymity, his ability to disappear in a crowd has rendered him invaluable.

column12: Place this crew face up during setup. Reduce the cost of all other crew placed on this ship by 1.
column13: Pierce's father, an old salt, would tell stories of the splendor of seafaring and seeing the wonders of the world.  Pierce wanted to see that world.  Unfortunately, Pierce is female.  So she cut her hair and began dressing like a boy, and now she is a member of the U.S. Navy in the South China Seas.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
Load this treasure face down. On any one of your turns, you may reveal Fireworks to give this ship +2 to her cannon rolls that turn. Then remove Fireworks from the game.
