This ship gets –1 to its cargo capacity. If this results in any excess cargo or crew, you must choose and transfer it to the wild island where Rotting Hull was loaded. Rotting Hull cannot be unloaded from this ship, but you may give this ship a repair action to eliminate Rotting Hull instead of repairing a mast.
Jade takes up one cargo space, and you may choose not to unload it. Whenever this ship docks at your home island, double the gold value of the treasure with the lowest gold value on this ship.
When revealed, eliminate one random treasure from the island and one random crew from every ship docked at the island. Then remove Volcano from the game.
When revealed, remove all face-up unique treasure from the game. If such a unique treasure changed the value of a treasure coin, that coin regains its printed value.
When you place Bad Maps face up on this ship, as a free action the opponent to your left moves this ship and the island Bad Maps was on 2L in any direction.

This ship gets –1 to the result of every die roll you make for her. At the beginning of each of your turns, roll a d6. On a result of 6, the player to your right places Albatross on another of your ships. Albatross cannot be unloaded unless the ship it is on sinks.

Load this treasure face down. When revealed, trade one random treasure from your home island with a random treasure from an enemy home island. Both home islands must have treasure in order for Trade Route to be used. Then remove Trade Route from the game.

Load this treasure face down. Reveal it when unloaded at your home island: You may choose to eliminate crew from this ship. For each crew you eliminate, you gain 1 gold. Then remove Pension from the game.
When revealed, each player must choose and put a unique treasure from outside the game aboard this ship.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
This ship may repair at sea or at any island.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a chainshot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the chainshot before rolling the d6. If the chainshot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target cannot move on its next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, you may declare that one of her cannons is shooting a smokepot instead of a cannon; you do not need to target a ship. Simply place the center of a fog bank within S of this ship; it may not touch an island or any ship docked at an island. Remove the fog bank at the beginning of your next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a stinkpot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the stinkpot before rolling the d6. If the stinkpot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target's crew cannot use their abilities on the target's next turn.
Fear.
column13: As soon as the golden treasure chest touched the deck of the Monkey's Paw, each crew knew immediately that he alone must possess it.  The slaughter left the ship free to sail wherever she wants-to find more sacrifices to the gods of greed.

column12: Fear.
column13: Captain Wegner laughed at the crew when they refused to destroy the small Haitian village dedicated to the voodoo loa.  After he set the first building ablaze, the fire spread to consume him and his crew.  Yet the crew didn't perish: They still live, sailing and hoping for death.

column12: Ghost Ship. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn. If this crew would be eliminated, place it on your home island instead.
column13: El Fantasma has not been seen for years, and his ships have been found destroyed. Yet some sailors say he now captains a ship made from the bones of his victims. They dare only to whisper his name for fear he may hear them and recruit them for his unholy alliance. El Fantasma lives.

column12: This ship gains the Fear keyword, except that it also affects your ships.
This ship's cannons may not be eliminated (masts still may be). If derelict, she cannot shoot.
column13: HMS Superior is where the Royal Navy sends its best trained cannoneers while their regular ships are being refitted.

column12: Two hits from the same shoot action are required to eliminate one of this ship's masts.
column13: Captain Santana uses the polished bronze bands that wrap the ship's hull to reflect the sun into his opponents' eyes.

column12: You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: Le Couer de Lion has her cannons uniquely positioned on deck to achieve higher and longer shot trajectories.

column12: Two hits from the same shoot action are required to eliminate one of this ship's masts.
column13: Rumors say that the hull of this ship is lined with the hardest of precious gems, explaining why she never seems to take damage.

column12: If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: Having lost their captain to scurvy two years ago, the crew of USS Adventurous have struggled to maintain discipline.

column12: This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: This ship, now crewed by pirates, was captured by a temperamental Spanish noblewoman who had fled from her family.

column12: Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.
column13: This captured galley has been put to use helping the English navigate the treacherous waters of the Barbary Coast.

column12: Galley. Spanish ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: During a battle with El Afortunado, which left both ships taking water, HMS Patagonia unknowingly killed a member of the Spanish royal court.

column12: Galley. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: The Spanish found this ship beached near Barcelona.  She was empty except for a gold cross-a sign of good luck!

column12: Galley. English ships get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship.
column13: El Afortunado attacked a galley that flew no flag, assuming she must have been a Corsair vessel.  To their chagrin, they nearly sank an English vessel gathering valuable information on the Corsairs.

column12: Galley. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: The crew of this tiny galley have learned to use Barbary Corsair tactics to take on the English.

column12: Galley. This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
column13: Capitain Piers won't consider looking for a treasure unless he has at least three sources to confirm it's authenticity.

column12: Turtle Ship. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: The oarsmen of the Floating Stone row so quietly that they can come up alongside a ship without alerting the watch.

column12: Turtle Ship. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The crew of the Sea Snake are called the "Red Ants" for their ability to swarm a ship when boarding.

column12: Turtle Ship. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non–Jade Rebellion ship.
column13: Spurred by a hatred of imperialists, the crew of the Dragon's Talon take on anyone not flying a Jade Rebellion flag.

column12: Turtle Ship. Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: It was a very happy day when Captain Quon discovered that some in the West hated the imperialists as much as he did.

column12: Turtle Ship. On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew and one mast from the rammed ship.
column13: Captain Prior traded a hull of gold for the Beast's Belly, which he uses as a battering ram to double his profits.

column12: Turtle Ship. If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: The Inferno sits near Hong Kong harbor, preying on already damaged ships as they limp into port.

column12: Junk. Treasure Ship.
column13: The Baochuan is both a fortress and palace for Admiral Zheng He. The admiral wishes for everyone who beholds it to take away only one impression: The emperor of China is powerful beyond comprehension.

column12: Emperor's Commander.

Once per turn, if this ship is within S of an island, you may mark the island as explored without docking at it. The island becomes unexplored in regards to all other players. This ship ignores terrain when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain).
column13: Captain Sweigart and his crew have measured and triangulated every island and natural terrain feature in the South China Seas. After all, you never know when you'll need to make an escape.

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: For over 300 years, every sailor who had seen the Flying Dutchman has died before the next day's nightfall. Their souls become trapped on the cursed ship, and their tormented screams forever ride the winds.

column12: Sea Monster. This sea monster gets +1 to its boarding rolls. If it succeeds at a boarding party, it also eliminates a mast.
column13: Rising from a dark temple in the ruins of Atlantis itself, Gog-Clocthoth considers itself a forgotten god, its duty to remind the ignorant of its existence.

column12: Sea Monster. If this sea monster succeeds at a boarding party, you may choose two crew, two treasure, or one crew and one treasure, instead of only one crew or treasure.
column13: Calypsos was summoned by a voodoo priest who was overwhelmed by its power. Now the kraken swims the Spanish Main, attacking ships with an unfettered rage.

column12: Sea Monster. If this sea monster succeeds at a boarding party, it also eliminates a mast.
column13: Calim developed a taste for human flesh by feasting on shipwreck victims. It has lately become more brazen in its attacks, sweeping ship decks of sailors to feed its insatiable hunger.

column12: Sea Monster. Fear.
column13: This ancient creature predates the human race itself, and has spent countless eons nursing its hate and malice.

column12: Sea Monster. You may give this sea monster a shoot action to make one L-range Rank 3 breath attack against a target ship (it may make no other attacks). If it hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target and its crew cannot use their abilities on the target's next turn.
column13: The rotting things embedded in this ancient creature's scales and teeth emit a smell so foul that this behemoth has rendered entire ships helpless simply by swimming near them.

column12: Sea Monster. You may give this sea monster a shoot action to make one one L-range Rank 3-rank breath attack against a target ship (it may make no other attacks). If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast, per the Firepot Specialist rules.
column13: No one knows if this creature is the god referenced in Babylonian myth, but few can dispute its awesome destructive power and pure hatred of all landwalkers.

column12: Sea Monster. If this sea monster succeeds at a boarding party, it also eliminates one mast.
column13: A monstrous sea snake whose existence dates back to the days of Viking raiders, Jormungandr uses its colossal body to splinter ships.

column12: Sea Monster. Give this sea monster a move action but do not move it. Instead, roll a d6. On a result of 5 or 6, move an enemy ship L in any direction.
column13: The wicked serpent Tsuro was summoned by the Jade Rebellion to aid them in their fight against the imperialists, whom it still relentlessly pursues wherever there is water.

column12: Fear. If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: El Fantasma's new acquisition is composed of the bones of his victims. Each time a wave breaks over her bow, a thousand trapped souls scream in anguish.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Cursed ship.
column13: Captain Stark struck a deal with the Devil: If he sends Lucifer a million innocent souls, then he and his entire crew will be forgiven. Captain Stark lives every day trying to keep up his end of the bargain.

column12: Schooner. If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: “Black Sam” Bellamy stole the slave ship Whydah, and led her “cargo” on a pirating rampage before the ship sank in a storm off North Carolina. Stories tell of the Whydah still sailing and hunting the seas on stormy nights.

column12: Schooner. This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks.
column13: Many a greedy sailor has signed to work the Dark Pact on promises of gold and gems, only to discover that in doing so they give up their souls to powers darker than they can imagine.

column12: After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Legends say that this ship sailed in search of a fabulous treasure and returned with nary a soul aboard—except for a crew made up entirely of monkeys!

column12: Fear. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Captain Lee keeps 13 black cats, a half-dozen broken mirrors, and a complement of women aboard. Other ships consider Spilled Salt so unlucky that they avoid her at all costs.

column12: Ghost Ship. This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her masts.
column13: The Banshee's Wail appears to sailors who have tasted the flesh of other humans. These desperate souls find they cannot harm the Banshee's Wail, her horrible scream the last thing they hear before going mad.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Captain Aleida Newport struck a deal with a figure she met at a crossroads at midnight. Ever since, her ship has been incredibly lucky, but only she knows that her luck will soon run out.

column12: If this ship ends her turn in a fog bank, on her next turn she may use her move action to move out of any other fog bank in play.
column13: It is whispered that the Hangman's Joke not only follows the fog, but also has become part of the unnatural mists it inhabits, attacking any foolish enough to enter.

column12: Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Captained by the voodoo priestess Zanna and crewed by runaway slaves from many countries, the Loa's Justice has sunk to evil ends to destroy those who commit far greater crimes.

column12: Fear. Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: Captain Schwartz discovered an ancient book containing the secrets of alchemy. It is rumored that the dark rituals required to work his magic are slowly turning him into a demon.

column12: Eliminate one of this ship's masts when she rolls a 1 on any cannon roll.
column13: Captain Robinson raises a crystal goblet to each foe he personally executes. His crew say that at the stroke of midnight, the goblet glows green and the souls of Robinson's victims can be heard crying for revenge.

column12: This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: On its maiden voyage, the crew of the Fallen Angel discovered an ancient cult dedicated to worshipping Gog-Clocthoth. The crew joined the cult, and ever since the ancient sea god seems to protect them from enemies.

column12: Fear. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Cursed ship.
column13: Missing for over 10 years, El Fantasma was declared dead. He does not dispute this; instead, he claims to have made a deal with the demons of the sea, whom he plans to pay back in mortal souls.

column12: If an enemy ship is within S of this ship, you can use this ship's action for the turn to try to possess a target crew on that ship. Roll a d6; on a result of 6, the target is immediately assigned to this ship. Its nationality changes to match the nationality of this ship.
column13: Papa Doc discovered that he can possess both the dead and living, and he has set his gaze upon the purity that is Josephine Godiva. For if he makes her his one hundredth soul, he will have the power to take on the loa themselves.

column12: Limit. At the beginning of each of your turns, choose any ability possessed by any ship or crew in play; this character has that ability. You may make a different choice each turn.
column13: The oceans are the dominion of the sea-devil Davy Jones. From them he summons and commands the most foul and evil of sea creatures. He can harness the powers of storms and disasters, and he rejoices in turning the sea red with blood. But most of all he craves the souls of all who sail “his” kingdom.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: While he was alive, Sammy Skulow was considered one of the most brutal and insane captains. It is only fitting, then, that his hatred for everyone damned him to living even after his flesh rotted away.

column12: If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: Devereaux found his great obsession, the Eye of the Dragon. Its power was everything he hoped it was—and more: Its power condemned him to a living death under its control.

column12: Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Tabitha McWarren was run out of Providence. Two months later she arrived in New Orleans with a crew devoted to her life. To join her crew, a sailor must drink a mug of her home brew.

column12: Fear.
column13: Ninety-nine people have questioned Papa Doc's power, and 99 souls have been captured for their insolence. Once you become one of the Unblinking, Papa Doc controls you for eternity, your only mission to follow his orders and spread fear and horror to those who oppose him.

column12: If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: The White Crew relish the opportunity to rip flesh from bone no matter where it is found, so infused are they with Sammy the Skull's hatred and venom.

column12: If a sea monster begins its move within L of this ship, it gets +L to its base move.
column13: Tossed overboard and left for dead, Stephen Kalhoun discovered a dark sea creature that kept him alive as the Sargasso Nightmare. All it asks of him is more blood.

column12: If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she wants, up to her available cargo space.
column13: Half-man, half-sea creature, these abominations are trained to leave the fleshy crew of their victims to the sea monsters. They are charged with gathering all of the victims' precious booty.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Captain Jack Hawkins used trickery and deception to steal his beloved Harbinger back from Blackheart. Now he must watch his back, as Blackheart will use the most unholy means to get her back.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Pirate ship.
column13: Hailing from the Barbary Coast, Captain Salazar has brought with him the secret of Greek fire, which he directs in an almost otherworldly rage at any who would enslave him.

column12: After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Captain Bonny Peel gathered the most experienced of Calico Cat's former crew and elevated them again to the ranks of the feared and respected.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The Sea Fox seems magically to appear near unsuspecting opponents, more because of Captain Smith's dark practices than the crew's skill.

column12: You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: The Selkie's Irish crew claim to understand the sea in ways no other sailors do. Whatever grants them this power, their ability to sink ships is feared by all captains.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: Captain Chase survived a shipwreck caused by a rampaging whale. Now he is more likely to attack such behemoths than hunt for gold, and he keeps several harpooners on board for just that purpose.

column12: When this ship carries no cargo, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: The Orca's crew works hard to keep her looking like a merchant ship, maintaining her fame as one of the best blockade runners ever to sail.

column12: After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Captain Dufresne has made his reputation smuggling slaves to freedom in the Jamaica's holds. Of course, he also uses his exceptional skill to make a chest or two of gold from other illicit cargo whenever possible.

column12: This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: The Calchas has a reputation for taking strange cargo: Her crew will often ignore gold in favor of exotic animals, plants, and powders from the Spanish Main.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. If this ship wins a boarding party, she may capture the crew with the highest point cost instead of eliminating it. A captured crew becomes cargo worth its point cost in gold when unloaded at your home island.
column13: Mentored by Calico Cat, Bonny Peel saw her opportunity to command when the Cat mysteriously disappeared. Tough on her crew, she's rumored to be kind to those she captures, sometimes even ransoming them back for nothing more than the right to dock at their ports.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: With Hawkins having the riches of a nobleman, many thought he would retire. But he had one last and very personal mission: to destroy the only man to have beaten him—Blackheart.

column12: Black Mark. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Some say that Blackheart has already sold his soul to the demons of the sea. Others say that he fights them like he has fought everyone else: to his death or theirs.

column12: Give this ship a move action but do not move her. Instead, roll a d6. On a result of 5 or 6, move an enemy ship L in any direction.
column13: The deep swamps of Louisiana breed a different sort of man. LeBeaux has learned from the mambos, magic men, and shamans that those who harness the power of the loa for evil means are an affront to life itself.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Pirate ship. Once per turn, you may eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action.
column13: New to the Crimson Coast, this Nordic pirate made his name staking daring raids along the coasts of England, France, and the United States.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-American ship or fort.
column13: Assigned to the Spanish Main to assess the reports of strange creatures and madmen, CPO Richard has his crew trained to expect anything and everything. Of course, he knows the reports are ridiculous, but he will follow his orders to the letter.

column12: If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she wants, up to her available cargo space.
column13: Back with Blackheart, this charming “pet” has become even more feral and greedy. Skyme's violent streak when he's denied gold evokes humor in Blackheart and terror in everyone else.

column12: If a sea monster begins its move within L of this ship, it gets +L to its base move.
column13: His left arm twitches (mauled by a giant squid); he has a limp (left foot eaten by a shark); and he's almost blind (too many days in a whale's gut)…yet ”Jerky” seems to know when any giant sea creature is near.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: The ultimate English warship, HMS Gargantuan bears the scars of a hundred engagements, and each of her sailors has spilled more blood alone than entire crews of other ships.

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: HMS Bretwalda has been charged with hunting down enemies of an otherworldly nature. Such hunts thrill Van Tyne, who relishes attacking such entities.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Captain Argyle and his crew recently returned from an expedition to the South Pacific, where they reportedly discovered an ancient submerged city—and stole the relics they found there.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-English ship.
column13: Despite her name, HMS Guy Fawkes is crewed by the strongest of English nationalists, whose pride can border on madness when in the thick of an engagement.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: The converted whaling ship HMS Seaham was issued mysterious orders before her last voyage: find and destroy any sea creature of unusual size. The crew has not been informed of their true purpose, and still believe they hunt mundane beasts.

column12: Cursed crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Captain Summerisle is so thoroughly at the mercy of Sir Edmund Atkinson and his “magics” that his crew no longer bears any resemblance to the Royal Navy.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against the Cursed.
column13: Before each voyage, the Archbishop of Canterbury himself blesses this ship. Her cannonballs have been seen tearing through the unnatural and dark ships that prowl the seas.

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Captain Charles and his crew are adept at sailing into enemy ports in broad daylight and making off with plunder, often before the flabbergasted authorities realize what has happened.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: HMS Half Moon's hold contains a strange mechanical device that Captain Maximillian claims can drill into an enemy's hold and claim her treasure without firing a shot.

column12: If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: Captain Rivera honed his skills in the South China Seas, and he has taught his crew that revenge is perhaps the highest virtue to which a sailor can aspire.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls against the Cursed. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: It did not surprise anyone that Van Tyne would risk his reputation for vanquishing monsters, demons, and beasts in the New World. What surprised many was how long it took him to find a woman to share the glory. But one glance at Mademoiselle Godiva, and it was a done deal.

column12: If an enemy ship is within S of this ship, you can use this ship's action for the turn to try to possess a target crew on that ship. Roll a d6; on a result of 6, the target is immediately assigned to this ship. Its nationality changes to match the nationality of this ship.
column13: Banished from London when the virgin daughter of a nobleman was killed while under his care, Atkinson spent countless hours contacting the “powers beyond,” which told him to come to the New World to see what power truly means.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may look at any one face-down treasure on any ship or island. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: With Spain on the decline, the power of the New World will not be held by the crown, but by those powerful enough to wrest control of it. Marques Miquel Antonio plans to make sure he is the last one standing.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice. This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks.
column13: Portland's disgust at having to answer to Van Tyne and hear rumors of monsters and other nonsense has him working his crew extra hard, preparing them to fight for the crown—not some fool's errands.

column12: Black Mark. Give this ship a move action but do not move her. Instead, roll a d6. On a result of 5 or 6, move an enemy ship L in any direction.
column13: Jean Desailly's name is not mentioned in polite company. He is scorned by society (both high and low), and his practice of dark magic has seen him banned in nine European countries. Yet he continues to practice his vile experiments, laughing at those who call him mad.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her masts.
column13: This enormous vessel has recently taken on a new passenger: the man known only as The Inquisitor. He now leads the Spanish fleet in its battle against evils both real and imagined.

column12: As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Capitan Guillen's vicious raiders have become a matter of national pride for Spain, as its power declines and victories become harder to achieve.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against the Cursed.
column13: The cherubic figurehead on the front of El Rafael masks this vessel's true purpose: a place of punishment for Spanish prisoners of war. It is often the last thing insolent prisoners see before being keelhauled.

column12: Fear.
column13: When engaging a foreign enemy, the crew of this ship will fly the flag of the Inquisition just below that of the crown's, striking fear into the most stalwart of opponents.

column12: This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: The cloaked figures who crew this vessel make no attempt to hide their allegiance to the Inquisition. Many sailors have thrown themselves to the sharks rather than be taken captive by them.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Spanish ship.
column13: Capitan Leclere claims to be a staunch supporter of Spain despite his previous Napoleonic leanings. Nevertheless, his superiors never order him to sail near Corsica for that reason.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, if this ship is within S of an island, you may mark the island as explored without docking at it. The island becomes unexplored in regards to all other players.
column13: Miguel Antonio has turned this ship to one purpose: trail a ship out of dock and then kill her crew for whatever treasure they find.

column12: If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: When the Inquisition began its hunt for supernatural forces on the ocean, this was the first ship they commandeered.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: El Pulpo has survived a number of encounters with creatures far larger than herself.

column12: This ship cannot carry crew.
column13: Only a skeleton crew mans this boat, whose jovial capitan named her with the thought that no one notices a mouse until after it has stolen the cheese.

column11: La Catedral del Mar, El Cristal del Obispo, El Martillo de Dios, El Rafael, and Santos Romanos
column12: Black Mark. If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: To have the Inquisitor notice you is to give up hope of a normal life. With one glance you are faced with the punishment of god or banishment to the devil. To hear his whispering voice is to hear the scratchings of 1,000 years of pain.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: With a fleet of cargo ships full of gold and reputation of courage, bravery, and sheer machismo, Guillen has become a Spanish hero, a hero that this once-mighty power desperately needs.

column12: Black Mark. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: A deal with Papa Doc has allowed Jacques to glimpse his future as a powerbroker who can control the weak of mind and spirit. All he has to do is deliver Lady Godiva—innocence and purity intact—to the voodoo king.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
column13: In a race to control the Pacific, the French have pinned their hopes on the Gaule; a ship that lost crew to the English in the Barbary Coast and the Americans in the Atlantic and has no intention of losing anything ever again.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: Amiral Saliceti assisted Emperor Napoleon in his rise to power, and has outfitted his ship with a variety of odd weapons, including a guillotine.

column12: Two hits from the same shoot action are required to eliminate one of this ship's masts.
column13: Once the pride of the emperor's naval power, La Corse was nearly sunk at Trafalgar but has since been rebuilt hardier and stronger than before.

column12: Schooner. This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: Capitaine de Guille is a veteran of a hundred battles, including many waged on the Barbary Coast. He picked up the Corsairs' knack for drafting low to avoid close-range shots.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: L'Eroica maintains a cabin for the beautiful Mademoiselle Godiva, who has eluded many capture attempts. She continues to sail as if on the notes of the Beethoven's symphony the ship was named for.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: The sailors on this vessel have reinforced her hull with as much wood as they could find, determined to stave off those who would harm her.

column12: This ship's cannons may not be eliminated (masts still may be). If derelict, she cannot shoot.
column13: Rumors abound that La Versailles was a place of refuge for nobility during the Revolution; even if that is true, the sailors manning her are now men of the sea, tried and true.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against the Cursed.
column13: La Richelieu sails on the will of the crazed Jean Desailly. Sailors claim they have been to port only once in the last five years—no one is sure just how they stay alive.

column12: Schooner. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Napoleon himself commissioned this ship and named her after one of his sworn enemies, as a warning against those who would defy his imperial authority.

column12: When this ship carries no cargo, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: Capitaine Chott, a former enemy of the emperor, proved his loyalty to Napoleon by capturing this vessel from rebels in Santo Domingo.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
column13: Capitaine Augereau recently returned from Haiti, where he spent quite a bit of time with the slaves. Some say he learned unnatural secrets that he uses to further the cause of the empire.

column12: Limit. Ransom. Choose one French crew during setup; this crew is linked to that crew. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: With innocence and pure trust, Mademoiselle Godiva boarded L'Eroica because her betrothed had requested her presence in the New World. The attacks she has endured from both ships and monsters have her and the crew both puzzled and cautious.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-American ship or fort.
column13: Admiral Crabtree's family hails from the original Plymouth settlers. His brushes with horror at sea, however, have turned him to the bottle, and instilled in him a burning hatred for non-Americans.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: Captain Ahab's, obsession with giant sea creatures led to a chance encounter with “Jerky,” who can not only find such monstrosities, but also may be able to control them.

column12: Schooner. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Under the command of CPO Charles Richard, the Paul Revere has circumnavigated the globe more than 10 times, and her crew is among the most seasoned in the American navy.

column12: Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The Mohican and her captain, a grizzled man named Simpson, represent a secret American intelligence experiment: recruiting sailors from other nations in the hope of turning them into spies for America.

column12: Fear.
column13: The Dark Fox made a name for herself in the war against Tripoli. She has since been fitted with the latest weapons in order to continue harassing European powers and disrupting piracy.

column12: If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: The Saratoga has been afloat since the last days of the American Revolution, and some say that during battle the spirits of Patriot soldiers aim the Saratoga's cannons true.

column12: Schooner. Broadsides Attack.
column13: Recruited by LeBeaux from the swamps of Florida and back alleys of New Orleans, the Swamp Fox's crew has been granted full military rankings amid rumors that they provide the ship with unnatural protection.

column12: This ship ignores terrain when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain).
column13: Some whisper of the Brandywine's unnatural ability to find her way through any ocean, but Captain Fry insists it is nothing more than the rigid application of natural scientific principles.

column12: Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.
column13: The tiny Hessian is nearly a renegade. In fact, she appears on no official naval records, raising questions about just who authorizes her vicious attacks.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against the Cursed.
column13: Jonas Richmond knows the seduction of evil only too well. The loss of his family to violent predators left him with a single motivation: the destruction of any servant of evil.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.

Load this treasure face down. You may reveal it after this ship is rammed by a sea monster, but before any boarding roll is made. When revealed, move the boarding sea monster to the nearest island. Remove Livestock from the game.
All cannon rolls made by Cursed ships against this ship are reduced by 1.
Once per turn when an enemy ship is given a shoot action to shoot at this ship, its controller chooses one of her cannons within range: That cannon automatically hits.
Once per turn instead of giving this ship an action, you may place a fog bank within L of her.

Once per turn, before this ship takes an action, roll a d6, On a roll of 5 or 6, the opponent to your right may give this ship a move action. If he or she does, this ship may not be given another action that turn.
No enemy ability can affect this ship or her crew.

When revealed, roll two d6. The total is how much gold Sunken Treasure is worth. At the beginning of each of your turns, reduce that value by 1, until Sunken Treasure is either reduced to 0 gold or is unloaded at your home island. Sunken Treasure takes up two cargo spaces.

At the beginning of each of your turns, choose a target crew on this ship. Then choose a Cursed crew in play. The target can use the Cursed crew's ability that turn instead of its own. You may make a different choice each turn.
Instead of giving this ship an action on your turn, you may give a sea monster an action, even if it is not part of your fleet.
Place this treasure on the nearest sea monster: It may now be assigned one crew, per the transfer rules.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gets +S to her base move.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
This ship may repair at sea or at any island.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a chainshot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the chainshot before rolling the d6. If the chainshot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target cannot move on her next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, you may declare that one of her cannons is shooting a smokepot instead of a cannon; you do not need to target a ship. Simply place the center of a fog bank within S of this ship; it may not touch an island or any ship docked at an island. Remove the fog bank at the beginning of your next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a stinkpot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the stinkpot before rolling the d6. If the stinkpot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target's crew cannot use their abilities on the target's next turn.
Sea Monster. Limit. At the beginning of each of your turns, choose any ability possessed by any ship or crew in play; this character has that ability. You may make a different choice each turn.
column13: Many sailors believe this monstrosity to be the legendary Behemoth the bible claims will be the a sign of the apolcalypse. Those who have encountered it and lived claim that it wields the power greater than both heaven and hell.

column12: Sea Monster. If this sea monster ends its turn in a fog bank, on her next turn it may use its move action to move out of any other fog bank in play.
column13: Sailors who have seen Mist Walker—and they are rare indeed—claim that the beast doesn't make a sound as it materializes out of the fog. The memory of their companions' screams and torn bodies, though, will forever live in their minds.

column12: Give this ship a move action but do not move her. Instead, roll a d6. On a result of 5 or 6, move an enemy ship L in any direction.
column13: Some say she is nothing more than a mad woman, but others know that she is a spirit forced to spend eternity haunting the sea and seeking revenge on those in uniform - those who let her death go unnoticed.

column12: This ship and any crew aboard her belong to the Cursed nation instead of to their nation.
Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: With her golden sails, the Fool's Gold looks like an imperial ship from the crown's personal fleet. Captain Jeffries uses that ruse to take the gold from the royal fools stupid enough to fall for such an obvious trick.

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Sneaky and deadly, Captain Ness Kruise has no qualms about relieving treasure from those he deems unworthy to possess it.

column12: Fear.
column13: The Boneyard is made of femurs and ribs, held together with the marrow scraped from her victims. Her very presence has driven the most hardened pirates mad with fear.

column12: Ghost Ship.
column13: The Drowned Man and her crew are made up of ships and sailors from wrecks the world over. Together, these entities have become a powerful and dark force intent on seeking revenge for their untimely demises!

column12: If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she wants, up to her available cargo space.
column13: The crew of the Black Diamond care about only one thing: gold. Specifically, taking your gold and adding it their holdings, which are hidden from the prying eyes of Davy Jones.

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: The captain of the Broken Key is rumored to have a part of the key to a secret vault of treasure hidden by Davy Jones himself. He has outfitted his boat to dissuade anyone from searching for his piece of the puzzle.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-English ship.
column13: Captain Hungerford keeps his crew focused on one task: destroying any who would challenge England's dominion over the sea.

column12: Ghost Ship.
column13: The Nightmare appears on moonless nights where any ship has sunk. She picks up those wretched souls who seek vengeance on the living.

column12: If this ship ends her turn in a fog bank, on her next turn she may use her move action to move out of any other fog bank in play.
column13: From the mists that gather at nightfall, the Howl appears with the scream of a thousand tormented souls.

column12: This ship gets +L to her base move if she has all of her masts.
column13: El Pluton seems to have emerged from the underworld itself. No one is sure how she is able to float, unless allowed to by the gods themselves.

column12: Fear. Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: No sane crew would ever sail on a ship named for the Devil, and yet she does sail, especially on moonless nights when no wind blows.

column12: Ghost Ship.
column13: No ship has ever been recorded as the Moor Hound, yet sailors swear the English ship has fired upon them.

column12: Cursed crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Rumored to be crewed by dead French corsairs, the “Bloody Sword” has been seen everywhere from the South China Seas to the Spanish Main.

column12: Cursed crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The Salem was sunk by a wave almost immediately after leaving Boston. Yet it docked in New Orleans with Tabitha McWarren.

column12: Ghost Ship.
column13: No Spanish sailor wants to die with unfinished business, so fearful are they of an undead assignment aboard La Desesperanza.

column12: If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: This ship's name comes from the swaying of hanged sailors, who still move this ship along her dark course.

column12: Cursed crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: This ship was banned from port because of rumor of plague. The screams of her dying crew can be heard for miles.

column12: Fear. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: La Dischorde's crew can be heard laughing at the sea madness, curses, and mutiny that occur aboard other ships wherever she sails.

column12: Ghost Ship.
column13: Once used to carry explosives and crewed by “expendable assets,” this vessel is rumored never to have returned from her last attack mission.

column12: Cursed crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The crew of the Judas is made up of those sailors who no one else wants, the scum of the scum.

column12: Turtle Ship. Fear.
column13: Rumors that Captain Drako chains up his rowers so that they can't escape during a raid have yet to be proven.

column12: Turtle Ship. If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she wants, up to her available cargo space.
column13: With a sense of humor typical of seamongers, the crew considers their raids both good (for them) and bad (for their victims).

column12: Turtle Ship. If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: No one has seen the inside of the Crypt and lived.

column12: Turtle Ship. Fear.
column13: Only the dead and those who think they can control them sail on the Sarcophagus.

column12: Turtle Ship. If this ship ends her turn in a fog bank, on her next turn she may use her move action to move out of any other fog bank in play.
column13: Made from the bones of a giant alligator, this vessel mutely menaces the shoreline like its reptilian namesake.

column12: Turtle Ship. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: When this ship rams and boards, it is said that sailors swarm out of her like a nest of spiders.

column12: Ghost Ship. Junk. Treasure Ship.
column13: When one of the emperor's treasure ships went off course in a storm, she was presumed to have sunk, her crew and treasure lost at the bottom of the sea. A year and a day later, the ship was seen and hailed, but when Jade Rebellion crew sailed close to her, they quickly noticed her new ghostly form. From then on the ship became known as the Guichuan - ghost ship. This ship of purest evil, commanded by the notorious Headhunter and crewed by mysterious phantoms, now claims allegiance to the Cursed and the sea fiends that animate her.

column12: Fear. Headhunter's Domain.      (Headhunter's Domain: This crew may use its abilities aboard only the Guichuan. Once at the beginning of each of your turns roll a d6. On a result of 6, any ship or sea monster in your fleet may be given two actions that turn. If this ship wins a boarding party, she may either take as much treasure from the other ship as she wants, up to her available cargo space, or eliminate all of the other ship's crew.)
Mercenary. Submarine. Two hits from the same shoot action are required to eliminate one of this ship's hull pieces.
column13: The Nautilus is Captain Nemo's flagship and his greatest creation, a ship so powerful and terrible that she is often mistaken for a creature from the deep.

column12: Fear. Mercenary. Submarine.
column13: A strange fog seems to follow the Terror, spirit-like wisps swirling about her decks whenever she surfaces.

column12: Mercenary. Submarine. This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her hull pieces.
column13: Though slowed considerably by the weight of her thick, iron hull, the Hephaestus once survived a direct shot from a 30-pound cannonball.

column12: Mercenary. Submarine. If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: A favorite tactic of the Fathom is to surface in the middle of a battle to sink a weakened ship, and then gather plunder from the ocean floor.

column12: Mercenary. Submarine. If submerged, this ship can ram another ship (then move away) and then initiate a boarding party against that ship.
column13: The Barracuda was originally built by Nemo as a gift for his friend Robur, years before the infamous “Conqueror” took to the air.

column12: Mercenary. Submarine. Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.
column13: Nemo named the Mobilis with part of his motto—mobilis in mobile or “moving in a moving thing”—before giving it to O'Brien.

column12: Mercenary. Submarine. When submerged , this ship gets +L to her base move.
column13: With plans from Nemo, Angria has created one of the fastest submersibles ever seen. Rumor has it that the Devil Ray can journey from Bombay to Fiji without surfacing.

column12: Mercenary. Submarine. Once per turn, if this ship carries treasure and is within S of an enemy ship, you may randomly trade one treasure with that ship.
column13: The Brave Selkirk was named by Nemo's shipbuilders in honor of the ancient sailor who called the Mysterious Islands home, long before even Nemo did.

column12: Mercenary. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any ship.
column13: Led by Fiore, the crew of the Forward mutinied while sailing in the Arctic. Since then, the criminal crew has haunted the waters around the Mysterious Islands.

column12: Mercenary. Schooner. Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Arriving in the warm waters of the South Pacific, the crew of this one-time Spanish trading ship have vowed never to return to the European port they once called home.

column12: Mercenary. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: The crew of the Meropis claim to be from one of the Mysterious Islands of the same name—one never seen by outsiders.

column12: Mercenary. After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Judging by the name of his ship, the one-legged captain of the Hare's Luck is not without a sense of humor.

column12: Mercenary. Schooner. Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: Once an American vessel, the Matuku was renamed by the natives of the Islands who captured and now crew the ship.

column12: Mercenary. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Sailors' tales say that the Duncan is crewed by traitors and cannibals more likely to eat their captives than ransom them.

column12: Mercenary. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: Those who don't believe in sea monsters quail when they see the serpent's skull used as a figurehead by the Bashaw Folly.

column12: Mercenary. This ship can't be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: The ragtag crew of rebels and mutineers aboard the Bosun's Bane will turn on each other if they go too long without attacking another ship.

column12: Ex-patriot. Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: Dissatisfied with czarist Russia, Count Leonardo Gustov contacted Nemo with the idea of a partnership, two men creating their own world order by destroying the old. Nemo declined but agreed to offer him his technology. Gustov has used it to wage his personal war on the minions of the “soon-to-be-dead queens and kings of Europe.”

column12: Ex-patriot. This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
column13: With the Prussian courts choosing favorites, Herr Fuchs saw his ingenuity too often declined. After consulting with Nemo, he saw the future: Leave Germany with his team of designers, take to the sea, and never again sell his designs.

column12: Ex-patriot. This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: With her family imprisoned by England and their land given to the Golds, O'Brien vowed revenge on all involved. With Nemo's technology, Irish wealth in the New World, and a crew of dedicated freedom fighters, O'Brien has taken her fight against England to the sea.

column12: Ex-patriot. If this ship wins a boarding party, she may capture the crew with the highest point cost instead of eliminating it. A captive becomes assigned to this ship, takes up no cargo space, and can use its abilities. The captive cannot leave this ship unless the ship sinks.
column13: His past as mysterious as the islands he has claimed to have found, and with riches beyond that of many of the Crowns of Europe, Captain Nemo has given those dissatisfied with the current state of the world a new vision: allegiance to oneself and honor to the sea.

column12: Ex-patriot. Once per turn, this ship may randomly take two treasures from any ship she touches.
column13: With shipping companies spread across the globe, the richest man in Greece felt he had conquered the sea. But when Gustov took him on a trip in his submarine, Chelios' eyes were opened to a world he had no control over. Using Nemo's technology, he has set out to prove that the true masters of the sea sail under it, not above it.

column12: Ex-patriot. This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against American ships.
column13: Watching Canada become a pawn and forgotten territory while the upstart United States thrived, Savard grew increasingly dissatisfied. Starting life as a pirate preying on U.S. ships was a start, but when he was outlawed by Canada, he vowed to fight on his own until he controlled the entire hemisphere.

column12: Broadsides Attack. Ex-patriot. This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
column13: Piracy was a dead end for this Cuban, who saw his countrymen cut down by better technology. So in a daring midnight raid, he took control of a Spanish ship and vowed that slavers the world over would pay. He hopes someday to meet the rumored Nemo and learn some of his secrets.

column12: Ex-patriot. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Petty conflicts in the Mediterranean became as silly as they were deadly, and Ozat knew he could not take another order from a sultan who never left his perfumed baths or pile of pillows. With rumors of uncharted islands, wealth beyond dreams, and technology unheard of in Europe, Ozat set sail for the Mysterious Islands.

column12: Ex-patriot. Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.
column13: Fiore had a knack for getting people to tell him their secrets, for creating kings. Eventually the objects of his manipulations began to bore him, and hearing of Gustov's plan, he took his talents to the sea to help create a new world order.

column12: Ex-patriot. Once per turn, this ship may look at any one face-down treasure on any ship or island. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: The last of the Angria dynasty, Yeshaji watched as the English fleet bombarded his family holdings near Bombay. He knew then that the age of piracy was dead. But when he saw Nemo's Nautilus surface from the depths, he saw a new way to restore his family's pride and power.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
This ship can shoot at submerged ships within S of her.
column13: The new pirate crew of the “Schultzie” are inordinately proud of capturing the German frigate and her cache of modern weaponry.

column12: Submarine. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Mercenary ships.
column13: After stealing the Coleoptera, Captain Mission painted the ship bright gold to taunt Nemo before setting out to waylay ships on the Sea of Krakens.

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: When piracy became difficult on the Mediterranean and Aegean Seas, Captain Zambrowsky led the Thirty Tyrants and her crew through the newly opened Suez Canal toward the Mysterious Islands.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a submarine.
column13: Negotiations aboard the Xiamen's Claws always take place in the captain's quarters, where he keeps his pet—a live tiger.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, if this ship is within S of an island, you may mark the island as explored without docking at it. The island becomes unexplored in regards to all other players.
column13: Villagers in the Mysterious Islands often see the silhouette of the Sunrise Fire as she sails by in the predawn hours, marking each island she passes as potential prey.

column12: If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she wants, up to her available cargo space.
column13: The Nancy Nox is a ship of carousing buccaneers who have vowed to “make merry even in the land of the dead,” and who prefer kegs of rum to chests of gold.

column12: This ship cannot shoot when she carries treasure.
column13: Because the Devil's Pay was built for speed rather than carrying capacity, her crew must take the best plunder rather than the most plunder.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: The Panama Sun is crewed by failed forty-niners who stole the ship and her cargo of gold, then fled to the Mysterious Islands to take up their new trade of piracy.

column12: You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: Crewed by determined Spanish outlaws, El Tejon will never give up a chase until she has captured her target.

column12: After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Under the guidance of American mastermind Adam Worth, the crew of the Shamrock sails unerringly toward the greatest plunder to be found in the Mysterious Islands.

column12: Once per turn, if this ship carries treasure and is within S of an enemy ship, you may randomly trade one treasure with that ship.
column13: Said to be captained by the ghost of a shantytown saloon-keep, the Smiling Jim is crewed by sailors who throw cargo overboard in hopes of appeasing the ship's namesake.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls against Mercenary ships. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Hammersmith's ship, the Glory, was laden with goods when a metal ship-beast surfaced and destroyed her. After washing ashore a mysterious island that rose out of the sea, he put together a new crew, whose only purpose is to bury submarines next to the Glory.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Benito de Soto claims to be the last true pirate: His attacks are quick; his goal is gold; and his crew has perfected the art of capturing ships. Hiding out along the coast of South America, de Soto appears only when his hunger for gold needs to be satisfied.

column12: If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: The “Little Devil” seems to have been spawned from Hades itself. With no regard for human life, he is chaos personified, and any ship that comes across him can only hope that they survive the onslaught.

column12: This ship can shoot at submerged ships within S of her.
column13: Professor Defoe has studied the emergence of the submarine with great interest. He has been paid handsomely by the Crown to bring in one—in any condition.

column12: Limit. Ransom. Place this crew face up during setup. You may build your fleet using 5 more points than the game's build total. This crew cannot leave this ship unless captured or eliminated.
column13: The son of Genny Gallows grew up as a pirate. But for him, piracy is all fun and games, almost like living a dream of gold, glory, girls, and rum. He sails for fun, and crews line up to sail with him.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: The ladies the Gentleman has rescued have spread his name throughout the seas and ports. To have been saved by him is to have been welcomed into an exclusive club, whose true nature is known only by its members.

column12: This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks. Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: With a laugh, this self-proclaimed King of Pirates is based in Madagascar. Mission considers Nemo to be a fool, his ideas the idiocy of  someone with too much money and too little imagination.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: Tasked with ridding the world of threats at sea, Chads' focus is the pirates who seem to attack at will. He has zeroed in on Captain Mission and his ilk, with the aim of making the seas safe for everyone.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a submarine.
column13: Among the nearly 700 sailors who crew HMS Pacificum are 20 who specialize in operating the hardhat diving suits they use to board submersibles.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any ship.
column13: Innumerable pirates have swung from the yardarm of HMS Gallows, a ship expressly constructed by the Crown to pursue pirates to the far ends of the Earth.

column12: Schooner. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Her white sails crisp and polished silver trim gleaming, HMS Zephyr often seems to race over the waves faster than the wind.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: One of Her Majesty's first and finest ironclads, HMS Iron Prince can withstand incredible impacts with minimal damage.

column12: If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: One of the Admiralty's few remaining packet ships, HMS Empress sails between Asia and England carrying only the most important cargo—and well prepared to defend it.

column12: This ship can shoot at submerged ships within S of her.
column13: Christened by Prince Albert, HMS Challenger was named in honor of the brilliant scientist who gave the secret of depth charges to the Imperial Navy.

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: Once a colony ship, HMS Botany Bay spent six months in the dry docks of Hong Kong to be outfitted with two gun decks and more than four dozen cannons.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: HMS Auckland is crewed by rough sailors recruited from the penal colony of Moreton Bay and offered a chance at freedom in return for service.

column12: Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The crew of the hired vessel HMHV Plunder is loyal to the Crown, but only so long as coin from the Crown outweighs what they might win from piracy.

column12: Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: When enemies close on HMS Disraeli, they fear the crack of her marksmen's rifles as much as the boom of her cannons.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: HMS Bletchley has been ordered to map the Mysterious Islands, plant the Union flag, and expand the empire.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-English ship.
column13: When Eileen Brigid O'Brien escaped prison, Hermione Gold took that as a slap to her family's face. With a ship paid for by her family fortune and a crack fighting squad provided by the Crown, she has begun her hunt for O'Brien.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: La Manila is the largest Spanish ship in the western Pacific, and the flagship of many Spanish fleets in Asian waters.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a submarine.
column13: This ship's crew won fame for sinking a submarine by dropping cannonballs over the side to pound the submersible's hull as she passed below.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Spanish nobility journeying to Pacific colonies often use the luxurious officers' quarters aboard El Corazon Dorado.

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: Under Capitan Zuan the crew of La Colera ignore the events of the past, instead blaming all countries for the loss of Spanish pride and power in the New World.

column12: On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew and one mast from the rammed ship.
column13: Since being disastrously boarded, the disgraced capitan of El Villalobos keeps several deck cannons constantly loaded with chainshot for the next time an enemy comes too close.

column12: This ship can shoot at submerged ships within S of her.
column13: Capitan Tito and his “Lightning” have hunted submersible vessels with a vengeance since one sank a Spanish galleon captained by his son.

column12: Schooner. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Either daring or mad, the Mask and his crew are well known for swinging over open water to board and assault enemy vessels before the ships are in contact, with extra gold going to the sailor exhibiting the most creative maneuver.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: An aging schooner that once patrolled the Pacific coast of the Americas, El Extremadura was sent west by the Crown after Mexico won its independence.

column12: One of this ship's treasures is worth +1 gold when she docks at your home island.
column13: Sailors aboard La Saragossa take inspiration from the once-besieged city for which the ship is named. In three decades on the sea, the ship has never been captured.

column12: After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Few believe stories that the San Theodora is crewed by monks searching for a holy artifact brought to the Mysterious Islands by a Spanish outlaw.

column12: This ship ignores terrain when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain).
column13: Capitan Espinosa firmly believes that the Mysterious Islands are all that remain of the Terra Australis described by Aristotle.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Spanish ship.
column13: When his uncles left the employ of Spain to be pirates, the family name was ruined. A child at the time, Luis remembers the anger he felt at his family's treachery. He has vowed to prove that the Zuan family is loyal to the Crown, and he will do anything to erase the past.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
