column13: Who is the Mask? That is the question running through the court of Spain. With victories against Spain's enemies (both real and imagined) and a flair for self promotion, the Mask has won the backing of Spain's Crown and its ladies.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Mercenary ships.
column13: After he was captured by mercenaries during a raid led by Count Gustov on his coastal African home, he escaped to Paris to become an expert on mercenary ships and tactics.

column12: Once per turn, if this ship is within S of an island, you may mark the island as explored without docking at it. The island becomes unexplored in regards to all other players.
column13: Italian by birth, but backed by the Spanish Crown, Malaspina mapped the Pacific from the coast of the Americans to the Philippines. His knowledge of Spanish holdings and his grand plan for global unity are visionary.

column12: This ship can shoot at submerged ships within S of her.
column13: A scholar and expert on sea life, Aronnax's goal is to discover what makes mercenaries tick, so that he can better answer questions of the sea and of man.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any ship.
column13: Even the battle-hardened crew of L'Aube can't help but smile at the antics of the trained monkeys brought on board by their capitaine.

column12: Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Featuring sailors from around the world, the crew of La Martinette are bound together by the rigid military discipline of their officers.

column12: Schooner. This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks.
column13: Named for the sword of the legendary Charlemagne, the “Flame Cutter” has a skilled and dedicated crew composed of the best French sailors.

column12: If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she wants, up to her available cargo space.
column13: Many of the sailors aboard Le Descharges came fresh from the academy at Brest, ill prepared for the bloody battles they've seen in the Islands.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: Though Le Vercingetorix is named for an ancient Gaulish chieftain, her steel-riveted hull marks her as one of the newer ships in the French fleet.

column12: This ship can shoot at submerged ships within S of her.
column13: Capitaine Nash has nerves of steel, and what sometimes seems like a death wish, as he insists his vessel carry only the most dangerous cargo in the Mysterious Islands.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a submarine.
column13: Preferring boarding to being boarded, the crew of L'Espadon brag that no enemy has ever set foot on her decks.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, this ship may move S after loading treasure.
column13: Construction of Le Petit Dauphin was funded by a wealthy French nobleman who secretly joined her crew as a deckhand to sail the seas in search of adventure.

column12: This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: French sailors ordered to serve aboard the “Coward of Calvados” throw themselves into battle with ferocious courage to prove that the ship was not named for them.

column12: If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: Since coming to the Mysterious Islands, the masts and planks of L'Emeraude have begun to sprout shoots and leaves as if they were still alive, leaving the ship's crew curious and slightly disturbed.

column12: Friendly ships within S of this ship get +1 to their cannon rolls.
column13: Carrying messages and supplies among the French fleet in the Islands, the “Silver Crest” boasts striped sails that are always a welcome sight to French sailors.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster or submarine.
column13: Hailing from Canada, Ned Lands' reputation as a harpooner was solidified when he became the only man ever to have speared a kraken and lived to tell about it. His search for the mysterious sea serpent and the even more mysterious “submarines” has kept him out at sea.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Under the command of Willeford, USS Stephens is an agile and dangerous vessel that has sailed circles around smaller and faster ships.

column12: Submarine. If submerged, this ship can ram another ship (then move away) and then initiate a boarding party against that ship.
column13: This submersible was called the Narwhal before an American crew captured her from Nemo and renamed her for the friend and confidant of President Lincoln, who led them and perished in battle.

column12: This ship can shoot at submerged ships within S of her.
column13: The crew of USS Eagan works closely with the brilliant engineers at the Gosport Navy Yard, who successfully duplicated the depth charges invented by the English.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: Since coming to the Mysterious Islands, the good men who crew the Grampus have been haunted by nightmares of mutiny and a dark end.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a submarine.
column13: A silver stallion on her masthead, USS Paladin sailed out of San Francisco riding the wind that called her to the most savage parts of the Mysterious Islands.

column12: Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: When not taking part in endless target practice, the crew of USS Quigley work endless hours to keep her hull a bright red and her trim a brilliant blue.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: USS Bartlett was part of a fleet that successfully blockaded Confederate ports and then was sent to explore the South Pacific after the Civil War.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: USS Bellevue crossed the Arctic waters of the Pacific to explore the northern reaches of the Orient before coming south to the Mysterious Islands.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any ship.
column13: The captain of the “Seven Seas” is a scholar trained in the classics who approaches each battle as if he were writing it up for a history of maritime warfare.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
column13: Her crew hastily assembled in California before setting out for the Islands, the Tombstone is crewed by outlaws who have spent more time on horseback than on the deck of a ship.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: When an American appeared in San Francisco Bay standing on the deck of a captured “submarine,” a hero was born. May now “owns” the western coast of the United States, and with a submarine at his disposal, Manifest Destiny may take root in the Pacific.

column12: This ship can shoot at submerged ships within S of her.
column13: A native of one of the Mysterious Islands, Shinji was traded like a possession from Nemo to Gustov to Chelios before he escaped to Hawaii, where Mays found him.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: This huge Alaskan native is rumored to be blessed by the gods of the sea. Legend has it that his aim is so perfect that he once killed a whale using only a single spear.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
When this ship rolls for effect at a mysterious island, subtract 1 from the die roll result.
When this ship rolls for effect at a mysterious island, add 2 to the die roll result.
This ship gains the Mercenary keyword.
The rank of each of this ship's cannons is increased by 1. Remove Luddite's Revenge from the game when this ship succeeds at a shoot action.
This ship's base move becomes S and enemy ships must roll a 6 to hit her. If this ship is hit, remove Metal Hull from the game.
Load this treasure face down. Reveal it when target enemy ship moves within S of this ship. Choose and eliminate one mast from the target at the end of her move. Remove Mines from the game.
The range of each of this ship's cannons becomes 2 L. Remove Power Cannons from the game when this ship succeeds at a shoot action.
Load this treasure face down. Reveal it when this ship is given a move or shoot action; any one target enemy ship cannot use any crew or ship abilities this turn. Remove Periscope from the game.
Load this treasure face down. When this ship is given a move action, you may reveal Screw Engine; this ship can move twice. Remove Screw Engine from the game.

Load this treasure face down. When this ship is given a shoot action, you may reveal Targeting Scope; one of this ship's cannons automatically hits an enemy ship within range. Remove Targeting Scope from the game.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
This ship gains one rank 3 with S range cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
This ship gets +S to her base move.
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
If derelict, this ship gains a base move of S. This crew takes up no cargo space.
This ship may repair at sea or at any island.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a chainshot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the chainshot before rolling the d6. If the chainshot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target cannot move on her next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, you may declare that one of her cannons is shooting a smokepot instead of a cannon; you do not need to target a ship. Simply place the center of a fog bank within S of this ship; it may not touch an island or any ship docked at an island. Remove the fog bank at the beginning of your next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a stinkpot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the stinkpot before rolling the d6. If the stinkpot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target's crew cannot use their abilities on the target's next turn.
Sea Monster. This sea monster can attack submerged submarines.
column13: Cadara is a Kraken so large that when it sits near the surface it has been mistaken for an island.

column12: Sea Monster. This sea monster can attack submerged submarines.
column13: Shaihulud is a large and ancient creature widely believed to have come from another world.

column12: Ex-patriot. This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
column13: When she was born the high priest in her village had a dream -  that Teresa Pavon would be the Queen that brought back the Mayan Civilization to it's hights. A chance meeting with Nemo led her to beleive that the modern technology was the means to reach glory and power she is destined to wield.

column12: This treasure can't be removed from this ship unless she sinks. Any other unique treasure aboard this ship that would be removed from the game after it is used remains aboard; it can be reused or continues to function.
Mercenary. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any ship.
column13: These prisoners overthrew the original crew and declared themselves independent from all governments - and the fools who are loyal to them.

column12: Mercenary. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you made for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Led by Bennett, a freed pirate captain, the crew of the Revolution instigate raids against all who stand in their path to worldwide anarchy.

column12: Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Captain Hart and his crew of pirates believe in two things: gold will make you happy and rum will make you even happier.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a submarine.
column13: Led by a private man-of-war from Boston, the crew of the Independence have been trained to attack the metal ships that have plagued the eastern seaboard.

column12: Mercenary. This ship can shoot at submerged submarines within S of her.
column13: The Corcoran came to the Mysterious Isles in search of the many monsters in their waters, but are the crew are happy to use their  'sea bombs' on ships as well.

column12: Mercenary. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: The crew of the Munchhausen claim it was once commanded by the Baron of the same name, where he discovered one of the Mysterious Isles was made of cheese.

column12: Mercenary. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Captain Smith credits the speed of his ship to a single member of his crew, a native shaman who claims to be able to control the winds.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a submarine.
column13: The Bragi is crewed by Viking-descended Norsemen who set sail to explore the Mysterious Isles on the far side of the world.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a submarine.
column13: Captain Sherman volunteered for the voyage to the Mysterious Isles in hopes of finding a legendary diamond mine said to be hidden beneath a volcano.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a submarine.
column13: After proving herself against pirates along the African and Brazilian coast, the Mohican was sent to help open the waters of the south Pacific to American ships.

column12: This ship can shoot at submerged ships within S of her.
column13: Shipwrecked in Manila, the French crew of the "Flying Fox" spent two years building the ship and named her for the enormous bats in the area.

column12: This ship can shoot at submerged ships within S of her.
column13: Due to their fascination with black powder and explosions, the captain and many of the crew of the Blackwater are nearly deaf.

column12: This ship can shoot at submerged ships within S of her.
column13: The Güímar's French crew was stunned to find pyramids in the Mysterious Isles similar to those in the town for which their ship was named.

column12: Mercenary. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Once a French galley, the Jongleur was captured by mercenaries when it ran aground on the shores of Van Diemen's Land.

column12: Mercenary. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The masthead of the Hanno is a carving of the ancient explorer and navigator of the same name, guiding the ship through the treacherous waters of the Mysterious Isles.

column12: Mercenary. This ship can't be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: On the Phlegyas, the names of those who fall in battle are carved into its masts, and their spirits are said to protect the ship.

column12: Turtle Ship. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a submarine.
column13: Her Majesty's Nightmare Rumbarrel is crewed by rowdy pirates feared by English sailors and weak-willed innkeepers around the world.

column12: Mercenary. Turtle Ship. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a submarine.
column13: Filled with treasure, the Obsidian Sun was given by the Chinese emperor to Ambassdor Fogg after he rescued the emperor's kidnapped mother from Robur.

column12: Mercenary, Turtle Ship. If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: The Sea Storm prefers to waylay European ships travelling the sea routes between the African coast and Asia.

column12: Mercenary, Turtle Ship. If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she wants, up to her available cargo space.
column13: On the day it set sail, omens said the Seven Brothers would not return to port until its holds had been filled with gold a hundred times.

column12: Mercenary, Turtle Ship. On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew and one mast from the rammed ship.
column13: The Chinese sailors aboard the Divine Dragon claim that when their ship rams another, their golden dragon masthead will come to life and fight for them.

column12: Mercenary, Turtle Ship. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a submarine.
column13: The captain of the Silver Current is called the "Mountain of Wealth" and has brought untold riches to her crew in Chinese ports.

column12: Submarine. This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her hull pieces.
column13: The Mercury is the first American "war submersible" made using plans from the captured ship Lamon by Montana Mays and revised by Admirals from Annapolis.

column12: Submarine. Mercenary. Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The least seen of Nemo's "children" the Slipstream spends more of her time exploring the oceans of the world than with dealing with the man and his follies.

column12: Ex-patriot. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: The only "submersible" captain that openly recruits crew and allows crew to leave when they want. Because of that policy Thane has become an outcast of the other outcasts. Nemo has shunned him and Gustov would like him dead, but Thane has became the friend of sailors looking toward the future.

column12: When placing treasure, you may place one or more of these crew rather than a treasure, on a one-for-one basis; you must still place the required value of gold. These crew may use their abilities on any ship. Follow all other treasure-placement and crew rules.
column14: Note on the 10 treasure card you will find the following: Cannoneer (2), Explorer, Helmsman(2), Musketeer (2), Captain, Shipwright, Oarsman

column12: Submarine. If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: Few know that the stories told of Davy Jones' Locker are true-and more nightmarish than can be imagined. The damned crew of this ship exist only to cause fear and spread death to those who sail above the waves.

column12: Submarine. Ghost Ship.
column13: Davy Jones handpicked the crew of the Pyre.They are all ghost who were victims of torture and imprisonment and who now want only one thing: revenge on those who took their lives.

column12: If an enemy ship is within S of this ship you can use this ship's action for the turn to try to possess a target crew on that ship. Roll a d6, on a result of 6, the target is immediately assigned to this ship. Its nationality changes to match the nationality of this ship.
column13: It was with the most sinister joy that Davy Jones reanimated Edward Low. Low was the worst of the pirates, a murderer, torturer, and vile human being who lived to see others suffer. Low was tasked with gathering the first of the Cursed crew, and he now commands the Locker.

column12: This ship and all crew on her become part of The Cursed faction.

1-2: Randomly move two treasure coins from this island to another wild island.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: When this ship explores this island, randomly move two treasure coins from every other wild island to this island, and then choose which to take.

1-2: Roll 3d6. For every 4-6 result, eliminate one of this ship's masts. 
3-4: No effect.
5-6: Move an opposing ship using this ship's base move.

1-2: The next time you give this ship a move action, the opponent to your left moves her.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: Crew on this ship do not take up cargo space until after this ship docks at her home island.

1-2: Roll 5d6. For every 4-6 result, eliminate one of this ship's masts.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: When this ship explores this island, replace one treasure coin with a unique treasure from your collection.

1-2: The next time you give this ship a move action, roll 1d6. On a result of 1-4, she can't move.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: When this ship explores this island, randomly move two treasure coins from every other wild island to this island, and then choose which to take.

1-2: The next time you give this ship a move action, roll 1d6. On a result of 1-5, she can't move.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: You can add an event from your collection to your fleet.

1-2: Randomly move one treasure from this island to another wild island.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: After exploring this island, place a treasure coin from your collection with value equal to or less than one you took on the island.

1-2: This ship can't explore this island. She must leave and dock again to try.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: The next time you give this ship a move action, add L to her base move.

1-2: Randomly move two treasure coins from this island to another wild island.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: After this ship explores this island, swap any number of treasure coins taken with an equal number of treasure coins chosen randomly from other wild islands.

1-2: The next time you give this ship a move action, roll 1d6. On a result of 1-5, she can't move.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: When this ship explores this island, replace one treasure coin with one of greater value from your collection.

1-2: The opponent to your left moves all this ship's crew to any other wild island.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: When this ship explores this island, randomly move one treasure coin from every other wild island to this island, and then choose which to take.

1-2: Move all treasure coins from this island to any other wild island.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: When this ship explores this island, replace one treasure coin with a unique treasure from your collection.

1-2: Roll 4d6. For every 4-6 result, eliminate one of this ship's masts.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: Move an opposing ship using her base move.

1-2: Roll 5d6. For every 4-6 result, eliminate one of this ship's masts.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: You can add an event from your collection to your fleet.

1-2: The next time you give this ship a move action, she can move only S.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: Randomly move one treasure coin from this island to your home island.

1-2: The next time you give this ship a move action, the opponent to your left moves her.
3-4: No effect.
5-6: After this ship explores this island, swap any number of treasure coins taken with an equal number of treasure coins chosen randomly from other wild islands.

column13: Our course has brought us to these uncharted isles...
As we explore each island, dread begins to consume the crew...
Natives whisper tales of monsters both flesh and metal in the water...

Our Captain's search for gold and glory has brought us to our end.
We are doomed!

column12: Icebreaker. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: This modern and magnificent vessel, under the command Sigurd Andersen, is the flagship and the pride of the new Viking fleet.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against the Cursed.
column13: The Wiglaf's crew named their vessel for the famed Swedish dragon-slayer, and they draw from his strength as they hunt the Cursed.

column12: Longship. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load up to two treasures. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Eling the Bear has trained his crew to infiltrate enemy ports, and then get out quickly enough to live to pillage another day.

column12: Longship. If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: Johann One-Eye has learned that preying on the wounded is easier than attacking the strong.

column12: Longship. On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew from the enemy ship.
column13: Wulfsmasher has been charged with training future berserkers, so the warriors aboard his ship fight only when provoked.

column12: Longship. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: After having plied the waters of the frigid north for so long, Warlord Lunt's crew are experts in the art of deftly maneuvering through ice.

column12: Longship. If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: Named for the home of the gods themselves, the Asgard was designed from bow to stern to carry plunder and win glory.

column12: Longship. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls against sea monsters.
column13: The Hrothgar's crew have sworn a blood oath to protect Scandinavian shipping from all threats—especially those that lurk beneath the surface.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls against the Cursed. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Sailors aboard the Grendel are regarded as wild and bloodthirsty, and ships will add weeks to their journeys just to avoid them.

column12: Longship. If this ship wins a boarding party, she may capture the crew with the highest point cost instead of eliminating it. A captured crew becomes cargo worth its point cost in gold when unloaded at your home island.
column13: War leader Mimir has trained his crew to look out for enemy dignitaries, having made his name by ransoming captains, dukes, and kings.

column12: Longship. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: The Donar's sails are emblazoned with a giant hammer, which the crew insists protects the ship from harm.

column12: Longship. Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Like their warlord, Skuld Blood-Axe, the crew of the Freya live only for the glory of battle, and will accept any sailor willing fight.

column12: Longship. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load up to two treasures. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Taking their cues from the myths of old, sailors aboard the Fenrir steal other nations' treasures in the hope of provoking Ragnorak.

column12: Longship. When this ship carries no cargo, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: Like the horse for which she is named, the Sleipnir always seems to run faster when unburdened.

column12: Longship. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load up to two treasures. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Often the only evidence left after the Loki visits a port are empty storage rooms and more than a few blushing women.

column12: Longship. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against the Cursed.
column13: Captain Thorfinn lost an eye, a leg, and his family to the Cursed, and has sworn never to rest until every last monster has been destroyed.

column12: Longship. If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: Berserkers aboard the Ragnorak prefer to keep the old ways, using axes instead of rapiers—and leaving no survivors.

column12: Longship. This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: The Hlidskjalf drafts so low that she rides the waves like a piece of driftwood, making her almost impossible to hit at close range.

column12: Longship. Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Captain Soren innovated a vile mix of grapeshot and regular shot, which his crew now uses with deadly accuracy.

column12: Once at the beginning of each of your turns, roll a d6. On a result of 6, any ship in your fleet may be given two actions that turn. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against the Cursed.
column13: As if a scion of the Norse gods themselves, Sigurd Andersen commands legions of sailors by appealing to their common Viking heritage. Some have said he has another mission: ridding the world of the Cursed and their demons and monsters.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Seemingly a valkyrie taken human form, Shayna Duex is one of the faces of the new Viking warrior. She has defied the odds to become one of the most feared captains in the Frozen North, skilled at taking on large fleets of ships and coming away with their gold.

column12: If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, choose two of the following: eliminate a crew, take a treasure, or eliminate a mast.
column13: Petr Skuld was a captain of a small ship before his fateful meeting with Andersen. From then on he became a man possessed with a new mission, calling himself a berserker warlord and pledging his allegiance to the new Vikings.

column12: Marine.
column13: Linstrom watched as a sea serpent destroyed a vessel within sight of his fishing village. He vowed to someday have the beast's heart, so he learned both the harpoon and the bow to assault the unholy creature from range.

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and take as much treasure as she can carry. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Grim was a pirate who sailed with Calico Cat before she disappeared. He decided that it was more fun to attack a port than a ship (after all, ports don't move), so he allied himself with a crew of port-raiding Vikings.

column12: This ship ignores terrain, except icebergs, when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain). Once per turn, if this ship is within S of an island, you may mark the island as explored without docking at it. The island becomes unexplored in regards to all other players.
column13: Convinced that passages exist through the northern ice floes to China and Japan (as well as to the internal lands of North America and Russia), Ethan was named The Farseeker by Andersen and given the right to any ship he needs to prove his theories.

column12: When another face-up crew on this ship would be eliminated, turn it face down instead.
column13: Lars Valgard protects Shayna Duex. No one knows why, including Shayna. He just showed up and claimed that he was sent to protect her. Since that day he has fought by her side and protected her from mutinous crew, Cursed minions, and ships of the line.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: As strong as she is powerful, the Stoneheart has carved a name for herself in the Frozen North by being as ruthless as the ice itself.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Pirate ship. Once per turn, you may eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action.
column13: Captained by a crusty old sailor who calls himself “Old Joe,” the Diamond Strike wages a private war against those who would destroy the freedoms of her crew.

column12: If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: The Jaguar's Spirit is crewed by the descendants of Mayan villagers who fled the Spanish Main hundreds of years ago.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: The crew of the Gruesome have decked out their ship to look like a Cursed vessel in order to distract potential targets while stealing their plunder.

column12: Schooner. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Captain Wordsworth resigned his commission in England's navy for a life of crime, turning his keen planning skills to nefarious ends.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The Poison Dagger is so named because her crew are known to smear a foul substance on their weapons before attacking other ships.

column12: This ship ignores terrain when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain).
column13: Rumor has it that Calico Cat once owned the Devil's Kiss, and that she sailed it to places no ship has been before or since.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Viking ships.
column13: Captain Stone taught his gunners the vulnerable points of longship design.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: The Full Moon is crewed by sailors who have survived encounters with sea monsters—and who have sworn to take revenge for what they have lost.

column12: Longship. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load up to two treasures. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: The Thrud was once an honest merchant ship, until her crew decided that robbing unsuspecting towns was more lucrative.

column12: One of this ship's treasures is worth +2 gold when unloaded at your home island.
column13: The Ahura Mazda once sailed the Barbary Coast, but her crew has adapted to a life of crime in the Frozen North.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice.
column13: Swept up in the Viking fervor spreading in the north, Gunther “Gunner” Borg became a Viking, but his first encounter with Jack Hawkins showed him that piracy is the way to go.

column12: This ship ignores terrain, except icebergs, when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain). Once per turn, if this ship is within S of an island, you may mark the island as explored without docking at it. The island becomes unexplored in regards to all other players.
column13: Vlad claims to have navigated the ice floes of the Frozen North to Asia. Of course, he also claims that he is both a secret heir to the Russian throne and the reincarnation of a Viking god. Needless to say, no one believes anything he says.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
Once per turn, if this ship is touching another ship, she can randomly take as much treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: Admiral Barrett renamed this vessel after England's latest acquisition from Norway to flaunt England's military might.

column12: This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her masts.
column13: HMS Orkney is made of the sturdiest Scottish hardwood and has survived full broadsides with nary a scratch.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-English ship.
column13: Prince Harry once stowed away on HMS Royal for an adventure at sea, where he distinguished himself as a fine sailor in the English tradition.

column12: If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: HMS Hastings has circumnavigated the globe four times, and has seen nearly every corner of the world.

column12: Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Captain Griffin's crack crew of gunners have won battles in which they were vastly outnumbered and outgunned.

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: HMS Duke of York sails the seas between England and Scandinavia, protecting England from the Viking threat.

column12: Icebreaker. On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew and one mast from the enemy ship.
column13: HMS Granville was recommissioned and outfitted as an icebreaker in England's attempt to find the Northwest Passage.

column12: This ship may unload cargo at your home island if she's within S of it.
column13: HMS Yardbird is crewed by former American Confederates who fled to England rather than rejoin the Union.

column12: Once per turn, if this ship is within S of an island, you may mark the island as explored without docking at it. The island becomes unexplored in regards to all other players.
column13: Captain Avalon has trained HMS Kirkwall's young crew to fend for themselves during their long sea voyages.

column12: L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: HMS Tweed is a marvel of naval engineering, so small that she practically disappears into the waves.

column12: Once per turn, if this ship is touching another ship, she can randomly take as much treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: The new breed of English sailor—captain and businessman—Miles sees the oceans of the world as nothing more than trade routes under the control of the world's greatest navy. Thus it seems fitting that all gold should flow into his hoppers.

column12: Once per turn, if this ship is touching another ship, reveal all face-down treasure aboard the other ship. This ship can take as much unique treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: Sir Jeremy is the most respected explorer in the world. His discovery of the Viking settlement is his crowning achievement. What isn't known is that he secretly buys holy relics and artifacts from pirates, rogues, and thieves.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Spanish ship.
column13: Named for the first city founded on the Iberian peninsula, La Tartessos is one of the last symbols of Spanish pride still afloat.

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: Capitan Renaldo is a scholar as well as a sailor in the Spanish Navy, and has studied history as closely as he has studied technology.

column12: After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: The deck of El Rosal is often dusted with rose petals—a symbol of the Virgin Mary's protection.

column12: After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Capitan Cordova recently returned from a tour of the Frozen North, where he claims to have found an artifact buried in ice that allows him to see into the future.

column12: Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.
column13: El Alma's figurehead was ripped from the prow of a Cursed vessel for its ability to paralyze entire ships with fear and awe.

column12: Icebreaker. Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: Although Spain's power has diminished, she has built this ship on the hope of unlocking—and monopolizing—the Northwest Passage.

column12: This ship may not be shot at while docked.
column13: One of the last remaining Spanish training vessels, La Academia is a floating naval academy and proving ground for young capitans.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
column13: Capitan de la Cruz is the grandson of a famous Spanish capitan, and has dedicated his life and ship to recapturing Spain's former glory.

column12: This ship cannot be pinned.
column13: La Cantabrian is listed on official Spanish naval records as a rogue vessel, but the truth is that her capitan still takes his orders from the Crown.

column12: When this ship carries no cargo, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: The crew of El Hambre named their ship after their lust for gold, which motivates them more than any whip-wielding bosun.

column12: Once per turn, if this ship is touching another ship, reveal all face-down treasure aboard the other ship. This ship can take as much unique treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: The Spanish Crown is said to control more supernatural artifacts than any other realm due to the items that Rollando has “acquired” during his travels.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: There are many who can only lament Spain's fall from naval power. Duque Alfonzo de Castilla laughs at their ignorance as he leads a new generation of sailors intent on not repeating their forefathers' mistakes.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: La Delacroix has sailed for France under the Crown and the Republic, and has seen more than her fair share of death.

column12: Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Capitaine Gaston is really the Marquis LeRoux, who escaped “Madame Guillotine” and rose through the ranks of the Navy.

column12: As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: French naval records show that the crew of the Marie Antoinette have mutinied numerous times, but somehow are always given letters of marque.

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: La Valois is the newest ship in France's navy, built to take advantage of the latest weapons.

column12: If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: The gunners about La Toulouse are opportunists who know how to exploit even the smallest weakness.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-French ship.
column13: Capitaine Molineux's loyalty to France is fierce, and his crew have adopted his nationalistic pride.

column12: Icebreaker. Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Le Breton has sailed farther north than any other French vessel in her search for the elusive Northwest Passage.

column12: After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: After having spent years in the sultry South China Seas, Capitaine Casta and his crew now relish their reassignment to the Frozen North.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: La Belois is used as a training vessel for French marine recruits.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
column13: The Marianne's crew are Republican through and through, proudly naming their vessel for the symbol of revolutionary freedom.

column12: If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: Leander Arnaud has found that life on a ship is really the only way to live. He targets only ships that he considers to be filled with an unjust supply of gold, regardless of affiliation.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action.
column13: A true believer in the liberte, egalite, and fraternite of the French Revolution, Louis was born poor but became the face of the French Navy due to his ability to lead men.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
You may double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: Captain Toluca is known to brag in Annapolis taverns about his crew's ability to hit an albatross with a cannon at five hundred yards.

column12: If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: The crew of USS Albany is composed of former prisoners of war who are focused only on extracting gold from their prey.

column12: As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Captain Liebowitz spent many years in the Frozen North, where he learned to command ruthlessly out of sheer necessity.

column12: Broadsides Attack.
column13: USS Cleveland's powerful guns can tear a ship apart with a single attack.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-American ship or fort.
column13: The crew members of USS Sioux are among the most idealistic in the American Navy, although their enemies see them as little more than nationalistic thugs.

column12: Icebreaker. Once per turn, if this ship is within S of an island, you may mark the island as explored without docking at it. The island becomes unexplored in regards to all other players.
column13: USS Cheyenne was commissioned for a secret American enterprise: to unlock the ice floes north of Canada and take command of the Frozen North.

column12: This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: Captain Griffin understands the principle of military might, and has trained his crew to attack ships in such as way that their crews surrender almost immediately.

column12: On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew and one mast from the rammed ship.
column13: Originally a whaling vessel, USS Maryland is armed with harpoons that her crew uses to fend off would-be attackers.

column12: Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Captain Doggett has sailed from the Barbary Coast to the Frozen North, recruiting any who would fight for democracy and justice.

column12: Friendly ships within S of this ship get +1 to their cannon rolls.
column13: This plucky little vessel has defeated ships four times her size, and the very sight of her inspires other crews to great deeds.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Viking ships.
column13: No one knows exactly where Brown came from, but when he came to Boston with knowledge of the Vikings and their operations, he was welcomed by private ship owners as well as American naval leaders.

column12: This ship ignores terrain, except icebergs, when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain). Once per turn, if this ship is within S of an island, you may mark the island as explored without docking at it. The island becomes unexplored in regards to all other players.
column13: When he isn't in New York being feted by money men and their daughters, Dr. Lewis can be found searching the Frozen North for the elusive passage to the Far East.

If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. Load this treasure face down. You may reveal it at the start of your turn. When revealed, none of this ship's abilities or crew abilities can be used this turn. This ship can be given two shoot actions this turn. The targets of the shoot actions cannot use their abilities or crew abilities this turn. Then remove Runes of Power from the game.

Load this treasure face down. You may reveal it at the start of your turn. When revealed, none of this ship's abilities or crew abilities can be used this turn. This ship can be given two move actions this turn. Then remove Runes of Speed from the game.

Load this treasure face down. You may choose to reveal it when one of this ship's masts is eliminated. When revealed, repair the mast and then move this ship S in any direction. Then remove Runes of Defense from the game.
Load this treasure face down. When revealed, eliminate an iceberg, and then remove Runes of Destruction from the game.
Load this treasure face down. When revealed, move any iceberg L in any direction. Then remove Runes of Magic from the game.

This treasure takes up one cargo space. When this ship has reached her cargo capacity, roll a d6. Replace the value of each non-unique treasure on this ship with the result. Then remove Runes of Wealth from the game.
Load this treasure face down. You may choose to reveal it after a d6 has been rolled. Change the result of the die roll to 1. Then remove Runes of Loki from the game.
Load this treasure face down. You may choose to reveal it after a d6 has been rolled. Change the result of the die roll to 6. Then remove Runes of Thor from the game.

Load this treasure face down. When revealed, place an iceberg from outside the game anywhere in the play area not within S of an island. If the iceberg touches any ship, remove the ship (and any crew and treasure aboard her) from the game. Then remove Runes of Odin from the game.

This treasure takes up one cargo space. This ship can dock at any iceberg. On her next turn, you may place her docked at any other iceberg; she can still be given a move action that turn. Then remove Runes of the Serpent from the game.

You must declare which cannon will shoot the chainshot before rolling the d6. If the chainshot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target cannot move on her next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, you may declare that one of her cannons is shooting a smokepot instead of a cannon; you do not need to target a ship. Simply place the center of a fog bank within S of this ship; it may not touch an island or any ship docked at an island. Remove the fog bank at the beginning of your next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a stinkpot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the stinkpot before rolling the d6. If the stinkpot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target's crew cannot use their abilities on the target's next turn.
Icebreaker. Ghost Ship.
column13: The Urd and her crew have sailed farther into the Frozen North than any other ship. They found something ancient and unspeakable under the ice, and have since earned a reputation for deeds so foul they make even the most hardened berserker shudder.

column12: Longship. Fear. If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: The Verdani is manned by Vikings whose horrific deeds called out to Davy Jones. Through his power, they sail the seas to sate their bloodlust. Even though they believe they serve Loki, Davy Jones is the hidden source of their power.

column12: This treasure takes up one cargo space. At the beginning of each turn, eliminate one crew from this ship. If there are no crew, eliminate a mast instead. Once all the ship's crew and masts have been eliminated, eliminate Runes of Death. Runes of Death cannot be unloaded, but it can be transferred to another ship this ship touches.
Longship. Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.
column13: The United States stole this longship with the unofficial help of France, and then turned her into a spy ship.

column12: Longship. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-English ship.
column13: The queen of England herself ordered this ship built in order to extend England's empire to lands where the sun never sets.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action. Any treasure coin printed with a silver number that this ship unloads at your home island is worth +1 gold.
Longship. Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The Elsinore's crew is made up entirely of English and American intellectuals who have read about the Frozen North and decided to try their hands at being Vikings.

column12: Longship. If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, choose two of the following: eliminate a crew, take a treasure, or eliminate a mast.
column13: The Scots who crew HMS Wallace once pledged allegiance to Norway—and their loyalties are questionable, at best.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action. Any treasure coin printed with a silver number that this ship unloads at your home island is worth +1 gold.
Longship. Fear.
column13: Those who operated “Madame Guillotine” during the heady days of the French Revolution are doomed to crew this ship until the end of days.

column12: Longship. This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks.
column13: Rumor has it that Jack Hawkins commissioned this vessel and hand selected her crew.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action. Any treasure coin printed with a silver number that this ship unloads at your home island is worth +1 gold.
Longship. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Cursed ship.
column13: The Russian crew of this longship pay homage to ancient deities long forgotten by the rest of civilization.

column12: Longship. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls against sea monsters.
column13: The Kalaallit's crew hail from the wilds of Greenland, and they hunt their prey as if hunting whales in a kayak.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action. Any treasure coin printed with a silver number that this ship unloads at your home island is worth +1 gold.
Longship. Once per turn, you may eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action.
column13: The Loki's Revenge spews fire like some kind of deranged god, an ability that science has yet to explain.

column12: Longship. This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: Captain Crabtree single-handedly captured HMS Wallace, turned her over to the Crown, and then accepted command of her shortly thereafter.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action. Any treasure coin printed with a silver number that this ship unloads at your home island is worth +1 gold.
Longship. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load up to two treasures. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: The Kalmar haunts the fjords, preying on empires who would abuse the resources in the Frozen North.

column12: Longship. Once per turn, if this ship carries treasure and is within S of an enemy ship, you may randomly trade one treasure with that ship.
column13: Refugees from the Jade Rebellion once fled to the Frozen North, where they stole this ship. They have lived as pirates ever since.

column12: This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action. Any treasure coin printed with a silver number that this ship unloads at your home island is worth +1 gold.
Icebreaker. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Some say that the modern Viking movement comes from a vision seen by Captain Wahlstrom: Odin rising from the ice and commanding him to take back the seas from the evil of the Cursed and the violators of the Viking code.

column12: Longship. If a sea monster begins its move within L of this ship, it gets +L to its base move.
column13: Stories abound that Jormungandr, the World Serpent, spit out the Serpent's Fang, fully intact with crew. Her singular purpose is to slaughter Vikings and leave the dead to fill the belly of her monstrous parent.

column12: When revealed, eliminate one mast from every ship in play. Then remove Odin's Revenge from the game.
Junk. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Cursed ship.
column13: El Fantasma himself raised the Divine Dragon from its watery grave and crewed it with the damned so that he may continue his unholy crusade.

column12: Sea Monster. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this sea monster; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: This hideous fiend was once Gog-Clocthoth's mate, and has spend countless centuries fuelling her hate for him and the humans who worship him.

column12: Once per turn, if this ship is touching another ship, reveal all face-down treasure aboard the other ship. This ship can take as much unique treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: As any crewman aboard the Maman Brigitte can attest, death is merely a minor setback in the eternal search for gold and plunder.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The Juggernaut's crew claim they are Roman soldiers damned to spend an eternity in the service of a forgotten god, reveling forever in the glory of slaughter.

column12: Sea Monster. After this sea monster resolves a shoot action, it may move as a free action.
column13: Maxehebel is notorious for his deadly speed and has destroyed entire fleets with his seemingly bottomless rage.

column12: Titan. This titan ignores the first hit it takes each turn as long as it has all of its segments.
column13: This ancient creature is responsible for the destruction of entire ancient cities, and has now turned its attention to annihilating ships that encroach upon its territory.

column12: Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.
column13: Literally a repository for souls who died on the ocean, the Guinee is a sinkhole of evil that drains the will to live from those she encounters.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: The Lilu's captain claims to be a vampire who has enslaved his crew as they challenge the horrors of the deep for dominance of the waves.

column12: Schooner. If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: It is said this ship is captained by none other than Baron Samhedi himself, who has taken a human form to experience the pleasures of the flesh.

column12: Junk. Once per turn, this ship may randomly take one treasure from any ship she touches.
column13: Some members of the Jade Rebellion sold their souls to evil powers rather than capitulate to the imperialists, and continue their fight forever marked by their decision.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: Pirates everywhere fear the Strix, and say she is crewed entirely by the spirits of former pirate hunters.

column12: If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: When the crew of the Jikininki boards an enemy ship, they kill anyone they cannot put in their cookpots and eat.

column12: This ship cannot be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: When ships fire at Nosso Lar, they find more often than not that their shots will pass right through her hull.

column12: Sea Monster. Fear.
column13: Anyone who sees this creature and lives to tell about it claims that is has a massive scar for every year it has terrorized humans – more than three thousand of them.

column12: Junk. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: The Sea Rat's crew all appear to be a hundred years old, but move with the speed and efficiency of men in the prime of their lives.

column12: Limit. Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 1–4, you may give this ship an extra action; on a 5, you may give any ship you control an extra action; on a 6, you may give an enemy ship an action.
column13: As his power grows and his minions cause more destruction, Jones has begun his second wave of terror, one that will take his power beyond the edge of the oceans themselves—setting him up to rule the seas once and for all!

column12: Fear. If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: The Wraith was Davy Jones' most powerful and feared disciple, a death machine who caused crews to scuttle their own ships rather than face him. That was, until Crimson Angel tricked him into kissing her, rendering him powerless. Davy Jones has given him a second—and final—chance.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action.
column13: After replacing the Wraith as Davy Jones' second-in-command, El Fantasma has set out to recruit the most bloodthirsty crew from the four corners of the world. He cares not if they are alive or dead—only that they will do his bidding.

column12: Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Stabbing his own English patriots in the back, Cavendish joined with rebellious warlords and then attacked his former mates. When he was offered even more influence from Davy Jones, he turned all the warlords over to him, dead or alive. Cavendish's only true allegiance is to power.

column12: This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
