If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against the Cursed.
column13: The Crimson Angel returned to piracy by beating Blackheart at his own game, wagering her own soul for those on the Deliverance. The newly free crew will serve the Angel until they die honorable deaths.

column12: Sea Monster. Give this monster a move action, but do not move it. Move any other sea monster instead.
column13: The pirates who know her claim that Seleucis rose from the brine of the Black Sea, and she now terrorizes ships and lays waste to those who do not respect the sea.

column12: English crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: No one is sure who captains the Pioneer, though hushed whispers claim that Griffin does. The crew changes from trip to trip; they are mostly English now, but that will likely change again soon.

column12: Schooner. If this ship isn't assigned a Helmsman crew, roll a d6 after she resolves a move action. On a result of 4–6, this ship can move L.
column13: Calico Cat once captured this ship, and in a rare moment of charity allowed her crew to go free—although they are forever in her debt.

column12: Titan. This titan eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: Raninoidea was trained by pirates to attack a ship's masts. Nothing is more unnerving than seeing the giant crab clacking its massive claws as pirates loot the derelict.

column12: Sea Monster. You may give this sea monster a shoot action to make one 3L breath attack against a target ship (it may make no other attacks). If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast, per the Firepot Specialist rules.
column13: Although it seems to favor Welsh buccaneers, when Morgawr is hungry she answers to no flag and attacks ships without discretion or pity.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: Captain Podray built this ship himself and named her after his favorite tavern. He and his crew have a reputation for tactics others consider insane.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Pirate ship.
column13: Captain Dan and the crew of HMS Rickets are known the world over for their excessive rum consumption and their habit of always keeping their cannons loaded.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may move S after unloading cargo.
column13: Commodore Brumwell quietly recruited former members of the Jade Rebellion who specialize in smuggling.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: After the Jade Rebellion was crushed by European powers, some members like Captain Hu and his Just Wind continue to fight the imperial powers.

column12: If this ship has a Captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: Calico Cat bristles at having lost her fleet, but stole this merchant vessel and christened her the Cat's Claw to let her enemies know she's coming for them.

column12: Ramming cannot eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: This ship routinely careens off the coast of Antarctica. Captain Crabtree and his crew believe the cold reinforces the strength of their ship's hull.

column12: Sea Monster. If this sea monster succeeds at a boarding party, it may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: Pirates have nicknamed this gigantic shark after one of their own, and have made him a mascot of sorts.

column12: When this ship hits an enemy ship, you may also eliminate one cargo from that ship.
column13: Captain Rontacourt seems more interested in wanton destruction than in capturing enemy cargo, a sentiment his crew heartily embraces as long as the rum keeps flowing.

column12: Turtle Ship. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against the Cursed.
column13: The Proud Tortoise escaped the fate of many of her sisters, who were stricken by the fell magic of the Cursed.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Rumors persist that Jack has softened in his desire for gold, pillaging, and raiding, that he cares only about his vendetta against El Fantasma. Of course, Jack loves those rumors because they make others underestimate him and his crack crew.

column12: Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Pirate ship.
column13: The Cat seems to have used up another one of her lives. After being reported dead in the South China Seas, she somehow managed to steal an English merchantman loaded with silk and gold from Africa.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Pirate ship.
column13: Crimson Angel returned to piracy by beating Blackheart at his own game, wagering her own soul for those aboard the Deliverance. The newly free crew will serve her until they die honorable deaths.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls against the Cursed. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: His fleet sunk by sea monsters controlled by Davy Jones, ports sacked by the English, and crew taken by the French, Spanish, and Americans, Shap'ng was found in a Singapore dive by Jack Hawkins, who gave him a new lease on life.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Secretive and mysterious, his face covered by a mask, the Griffin (as his crew calls him) rarely speaks or leaves his ship. He swaps crew at every port so that he leaves no pattern to follow. Yet no one knows who he really is, or what his goals truly are.

column12: If this ship wins a ram roll against a sea monster or titan, remove two segments instead of one.
column13: Empress is a Bengal tiger who sits at the right hand of Griffin, both figuratively and literally. He trusts her more than any of his crew. And after watching her rip apart Griffin's enemies, the crew treats her with all deference due a superior.

column12: Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
Junk. Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Admiral Kenyon made a great show of the Jade Rebellion surrendering this ship to his forces, and now uses her as his flagship to symbolize English power.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: Known as the “right hand of the Queen,” HMS Victoria is systematically hunting down the last pirates who oppose English trade.

column12: Sea Monster. This sea monster gets +1 to its boarding rolls. If it succeeds at a boarding party, it also eliminates a mast.
column13: Carvings of this ancient monster have been unearthed off the coasts of Scotland and Ireland, leading scholars to believe that it is older than history and more evil than anyone can imagine.

column12: Schooner. When touching a Pirate ship, this ship may load as much of that ship's treasure as she can carry.
column13: HMS Dunlap continues her exceptional service to the Crown, looting and pillaging every ship she encounters.

column12: After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Captain Samson is known for encouraging his crew to sing bawdy sea shanties, which keep their spirits high so that they can accomplish great feats of naval prowess.

column12: Junk. If this ship shoots at a ship that was previously shot at by another ship this turn, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls against that ship this turn.
column13: HMS Clear Wind's crew willingly surrendered to England, and they quietly wait for the day when they can resurrect the Jade Rebellion.

column12: When this ship hits another ship, you choose which mast is eliminated.
column13: It is said of both monarch and ship that England is lucky there is only one King John, even though her crew are some of the finest cannoneers England has ever produced.

column12: When this ship carries no cargo, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: HMS Galway was built as a fast warship, and her captain prefers to do the shooting and let other ships clean up the mess afterward.

column12: Junk. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: HMS Sea Phoenix was pressed into service by France and subsequently captured by England. The only vestiges of her Jade Rebellion roots are her design and name.

column12: If this ship isn't assigned a Helmsman crew, roll a d6 after she resolves a move action. On a result of 4–6, this ship can move L.
column13: Once the property of El Fantasma and then Jack Hawkins, HMS Snipe is now the property of England and under the command of the young Captain Mulvihill.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Gunn's exploits under his father's guidance won him acclaim with his crew and his military commanders. His victories for the English Crown won him his own title, his pick of ships, and the freedom to follow his own counsel at sea.

column12: Black Mark. If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: Hampstead knows that money—not the Crown—is what keeps the world turning, and he'll do whatever is necessary to keep that money flowing back to the investors in London. Flags, kings, and courts are all secondary.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: When Gunn defeated Suong, he spared Suong's life because he knew that Suong could help him understand the minds of pirates, rogues, and warlords. Suong has repaid his debt with an astounding amount of information.

column12: Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: El Acorazado was recently discovered rotting away in a Spanish shipyard. She was restored and outfitted with harpoons to battle a different enemy.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Spanish ship.
column13: Capitan Ladron, the great-grandson of La Resolucion's original capitan, and his ship are among the last vestiges of Spain's former naval glory.

column12: Titan. Fear.
column13: El Pescador seems to have tamed this horrid creature, and have trained it as a vessel of war.

column12: Schooner. Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Spain's new policy of open recruitment has given a home to many sailors with nowhere else to go aboard Salte el Tiburon.

column12: One of this ship's treasures is worth +1 gold when she docks at your home island.
column13: La Cordoba was one of the last ships to make the famed treasure fleet run from the Spanish Main to Spain, even though the treasure is all but gone.

column12: After looking at treasure on a wild island, you may trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
column13: Capitan de la Cruz has little time for legalities of trade, and simply uses his influence to rewrite laws that don't suit his needs.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: La Serpiente's cannoneers swapped gunpowder for harpoons, and now use their considerable skill against the horrors of the deep.

column12: Once per turn when this ship hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Crewed by the best Spain has to offer, La Reconquistador continues to fight for Spanish glory, even though others have written it off as a hopeless cause.

column12: This ship may never load the last treasure from an island.
column13: Capitan Vencinia has become a victim of his own success, having replaced shrewd negotiating with wastefulness and gluttony.

column12: This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Capitan Santana once fought the Jade Rebellion, and now opposes those nations who have made peace with his sworn enemy.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Victor, son of Luis de Alva, the great comandante of the Spanish fleets, believes as his father did that Spain is blessed by the gods. Those blinded by New World gold may have temporarily tarnished Spain's luster, but she is destined to return to her deserved glory.

column12: If a sea monster begins its move within L of this ship, it gets +L to its base move.
column13: El Pescador, “the fisherman,” is able to command the sea creatures that have recently created havoc on the shipping lines. He personally tamed the giant crab El Toro.

column12: This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.

This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls against the Cursed. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Le Gaule's successful campaign to build French power in the Pacific made her a legend in her time, and the French have now loosed her upon the Cursed.

column12: Schooner. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: Le Bonaparte was instrumental in crushing the Jade Rebellion, and has since been refitted to hunt serpents, crabs, and other horrors of the deep.

column12: If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: Le Musarde has been seen trading goods with known enemies of France, but somehow continues to raid quite effectively under the French flag.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: This aging but extraordinary vessel has been charged with protecting French interests against the “criminal colonies” in Australia.

column12: Junk. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: The French found this ship scuttled off the coast of New Guinea. They raised her, crewed her, and then turned her against her former owners.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: Having personally sunk more Barbary corsair ships than entire fleets have, Captain Ange now has turned his attention to the last of the pirate element.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Captain Roi named his ship after his favorite place in Paris, although his men secretly loathe the name.

column12: Sea Monster. If this sea monster succeeds at a boarding party, it may eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: This colossal predator was named by Pierre Aronnax, and the crew of French ships everywhere thank God every day that it seems to avoid their ships as it destroys those of other nations.

column12: This ship cannot shoot when she carries treasure.
column13: Le Coeur du Lion is a mere shell of her former self, barely able to maintain discipline among her crew and sporting more leaks than usable cannons.

column12: Turtle Ship. Pirate crew may use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The Floating Stone is France's experiment in allowing revolutionaries and former members of the Jade Rebellion to try to make amends by fighting for their new masters.

column12: Crew of any nationality may use their abilities on this ship. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Add “revolutionary” to the list of “occupations” Dumas has held. He has simultaneously been branded both a hero and an enemy of France, and he uses that confusion to attack friend and foe alike—after all, it's easier to ask forgiveness than permission.

column12: Once per turn, this ship may look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
column13: Old Vidal has sailed under the French flag his entire life; he was even born on a ship. Considered by many to be a good-luck charm, Vidal has the uncanny ability to discern a ship's allegiance, even if she flies a fake flag.

column12: This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
This ship gains one 3S cannon that may not have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: “Old Ironsides” still keeps America's shores safe from piracy, and recently sent the notorious pirate Blackbeard to his watery doom—or so her captain claims.

column12: Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: USS Kentucky is an assignment reserved for elite graduates of Annapolis, where they are trained to become future admirals.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, this ship may move S after loading treasure.
column13: USS Oregon was the United States' first vessel commissioned on the West Coast, and has become a common sight on the Pacific.

column12: Sea Monster. If this sea monster succeeds at a boarding party, it also eliminates one mast.
column13: No one knows how Champ escaped Lake Champlain, or why she seems to attack ships at the behest of American handlers, but no one can deny her destructive power.

column12: When touching a Pirate ship, this ship may load as much of that ship's treasure as she can carry.
column13: Captain Adams hunts pirates for his government but keeps their treasure to sell on the black market, making him one of the wealthiest men in the Navy.

column12: Schooner. L-range cannons cannot hit this ship.
column13: USS Georgetown was nearly sunk exploring the Mysterious Islands, but her captain learned from the experience and now keeps her low in the water as a precaution.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: An old but reliable ship, USS James Madison was instrumental in destroying the Jade Rebellion and conducting Commodore Perry into Shanghai.

column12: If this ship wins a boarding party, she may take as much treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: The crew of USS Aaron Burr are little more than common thugs, and although they claim to be members of the American Navy, no official records exist to confirm that affiliation.

column12: Junk. When this ship is docked at your home island, you may eliminate one treasure. It becomes a 3S cannon that can be eliminated only when the ship sinks.
column13: The crew of USS Sea Tiger found it more lucrative to abandon their revolutionary ideals in favor of the lure of American dollars.

column12: If this ship isn't assigned a Helmsman crew, roll a d6 after she resolves a move action. On a result of 4–6, this ship can move L.
column13: Small but exceptionally fast, USS Plymouth Rock has a reputation for stealing treasure from under the noses of America's enemies.

column12: Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given the same action twice. This ship's crew cannot be eliminated unless she sinks.
column13: May's military commanders dislike his wild and reckless ways: he's lost seven ships chasing sea monsters and other Cursed ilk. But they admit that he always finds a new ship to sail, even if she doesn't meet Navy specs. His crew and the American press love him, and extol his exploits every chance they get.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: Promoted at sea when his captain was pulled overboard by a giant tentacle, Master Richard is determined to prepare his “boys” for battles against both the real and unreal threats of the Cursed.

column12: Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons may shoot again if it misses.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a firepot at a target within S of her. Declare which cannon will shoot the firepot before rolling the d6. If it hits, the target's controller replaces one of her masts with a fire mast. At the beginning of every turn, roll one d6 for each fire mast. On a result of 6, remove the fire mast; on a 1–3, the ship's controller replaces another of her masts with a fire mast. When a ship has only fire masts, she must be scuttled on her next turn. When a ship docks at her home island or a fort, remove all of her fire masts as a free action.
Immediately dock this ship at the wild island with the fewest treasure coins on it. If there is a tie, your opponent chooses which tied island this ship docks at.
This ship can shoot at submerged ships within S of her.
Load this treasure face down. You may reveal it any time a crew on this ship would be eliminated. Place that crew on the nearest wild island instead. Remove Driftwood from the game.

One of this ship's cannons becomes a claw cannon (you choose which). When you give this ship a shoot action, you can fire all your other cannons as normal or you can fire the Claw Cannon only. If the Claw Cannon hits, eliminate a mast as normal and then place the target ship next to this ship; you can immediately initiate a boarding party. Neither ship is rammed.

Load this treasure face down. You may reveal it when you give this ship a move action and can draw a straight line (that does not cross a game piece, terrain, or other islands) from this ship's bow to your home island. Immediately dock this ship at your home island. Remove Homing Beacon from the game.
Sea dragons, sea monsters, and titans get +1 to their cannon rolls against this ship. Curse of Davy Jones cannot be unloaded from this ship.
This ship can move through whirlpools without losing crew, masts, or treasure.

Load this treasure face down. You may reveal it when this ship is attacked by a sea dragon, sea monster, or titan. The attacker's player must eliminate a segment from the attacker and move it S away from this ship. Remove Triton's Defense from the game.

Roll a d6. Place a number of terrain pieces from outside the game on the play area equal to the die roll result. All terrain must be placed at least S from any other terrain or island. Terrain may be placed under ships and monsters.
Immediately move this ship into the nearest whirlpool, and then follow the whirlpool rules for ship placement and damage.

Titan. This titan ignores the first hit it takes each turn as long as it has all of its segments.
column13: This ancient creature is responsible for the destruction of entire ancient cities, and has now turned its attention to annihilating ships that encroach upon its territory.

column12: Sea Monster. Fear.
column13: Anyone who sees this creature and lives to tell about it claims that is has a massive scar for every year it has terrorized humans – more than three thousand of them.

column12: This ship may move and shoot using the same move action.
Catamaran. Once per turn, you may reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Captain Black Szubski once saw natives sailing a ship the likes of which he had never seen. She moved almost too fast to see, like a stone skipping over the waves. And he knew then that he would own one—and get rich sailing her.

column12: Catamaran. This ship ignores terrain when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain).
column13: The crew of HMS Hermes have been tasked with scouting as many islands as possible. They are secretly tracking which islands can be used as either naval staging points, trade ports, or pirate havens.

column12: Sea Dragon. Fear.
column13: Davy Jones treats this demonic beast more like a partner in destruction than a pet. Shal-Bala doesn't need to be told her purpose: to strike fear and terror into the hearts of anyone not worshipping at the bloody altars of Davy Jones.

column12: Sea Dragon. When this sea dragon hits an enemy ship, you may also eliminate one cargo from that ship.
column13: Angelica was given her name by Jack Hawkins because she once swooped down and destroyed an English battleship that was about to unleash a broadsides attack upon the Deliverance. Since then Jack has kept a cow on board to feed her whenever she appears.

column12: Windcatcher. Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship cannot use its ability that turn.
column13: Designed in secret by some of the top naval minds in the United States, the Ghost Walker is an experimental ship that sails the seas spying on friends and foe alike so that the admiralty can be prepared for all future operations.

column12: Windcatcher. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: No one know how Captain One-Eye Tuttle got his hands on this prototype, but ports all over the world claim they have been pillaged by the Mystic—and they blame the Americans, who deny everything. As One-Eye gets rich, more fingers continue to get pointed.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Cursed ship.
column13: The crew of the Last Hope hang their victims from her masts as a message to any captain looking through his spyglass: This is your fate.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Jokers and rogues to a person, the crew of the Jape love to play their out-of-tune instruments loudly as they come upon a target in order to obscure their true purpose: piracy.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-English ship.
column13: Prowling from island to island, HMS Burma's purpose is to enforce good behavior from other sailing ships—especially those flying the skull and crossbones.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-American ship or fort.
column13: Sailing from the West Coast, USS Seattle has been given the latitude to determine whom to fire on and whom to befriend. Captain Hauck has decided to take no prisoners in order to keep the Pacific free from those who would terrorize it.

column12: Junk. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls for every friendly ship within S of her.
column13: This ship was taken in a bloody battle near Hong Kong. The American crew actually swam to her when their ship sank, surprising the crew aboard the Sea Wind.

column12: Junk. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she may move as a free action.
column13: Captain Mays put out the word that the first Jade Rebellion crew to turn themselves in would get a bag of gold and a piece of land in California. The crew of the Sea Serpent were the only takers.

column12: Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, you may declare that one of her cannons is shooting a smokepot instead of a cannon; you do not need to target a ship. Simply place the center of a fog bank within S of this ship; it may not touch an island or any ship docked at an island. Remove the fog bank at the beginning of your next turn.

Once per turn when this ship is given a shoot action, one of her cannons may shoot a chainshot at a target within S of her. You must declare which cannon will shoot the chainshot before rolling the d6. If the chainshot hits, do not eliminate a mast; instead, the target cannot move on her next turn.
This ship may dock and explore a wild island using the same move action. Any treasure coin printed with a silver number that this ship unloads at your home island is worth +1 gold.
Junk. This ship may dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: When their ancestor spirits seemed to indicate that they should help a Spanish galleon rather than attack her, the crew of the Virtuous Wind were welcomed as allies by the Spanish Crown.

column13: Blackheart attacked the Baochuan with a fleet of six ships. Five of those ships were lost before a single hit was scored against the great ship of the Jade Rebellion. Changing Tactics, Blackheart used his last ship, the Blackheart, to volley shot after shot, all the while maneuvering quickly out of the way to avoid return fire. It took nearly a day of combat, but in the end Blackheart walked upon the decks of the Baochuan, claiming her and raising his flag. Once in control of the massive 10 mast junk, he renamed himself “Emperor Blackheart” – after all, he was in command of the greatest of the gods.

With the sweat of our brow and the strength of our backs and the courage in our hearts! Gentlemen, hoist the colors!”                                                                                                                         —Elizabeth Swann

Eliminate the crew on this ship with the lowest point cost. Then remove Cannibals from the game.
This ship can unload cargo at your home island if she's within S of it.
This ship can't be given an action the turn after loading Plunder. After loading Plunder, roll a d6; Plunder is worth gold equal to the result.
This ship can dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
When this ship unloads gold at your home island, double the gold value of the treasure with the lowest gold value on this ship. Then remove Smuggled Goods from the game.
Fear. If this ship has a captain crew, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13:
“You've seen a ship with black sails that's crewed by the damned, and captained by a man so evil that Hell itself spat him back out?”
—Mullroy

column12: Friendly ships within S of this ship get +1 to their cannon rolls.
column13: Rumors of the Fantasia are whispered in every pirate port: a ship of pure magic that will sail for only the pure of heart.

column12: Parley. Once at the beginning of each of your turns, roll a d6. On a result of 6, no abilities except Parley can be used until the beginning of your next turn.
column13:
“ ‘The Immortal Captain Jack Sparrow.' ” It has such a lovely ring to it, and it's not a bad look, really.”
—Jack Sparrow

column12: At the beginning of each of your turns, roll a d6. On a result of 1, eliminate a kraken. On 2-5 ignore any damage dealt by a kraken to a friendly ship this turn. On a 6, choose any kraken and place it within S of an enemy ship.
This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: HMS Diamond sails the oceans hunting and destroying pirates under direct orders from Lord Beckett.

column12: You can double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: With cannons made of the purest steel in London forges, HMS Phoenix can target a ship as soon as she can spy it.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: The crew of the Neptune would rather fight the East Indian Trading Company than hide from it.

column12: This ship can dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: The best gold, the crew of the Sea Nymph have found, is the gold someone else has already done all the work collecting.

column12: Kraken.
column13:
“A fearsome creature with giant tentacles that suction your face clean off. And drag an entire ship past the crushing darkness.”
—Joshamee Gibbs

column12: Kraken. Eternal.
column13:
“Hello, beastie.”
—Jack Sparrow

column12: Kraken. Each turn roll a d6, on a result of 5 or 6 no crew abilities can be used this turn.
column13:
“ . . . I always heard it said ‘kray-kin.' ”
—Pintel

“It's a mythological creature, I can calls it what I wants!”
—Ragetti

column12: Kraken. Eternal. Each turn roll a d6, on a result of 5 or 6 no crew abilities can be used this turn.
column13:
“Let no joyful voice be heard! Let no man look up at the sky with hope! And let this day be cursed by we who ready to wake . . . the Kraken!”
—Davy Jones
Think this is cool? Try playing the full Pirates of the Caribbean PocketModel™ CSG! Learn more at www.wizkidsgames.com/pirates or www.disneypirates.com!

column12: Eternal. If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, choose two of the following: eliminate a crew, take a treasure, or eliminate a mast.
column13: The crew of the Fool's Hope love the fact that ships seem almost relieved to see them instead of the Cursed—until they learn that Blackheart is aboard.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against Pirate ships.
column13: HMS Apollo has been tasked with sorting the powerful from the weak on the high seas, while not divulging the Crown's true strength.

column12: This ship can dock and explore a wild island using the same move action.
column13: The English fleet has spread across the oceans as England continues to widen its empire, and the Aberdeen Baron has seen more ports than most.

column12: If this ship has a captain crew, she gets +L to her base move.
column13: Spain has tied its fortunes to Victor de Alva and this ship, named after the patron saint of travelers, St. Christopher.

column12: This ship can dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Captain Watson takes great pride in the fact that his ship can “weasel” in and out of port without anyone noticing.

column12: L-range cannons can't hit this ship.
column13: HMS Stingray is a prime example of England's newfound realization that stealth can be as valuable as strength.

column12: Once per turn, this ship can look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
column13: “Follow the gold wherever it leads” is the crew's pledge, and it's made both them and Spain very wealthy.

column12: When touching a Pirate ship, this ship can load as much of that ship's treasure as she can carry.
column13: Pirates are still the most satisfying targets for the Spanish fleet, and so this young crew hunts them in order to earn the Crown's respect.

column12: Scorpion, Fear.
column13: Rumors tell that this ship is crewed by the worshippers of the four horsemen of the apocalypse, and no one has lived to dispute them.

column12: Scorpion. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The Scythe often pretends to float deserted on the sea—until her blade comes whining down and fiends rise from her bowels in a swarm of evil.

column12: Scorpion, Eternal.
column13: The first of the Cursed's terrible new ships, the Scorpion was named by English sailors who watched her devastate a fleet of ships off the coast of England.

column12: Scorpion. This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her masts.
column13: The all-too-human crew of the Bloody Blade keep their giant “stinger” coated in the blood of their victims.

column12: Flotilla. Printed cannon ranges are doubled.
column13: Death's Anchor proves that the Cursed are all too capable of taking the technology of the time and adapting it to their own brand of evil.

column12: Flotilla. Printed cannon ranges are doubled.
column13: First deployed in the Caribbean, El Diablo surprised pirates used to Spain's “old ways.”

column12: Flotilla. Printed cannon ranges are doubled.
column13: The English created this “sea tank” after Cursed attacks became too bold and occurred too near their own borders.

column12: Flotilla. Printed cannon ranges are doubled.
column13: Using stolen plans, the Americans fashioned their own flotillas and stationed them in the harbors of the Atlantic Coast.

column12: Loyal: Cursed. Eternal, Fear. Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship can be given the same action twice.
column13: Completely in command of the Cursed—from the undead and fiends of the sea to humans who crave unholy power—El Fantasma has assembled a devastating following. His search for even more powerful ancient artifacts is his only goal. Those who oppose him are nothing more than food for his minions.

column12: If a sea monster begins its move within L of this ship, it gets +L to its base move.
column13: The seventh daughter of the seventh daughter, the Hag of Tortuga was destined to great power as a voodoo priestess. But El Fantasma corrupted her after discovering her ability to speak with the fiends of the sea.

column12: If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she can eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: Known to use torture and other unspeakable acts to acquire gold, Blackheart is considered by many to be no better than the Cursed. Still, he is pirate through and through, only too willing to inflict a little bloodshed to guarantee respect.

column12: Loyal: Pirate. Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship can be given an extra action.
column13: “Cannonball” is a second-generation pirate not beholden to the longstanding feuds of his kind, including those of his mother, Genny Gallows. Instead he despises those who would control adventure-loving free spirits of the sea.

column12: Loyal: England. Captain, Helmsman.
column13: Having been given command of the English flagship by the Crown, Thomas Gunn has followed in his father's footsteps. Immaculate pedigree in tow, Gunn knows that the eyes of all of England are watching his every move—just the way he likes it.

column12: Hostile: Pirate, Loyal: Spain. Captain.
column13: Luis Zuan spent his youth living down the reputation of his uncles, both anti-Spanish pirates. He knows that the only way to repair his family's reputation is to take the fight to any ship flying the Jolly Roger.

column12: If a sea monster begins its move within L of this ship, it gets +L to its base move.
column13: Arnaud advises France on affairs of the Cursed, but unknown to them, he is actually the godson of the Hag of Tortuga. Though he has tried desperately to forget his past, he owes the Hag a debt of life—a debt she intends to see him pay in full.

column12: Loyal: France. Parley. Once per turn, you can reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Some swear to have seen Lenoir at sites of ship explosions, sacked ports, and supposedly unexplored islands. Others say he whispers in the ear of the French king. True or not, what is known is that paying too much attention to Lenior is bad for your health.

column12: Eternal. Once per turn, you can reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Sailors talk of the seas never being without a lady scorned, and the Calico Cat's newest vessel proves it. This ship of the line is painted blue so that she can blend into both the sea and sky to surprise her suddenly numerous enemies.

column12: When touching a Pirate ship, this ship can load as much of that ship's treasure as she can carry.
column13: Under orders from Gunn himself, HMS St. George patrols only for ships flying the Jolly Roger in an effort to rid the waters of pirate ilk.

column12: One of this ship's treasures is worth +2 gold when unloaded at your home island.
column13: Rumors persist that El Concepcion never leaves a port without her hold brimming with gold, making her a marked ship by those who value Spanish wealth.

column12: Eternal
column13: Claimed to have been sunk by every faction on the sea, La Tepant continues to sail proudly for France.

column12: Parley
column13: The Royal Louis craves neither gold nor military accolades. Her goal is to gather information that will help France decide military policy.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: Hiring whalers instead of gunners, the captain of the Congress is confident that his crew are prepared to fight the ghastly beasts of the Cursed.

column12: When this ship is given an explore action, you can swap a treasure on the wild island a crew on any friendly ship.
column13: The crew of the Rising Sun are wary of Captain Wyung because of his habit of leaving behind crew to make room for more treasure.

column12: This ship can dock at an enemy home island and load one treasure. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: The captain of the Siren's Song considers it good business to pay dock masters a portion of the spoils when his crew pillages their ports.

column12: Crew of any nationality can use their abilities on this ship.
column13: She flies an English flag, but HMS Merlin can be crewed by anyone who wants to fire a cannon and find gold. No personal history is divulged and none is required.

column12: Once per turn, if this ship carries treasure and is within S of an enemy ship, you can randomly trade one treasure with that ship.
column13: The crew of the San Estaban have discovered the lucrative business of  exchanging goods for gold—an easy way to get rich as long as the Crown doesn't catch on.

column12: Once per turn, this ship can move S after unloading cargo.
column13: The French prefer to keep their ships at sea rather than in port, so the crew of Le Jaguar don't spend the night in dock if they don't have to.

column12: If this ship has a captain crew, she gets +L to her base move.
column13: The Saratoga has a history of being a slacker ship, but under the command of a strong captain she has proved herself a quick and motivated vessel.

column12: Schooner. This ship can dock at an enemy home island and take as much treasure as she can carry. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: With the seas so dangerously infested with the Cursed, the crew of the Belladonna have taken to stealing gold from docked ships, where it's safer.

column12: Schooner. As part of a move action, this ship can initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship can't use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Using the natural maneuverability of the schooner, the crew of Le Mercure board a ship before their target can prepare for battle.

column12: Schooner. After this ship resolves a shoot action, she can move as a free action.
column13: Like her namesake, the Gold Eagle swoops in for the attack and then quickly moves out of range—playing with her target like predator plays with its prey.

column12: Schooner. This ship can't be shot at by ships within S of her.
column13: The crew of the Black Arrow close in quickly and confuse their enemies into missing with their cannons, while they attack.

column12: Schooner. When this ship carries no cargo, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: Small and light, Le Glaive cuts so easily though choppy seas that even when laden with gold she remains difficult to track.

column12: Schooner. This ship can't be pinned.
column13: The crew of the Fly know that if they tack just right, they can't be pinned. They use that knowledge to tie up and confound larger ships.

column12: If this ship ends her turn in a fog bank, on her next turn she can use her move action to move out of any other fog bank in play.
column13: The Needle seems to appear and disappear like a specter into the fog. Sailors throughout the seas fear that she is nothing less than a nightmare come to the waking world.

column12: You can double the range of this ship's cannons each turn, but you must roll a 6 to hit.
column13: The Sea King is a training ship for English cannoneers. If they become proficient at making their guns shoot farther and more accurately, they are promoted to bigger ships of the line.

column12: L-range cannons can't hit this ship.
column13: The crew of La Bazana prefer to sail slowly toward their enemy, then turn on a short burst of speed as they close to confound their enemy from targeting them.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: The crew of Le Sabre don't hesitate to draw their cutlasses when cannon fire isn't winning the fight.

column12: This ship ignores terrain when she is given a move action (islands are not terrain).
column13: Armed with the latest navigational devices, the Argo has been tasked to sail the world mapping islands that America can use as ports of call.

column12: If this ship wins a ram roll against a sea monster or titan, remove two segments instead of one.
column13: Crewed by the best whalers from the north Atlantic, the Hancock is attempting to wipe out sea creatures under sway of the Cursed.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: When the Grim Reaper gets close enough to board, undead pour over her sides and onto the deck of her doomed target.

column12: Ghost Ship.
column13: The Crushed Skull seems to appear from nowhere to destroy ships, terrorize crew, and do the bidding of El Fantasma himself.

column12: Once per turn, you can reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Each morning the crew of HMS Pride come to attention and salute the raising of the Union Jack. They are convinced this patriotic ritual brings them luck.

column12: Once per turn, this ship can look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
column13: The crew of La Ventura allow other ships to do the dirty work of collecting gold. Then they take it for their own.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. She gets +2 instead if her opponent is a sea monster.
column13: Fearing Cursed attacks, France has ordered L'Aquilon's harpooners to concentrate solely on sea creatures feeding near France.

column12: When touching a Pirate ship, this ship can load as much of that ship's treasure as she can carry.
column13: The Lady Washington prefers to hunt pirates rather than the Cursed—they figure the living have more need for gold than the dead.

column12: Hostile: Pirate, Loyal: Cursed. Once per turn, if this ship is touching another ship, reveal all treasure aboard the other ship. This ship can take as much unique treasure from the other ship as she can carry, even those that otherwise can't be removed.
column13: Devereaux was always considered an outsider, obsessed with finding mystical items left by ancient gods. When his crew mutinied and left him for dead, he was saved by El Fantasma, who sent him in search of the most powerful artifacts ever created.

column12: Loyal: Pirate. Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship can be given the same action twice.
column13: The Calico Cat is the most powerful female pirate on the cursed seas. Afraid of nothing, she has single-handedly put down a variety of enemies, from mighty England to beasts from the depths. Nothing stands in her way, and she happily collects treasure from those she deems unworthy of possessing it.

column12: Hostile: Cursed, Loyal: Spain. If this ship succeeds at a boarding party, she can eliminate all of the other ship's crew.
column13: The Inquisitor insists that all enemy ships be searched, and all Cursed crew put down before their ship is sunk. He shows no mercy to enemies of Spain, believing any threat a potential puppet of El Fantasma.

column12: Hostile: Cursed, Loyal: England. This ship gains one 3S cannon that can't have its range or cannon roll increased. It can shoot from any mast (even an eliminated mast).
column13: Rumor has it that Van Tyne's soul was once owned by El Fantasma. But he fell in love with Hermione Gold when he saw her in battle against a sea beast attacking an English port. That love set him free and now he has joined the English in their fight against the Cursed.

column12: Captain, Helmsman.
column13: Conscripted to the English for acts of piracy, Hermione uses her tremendous skills as a captain and helmsman to keep her employers happy in their battle against those who oppose the Crown. But it is her knack for piracy (under the good Union Jack) that keeps the crew very, very happy.

column12: Hostile: Pirate, Eternal.
column13: When word came to him that his new bride had been killed by Blackheart, something broke inside David. This long-standing “gentleman of the south” began to sell off his land to gather a personal fleet to rid the seas of pirates. His money ensures he always has a ship ready and willing to go to “war.”

column12: Loyal: Cursed. If any crew on this ship with point cost 4 or less would be eliminated, eliminate this crew instead.
column13: These evil fish-men are rumored to be the souls of the mutinous brought back to life by El Fantasma, freed from an ancient temple below the sea.

column12: Crew of any nationality can use their abilities on this ship.
column13: The Crimson Angel once served alongside the Calico Cat. But her obsession with the Cursed led to her taking on her own ship and a quest to find artifacts to stop them.

column12: Explorer. This ship gets +1 cargo spaces. This crew takes up no cargo space.
column13: Italian by birth and a merchant by trade, Dominic was recruited to open up new ports, establish new trade routes, and discover pockets of gold hidden in the jungles of newly discovered islands.

column12: As part of a move action, this ship can initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship can't use any boarding bonuses.
column13: Griffin has been said to be English royalty, an illegitimate son sent to die at sea, and a pirate in hiding. Griffin maintains his silence and lets his sword do the talking.

column12: Loyal: France, Captain. Once per turn, you can eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action.
column13: Only French men and women of noble blood are safe from the cannons and swords of Arazure's fleet. Everyone else, including his own crew, must fear him. Those not flying the tri-colors are obvious enemies, as are those who fly them without honoring France.

column12: Eternal.
column13: Gus Schultz seems to pop up whenever a docked ship prepares to go out to sea. Sailors claim that you can go to the log of any American ship at any time and see the name Gus Schultz on her rolls.

column12: At the beginning of each of your turns, choose a non-Cursed enemy crew and roll a d6. On a result of 5 or 6, turn that crew face down; it can't use its abilities on its next turn.

When this ship leaves a wild island, randomly choose one of her treasures and put it face down on that island. When this ship touches another ship, randomly choose one of this ship's treasures and put it face down on the other ship; eliminate the treasure instead if the other ship's cargo is full.
column13: The captain had given explicit orders not to open the mysterious barrel under any circumstances, but the night watchman was so intrigued by the strange sounds emanating from within that he couldn't resist taking a peek. The next thing he knew the deck was crawling with enraged monkeys, hell-bent on a single goal: escape from the ship at any cost. It took nearly a week to clean up the mess, and only then did the crew realize how much of their plunder had disappeared along with the wretched creatures.

column12: Instead of loading Blood Money, put it face-up on the wild island. Then reveal all treasure on the island. Each time a ship loads a non-unique treasure from the island, eliminate a crew on that ship that has a point value equal to or greater than the value of that treasure. Eliminate Blood Money when there is no non-unique treasure on the island. Spanish ships are not affected by Blood Money.

When revealed, roll a d6. On a result of 1–3, eliminate the crew on this ship that has the lowest point value; on a 4–6, eliminate the crew that has the highest point value. Then this ship can load one more treasure (only). Then put Cursed Natives face down on the island; this ship must leave the island on your next turn. Cursed ships and crew are not affected by Cursed Natives.
