"I request parley with your captain," Johann Sussler calmly told the man who held a saber to his throat. Sussler knew how to handle pirates; he had not lost a ship or crew yet.

"Parley!" the pirate boomed, and Sussler wondered if he saw a flash of barely hidden amusement on his face. The fighting on the ship slowed and eventually stopped, "Call the captain!"

Sussler noted the poor condition and lack of a flag on the pirate ship. These scum just want some easy gold, and I have maps doctored for such occasions. We'll be heading to port by nightfall, he thought.

"Captain coming aboard!"

The footfalls from the makeshift bridge were slow and deliberate, nearly a shuffle.

What appeared was nothing more than a skeleton-a set of bones in human form wearing the clothes of a long-dead naval captain. Sussler felt bile rise in his throat and had to swallow hard to keep from vomiting all over himself.

The captain held sway over the entire deck. A wave of fear seemed to follow from his glowing yellow eye sockets. Sussler heard his men begin to cry.

A raspy, dry voice of command, starting soft and then becoming louder than it had any right to be, emanated from the fiend's skull. "Who has requested parley with Admiral Sammy the Skull, naval commander under the great El Fantasma, Lord of the Seas?"

And then Sussler saw the blood red flag of El Fantasma being raised high on the ship, and he knew then that he and his would not live another day.

It chafed Captain Prior to no end that he was being commanded by Lord Mycron himself to make this deal. At least this man was dealing with looked normal; in fact, he looked as if he could be any one of the merchants who plied their trade in Port Royal.

"The package . . . do you have it?" The scum could actually speak.

"Sir. Do you have it, sir?" Prior snapped. "I am a member of the English Royal Navy and I will be addressed as such." He didn't have to like his job, but the power had its benefits.

"My pardon, sir. I am not used to dealing with men of your caliber."

Prior handed him the package, a leather satchel that the man opened so quickly Prior thought maybe he hadn't sealed it. The package contained a letter of marque and an English flag. It sickened Prior to see the Union Jack in the hands of scum.

"This will do nicely, Captain Sir," the pirate responded excitedly. "Thank your Lord Mycron and tell him he will not be disappointed with the number of French flags I send to the ocean floor." Prior snorted and turned to leave the pirate on the docks. The church bells struck midnight.

Barstow watched him walk down the pier and waited until the bells stopped ringing. He had an hour before meeting the French captain. A glorious night like this called for a celebratory spot of rum.

"Who are they again?"

"Sir, the governor of Maryland is speaking. Members of Congress are over there. The local politicians are further back. Other members of the president's Cabinet are all sitting by the admiral over there."

"And all of this is for me? Why?"

"Well, sir, you have become a bit of legend. Reports of your adventures in the Pacific have preceded you here and everyone wants to see the newest admiral."

As if on cue, Montana heard his name mentioned loudly by the speaker, followed by a round of huzzahs!

"Now what?"

"You need to acknowledge the crowd sir; a wave of the hand is all they ask."

Standing to face the crowd, Mays waved and sat back down. More cheers rang out and a band began to play a loud and jaunty patriotic song.

"So now back to the ship?"

"No, sir. First you have a lunch thrown by the mayor. Then a reception at the admiral's home. And tonight you will be attending a formal party in your honor at the governor's mansion."

"Do new admirals actually ever get to sail a ship?"

"Of course, sir, you leave in the morning. You need to be in New York for a reception in two days."

Mays sighed. "They said I was getting promoted. I'd hate to see how I'd be punished if I ever did something wrong."

The HMS Destiny was anchored a safe distance from Port St. Louis.

Lord Mycron sat in the captain's cabin eating what passed for prime rib. Even the turnips were barely edible, which was something of a feat since turnips were at their best merely passable. The wine, taken from the French governor's own cellars, was worth the horrible food.

Lord Mycron poured himself another glass and drank it in one gulp. Parts of Port St. Louis were still aflame, and word was that much of the French fighting force had taken to the jungles outside of town, hoping to hold out until the English left.

But Mycron had thought of that and had a squad of marines at the ready. The Redcoats would ensure that Port St. Louis remained his.

It was a simple thing to start a war. First, a few patriotic speeches for the military. Have them plan out attacks on a few easily captured ports like this one, to make the money men in London happy. Then a quick talk in Parliament about new trade routes and more income for the glory of England. And finally, stroke the Captain's ego by tantalizing them with the ultimate defeat of France - an age-old adversary.

He poured a new glass of wine, pushed away the horrid meal, and grabbed the open document on the table. His first order of business as the new governor of Port St. Louis was to change its name, to Fort Mycron.

The sound of swords clashing outside Admiral Laurie's quarters was not something new for a warship. It was odd, though, to hear it while docked in Manchester harbor.

The door burst open and a woman rushed in. Laurie knew immediately who it was. "Cease this now; leave her," he commanded. He watched as his guards slowly closed the door behind them, never letting their eyes leave the unkempt woman.

"I want out," Hermionie Gold demanded, sword still in hand. "I never signed up for war."

She smelled of the sea, the admiral thought, normally a pleasant smell - but not on her. The stench of sulfur from the gunpowder was overwhelming. Her clothes were singed and blood-spattered. Her hair was cropped short and scorched. Her face was caked with grime.

"You never signed up, period. You were assigned," Laurie continued. "Your crimes against the Crown were extensive. Do I need to list them for you? Ship stealing, piracy, pillaging the Crown's ports, murder, vengeance against noble families, blackmail, threats . . .. In fact, I find it odd they didn't just hang you. But lucky for you, somewhere you have a guardian angel. Unlucky for you, you were assigned to me - and I'll use you as I see fit, until the Crown deems your debt satisfied."

"Or I die trying," Gold spat.

"Exactly my hope, my dear. Now back to your ship before I add mutiny to this ever-growing list and have you hung this very day."

"You are joining France's navy at a most glorious time, young capitaine," grizzled veteran Michel spoke first. "You will be a hero and sung about in taverns throughout France, and the choruses will grow louder with each ship you sink." He raised his goblet in salute.

"True," offered Father Ducet, "and if you happen to die, God bless us all, you will be immortal."

"Die!" Phillipe Jordan, already on edge, spat. "I do not want to die, Father. But it seems even God is laughing at me. This ship is larger than the village I grew up in. I'm the son of a corsair. I am a CORSAIR!" Jordan slammed his fist down on the table. "I should not be the captain of a warship. I need one of those faster sloops over there - not a warship."

"Exactly the reason you are the capitaine." It was Lenoir who now spoke, softly as if he couldn't trust the walls. "The English have brought this war to us. They expect - no they know - the kind of response France usually sends: a warship. But, no, this one is led by a daredevil of a corsair, and acts like a corsair's ship. This warship does the unexpected, and by the time the English understand this the scales will tip in France's favor. You, Phillipe Jordan, are the perfect capitaine for the Neptune."

"Amen," replied Father Ducet.

"Another report from the Caribbean, sir, about Capitaine Arazure."

The amiral rubbed his eyes. This war had caused many sleepless nights for him. At all times he had an exact count of the French dead seared into his brain.

But Arazure . . . Arazure was another matter. "What is it this time?"

"Well, sir, he has sunk another three ships. There is no mention of captives."

The amiral sighed. "There would be no captives - Arazure doesn't believe in them."

The secretary paused. "There is some mention of French men, whipped and beaten. I assume they were prisoners aboard the English ships."

"No, no, they were Arazure's crew, I'm sure. Did he kill anyone this time?"

"Sir, are you suggesting Capitaine Arazure is harming his own men?"

"I'm telling you he is. Arazure is nearly insane. He hates the English, which right now makes him valuable to us. But it has become harder and harder to find him crew who can tolerate his mood swings and demands."

"But, sir, if his is harming his own men, shouldn't he be removed?"

"See that tally there on the board? That is the count of English ships sank by Arazure. Make sure you add in those three ships from your report. When that tally stops increasing, then we will deal with him."

With his splyglass trained on a spot on the horizon, Victor de Alva watched the battle rage between the two French ships and three English ships. Bored with the action, he turned to his helmsman. 

"Take us south, around the battle; we are not to be seen. Head toward the islands. Either one of them has a port not on our charts, or the fools have decided to fight to the death in the middle of the ocean."

De Alva knew his history: Spain had gone down the road that leads to war once before, and nearly lost everything. He would not let Spain make the same mistake again.

* * * *

De Alva noted his ship's longitude and latitude in the open journal on his desk, as well as a summary of the battle he had just witnessed.

He then opened his charts and examined the string of islands. Nothing indicated a port at any of them. De Alva put the tip of his finger on the largest island.

"Something is there. I know it," he said aloud. He considered the supplies they had on board and the merchant ships ready to sail at his summons. If he were right, within a week Spain would have a fully functioning port in that cove - no matter who claimed it now.

"Let them fight like children," thought de Alva, "while Spain wins the game."

Keeping the rowboat afloat during the squall consumed all the giant man's attention. Hammersmith's arms kept rowing as rain stung his eyes, but it failed to keep him from focusing on the shore of the tiny island.

Proving to be the stronger force of nature, Hammersmith eventually hit the beach and stumbled across the sand to a large rock.

Using his right hand he examined the surface of the rock until he found a crack. Standing with his back to it he walked out 35 paces, and with a shovel that he had carried like a sword, he began to dig.

* * * *

"I don't want to be disturbed," were Hammersmith's only words as he carried the great chest to his cabin. This was a private mission. His crew knew not to interfere - or else face the foreboding man's wrath. Hammersmith's gaze lingered at the words HMS Hardcastle, which were exquisitely etched in gold on top of the chest. The words below that, however, looked as though they had been scratched there by a rusty nail: Prison Ship.

The chest was filled with various sacks, but he was concerned with only one: the big one labeled "Wordly Possessions of Prisoner #5984, Mr. Hammersmith. Not to be opened until received at the Royal Australian Penal Colony."

Hammersmith opened the sack and a smile broke his haggard face for the first time in a long time.

Sammy the Skull's glowing eyes watched as the Chum Maker's large, scythe-like blade was cranked back from her victim's hull: a five-mast ship that was taking on water from the hole the blade had just vacated.

"Captain, sir," a voice from behind him quivered. "Should we board her?"

"No," said a voice as dry as the desert. "Drop the blade again."

"But, sir. . ."

Sammy turned to the man. His skull face, expressionless as usual, showed nothing, but his voice cut more deeply than the scythe. "Would you like to join them?" His boney hand pointed to the screaming crew on the now quite doomed ship.

"N-n-n-n-no, sir. I'll personally see the blade gets dropped again."

Sammy's attention began to be drawn away from the damned ship to a dark spot forming just under the now-churning sea.

The blade crashed through the ship again, cutting her as if she were no more substantial than a child's toy. The trapped crew began jumping overboard to save themselves, hoping the sea would offer comfort. But Sammy watched as the black spot slowly took shape as tentacles and fins of hundreds of sea creatures boiling just under the surface. He could see them sensing the banquet about to jump unwittingly to their table.

"Dinner time, my pets," Sammy whispered.

column12: Sea Monster. When you give this sea creature a shoot action, you can choose to make only one cannon roll. If you do and the shot hits, eliminate two masts from the target and then place the ship next to this sea creature; this sea creature can immediately initiate a boarding party, but neither is considered to be rammed.
column13: Revered by the natives as the fiercest predator in the sea, He'e can rapidly change the color of its skin to hide itself against any background.

column12: Sea Monster. If this sea creature is within S of both a wild island and a friendly ship, she can place one treasure from that wild island on that ship as a free action.
column13: Intermediaro has a penchant for collecting shiny treasures, a gift the Spanish reward with food for filling their coffers.

column12: Sea Monster, Fear. If this sea creature is within S of a friendly ship when this sea creature is given a move action, it gets +S to its base move.
column13: French ships are unsure of why the "Lurker Below" enjoys following them, though some sailors speculate "she" has an attraction to the red, white, and blue of France.

column12: Eternal, Sea Monster. An opponent may initiate a boarding party against this sea monster. If the opponent wins the boarding party, it may load one of the sea monster's segments. The segment does not take up any cargo space and may be unloaded at the player's home island for +2 gold.
column13: Treasure hunters search the globe for this elusive creature, believed to make its home within the shipwreck of an archaic galley, nesting on a massive cache of sunken gold.

column12: Hoist, Secret Hold.
column13: Constructed in the spirit of exploration, the Frontier pushes ever onward to new horizons.

column12: Hoist. If this ship is within S of an enemy ship when this ship is given a move action, she gets +S to her base move.
column13: Other ships that have met the "Finder" often say she would be better named the "Runner": As soon as she spies enemy ships she tacks quickly to protect her precious cargo.

column12: Galley. When this ship is given a move action, roll a d6 before moving her. On a result of a 5 or 6, place a trade current. On a 1 or 2, eliminate a friendly trade current. On a 3 or 4, this ship gets +S to her base move that action.
column13: Long ago this ship embarked on a mission to chart the known world. Now her crew is cursed to sail for eternity, their task doomed to never be completed.

column12: Galley. Masts on this ship can't be eliminated by shots unless the cannon roll is a 6.
column13: No one is sure how a black cat found her way aboard this ship a few years back, but contrary to the crews initial superstitions, she has brought nothing but good luck since.

column12: Galley. If an enemy ship is within S of this ship, you can use this ship's action for the turn to try to possess a target crew on that ship. Roll a d6; on a result of 6, the target is immediately assigned to this ship. Its nationality changes to match the nationality of this ship.
column13: Legend says that when men venture too close to the realm of the dead, a ship borne by the wings of a thousand ravens will drift silently out of the fog to beckon the living crew to cross over.

column12: Galley. Crew assigned to this ship don't take up cargo space; this ship can be assigned a maximum of three crew.
column13: Under the cover of darkness, the seemingly crewless "Tricksters Spirit" will sneak into sleepy port towns and make off with untold riches.

column12: Captain, Loyal: America, Hostile: Spain. Once per turn, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship may be given an extra action. This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls.
column13: Commodore Stern was sent to the South Pacific to promote friendly relations between America and the islanders-and to turn as many against the Spanish as possible. They say that he has also offered to aid France in its efforts against the English.

column12: Cargo Master, Secret Hold.
column13: Bianco is a marked man. No longer under Alarico Castro's protection and followed by Sebastian Rojo, Bianco knows that if he cannot produce what he stole, he will not return home.

column12: Captain. Instead of giving this ship an action this turn, you can give another ship in your fleet two actions.
column13: A shining star of the French fleet, Capitaine Deleflote has been instructed to hamper England's efforts at trade and exploration. Deleflote has even met with American Commodore Stern to try to enlist American aid in exchange for some well-placed raids on Spanish ships.

column12: Whenever any crew is eliminated, roll a d6; on a result of 6, assign the crew to this ship. Its nationality changes to match the nationality of this ship and it becomes linked to this crew.
column13: Furious at his defeat from Crimson Angel's kiss, the Wraith scours the South Pacific in search of the heart of stone, a relic that will help him overcome the vestiges of his mortality and restore him to his place beside Davy Jones.

column12: This ship's cannons may not be eliminated (masts still may be). If derelict, she cannot shoot.
column13: Able to stand against the greatest of England's warships, the "Angel's Sword" might be the key to France's ultimate victory over the British.

column12: Fear. When this ship hits an enemy ship, you can also eliminate one cargo from that ship.
column13: Those who have encountered the "Witch" whisper tales of mystery and black magic. Some surmise that she is captained by a madman who sold his soul to the devil.

column12: Native Canoe. Once per turn as a free action, you can transfer one treasure from a friendly ship within S of this ship to this ship.
column13: In return for better sail materials, some island dwellers ferry cargo for American ships.

column12: Native Canoe. Each treasure this ship unloads at your home island is worth +1 gold.
column13: Not quite understanding Spain's interest in their bright metals, many natives offer them to Spain in return for new spices.

column12: Native Canoe. If two or more Cursed native canoes hit the same ship on the same turn, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: Some hostile tribes are convinced the influx of visitors is a threat to their simple way of life.

column12: Junk. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: This abandoned ship was discovered resting along a quiet shore. Once again seaworthy, she was renamed for the feisty goose that reluctantly gave up the main mast as it's perch.

column12: Junk. Ramming can't eliminate this ship's masts.
column13: The British captured this armored ship for the Royal Navy, not realizing she's being hunted by other nations.

column12: Junk. As part of a move action, this ship may initiate a boarding party against a ship up to S away from her, without having to ram. The boarded ship may not use any boarding bonuses she may have.
column13: Guardians of an unthinkable horror, the crew of the Demon Gate patrol the southernmost seas, attacking foreign invaders who wander too close.

column12: Junk
column13: The Xi'an and her crew are nearly all that remain of the once powerful Jade Empire.

column12: After this ship resolves a shoot action, she can move as a free action.
column13: Though the ship herself is silent, the crew of the "Laughing Lady" often chuckle heartily at the the epithets hurled by enemy crews after she has fired and run.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, if this ship is within S of an island, you can mark the island as explored without docking at it. The island becomes unexplored in regards to all other players.
column13: The captain of the "Cinnamon" will not give up on the dream of one day finding one of the fabled cities of gold and spices.

column12: When this ship is within S of an enemy ship, she gets +S to her base move during her move action.
column13: Unfazed and uncorrupted from her many entanglements at sea, the majestic HMS Silent Swan inspires courage in every ally she's had the honor to serve with.

column12: This ship can't be shot at while docked.
column13: With threats from Master Bianco tying their fate to his own, Bianco's Haulers do their best to ensure the safety of their ship as they furiously attempt to gather enough treasure to replace what was once skimmed from Spain.

column12: Parley. Once per turn, you can reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: No longer welcome in his strict, Puritan community (though he'll just slyly grin when asked why), this cheerful scoundrel changed his last name and enlisted with the French to seek his fortune.

column12: Explorer, Navigator.
column13: After centuries spent charting the globe and recording the history of the sea, the Master Scribe is resigned to scratching out maps in dim candlelight, unable to find the fabled end of the earth that will at last grant him rest.

column12: Captain. Always place this crew face up; it can't be eliminated unless its ship sinks. Crew placed on this ship cost no points, but still take up cargo spaces. When this ship is hit, roll a d6. On a result of 5 or 6, move the crew on this ship with the highest point cost to a wild island chosen by the player to your left.
column13: Charles Richard returned to shore a changed man and the only living being on a formerly bustling ship.  The tale he told was of the cursed treasure, the Eye of Insanity, which infected his captain and spread to the crew.

column12: Explorer. Once per turn, this ship can move S after loading cargo.
column13: His fortunate blunder onto a Pacific passage from the realm of the Vikings led to Sir Jeremy's assignment to the South Pacific. Some say he seems a changed man, now genuinely bent on exploration instead of his petty collecting of Artifacts.

column12: Captain, Hostile: Spain. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against any non-Pirate ship.
column13: Vowing revenge against the tyranny of his former Spanish comrades, Ramirez's hatred has poisoned his mind. Believed to be dead, fear is now his weapon against the encroaching Spanish empire.

column13: She's no beauty, but the Mongrel has a lot more to offer than the pretty faces of her crew. She is frequently set upon enemy vessels to ensure safe passage.

column12: Junk. Once per turn as part of a move action, this ship can randomly take one treasure from any ship up to S away from her.
column13: As her name implies, the “Winged Fox” specializes in swift raids, stealing from England's fleets. The British Navy has yet to so much scratch her hull.

column12: Junk. Two hits from the same shoot action are required to eliminate one of this ship's masts.
column13: Arrogant sailors of every nation have mistaken the small size of the “Goat's Horn” for weakness—and their pockets have paid dearly for it.

column12: Ghost Ship.
column13: Sailors claim the Faerie Fire glows not from any ethereal light, but from the burning hatred gathered in life and now harbored by the men who crew her.

column12: Schooner. Secret Hold.
column13: Shipwrights constructed many hidden holds within the cargo bay of the HMS Goodfellow. Her singing crew is always greeted with beaming smiles when she returns to port.

column12: Schooner. Once per turn, one of this ship's cannons can shoot again if it misses.
column13: An older vessel, the “Beautiful” has seen many adventures across many seas but has never lost the glow that surrounded her since her maiden voyage.

column12: Place this crew face up during setup. Reduce the cost of all other crew placed on this ship by 1.
column13: Unable to bring himself to see Lady Godiva's fate, the Duc de Valois warned her of Papa Doc's plans for her. Shocked but now armed with the knowledge, Lady Godiva realizes the path to her beloved is fraught with peril, which she will need to overcome to see him again.

column12: Marine. Once per turn, you can eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action.
column13: Rojo's past is steeped in blood. An expert at dealing with natives and policing those disloyal to Spain, Rojo has dedicated himself to ensure that the conquest of the South Pacific is successful.

column12: Musketeer. This ship gets +1 to her cannon rolls against English ships.
column13: Pierce often recalls her father's tales of travel from the South China Seas to the Pacific Triangle. If a man could make his fortune there, perhaps a woman could, too.

column12: This ship gets +1 to her boarding rolls. Once per turn, one crew or ship within S of this ship can't use its ability that turn.
column13: When Duc de Valois failed to deliver Josephine Godiva, Papa Doc turned all his wrath on France. With news of Godiva in the Polynesian triangle, he has begun stopping ships to find her. His luck is doubled by having her so close to the very altar where he plans to sacrifice her.

column12: Once each time this ship is given an action, you can roll 2d6 any time you would roll a d6. Choose the result you want to use.
column13: All was well for Countess Doone until the Doone family showed up in the Caribbean looking for their daughter. Fleeing before disgrace and English authorities could catch up with her, she's on the run trying to cling to the life she's stolen. Or perhaps acquire another one.

column12: Once per turn, this ship can look at one face-down cargo on any ship.
column13: Worthington's odd looks are easily gotten past once one realizes he's one of the best set of eyes available on the high seas. They say he can spy the color of a captain's eyes from leagues away.

column12: Eliminate all but one crew from this ship. If there is a Tribal Chieftain on this ship, you must eliminate only one crew from this ship.
Place three trade currents, and then remove Native Lore from the game.
Load this treasure face down. When revealed, once per turn as a free action roll a d6. On a result of 5 or 6, repair one mast on this ship.
When this treasure is revealed, mark all wild islands as explored and choose any wild island and look at all the face down treasure on that island. Then remove Abandoned Charts from the game.
Shipwright.
Shipwright.
Shipwright.
Shipwright.
Shipwright.
Shipwright.
Cargo Master.
Hoist. If this ship has a crew with the Captain keyword, she gets +L to her base move.
column13: To help make an ally of France, Lady Roimata presented a captured hoist ship. In a return gesture France bid her to keep it in order to help her and her people through the explorations of the newcomers.

column12: This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
column13: France presented the natives with "Paradise" in return for shipwreck treasure. She was quickly renamed in a native tongue and put to work fending off would-be explorers of their shores.

column12: Captain. Once per turn before you give this ship an action, roll a d6. On a 5 or 6, this ship can be given the same action twice.
column13: Suspicious and not very welcoming of the newcomers to her ocean-bound land, Lady Roimata has made overtures towards France for the benefit of her people. French cannons may be put to even better use against neighboring islands.

column12: When this ship is given a shoot action you may double the range of one of her cannons.
Catamaran. This ship can dock at an enemy home island and take as much treasure as she can carry. If able, she must leave on your next turn.
column13: Though working for England, the crew of the Brazen use techniques that are decidedly un-British. Even so, England has yet to complain about the cargo they continually bring in.

column12: Double Catamaran. If this ship is the target of a shoot action, the attacking player must first roll a d6. On a result of 1-3, this target can't be shot at and the attacking player can give their ship another action.
column13: The scattered survivors of pirate ships sunk by various nations have banded together to set sail once again aboard the Orphan.

column12: Windcatcher. On the turn this ship is pinned, eliminate one crew and one mast from the rammed ship.
column13: Crewed entirely by Trogs, this foul vessel actually carries a coral nest beneath her hull. What lives within the nest is known only to the Trogs—and the captives who are lowered into the hull as food.

column12: Turbine. This ship can load cargo from a wild island if she's within S of it.
column13: The French built the “Damselfly” to hunt treasure in distant lands and to always stay one step ahead of the English.

column12: Turbine. When this ship hits an enemy ship, you can also eliminate one cargo from that ship.
column13: The ship formerly known as Kingfisher was “persuaded” to join America's fleet. Taking the name USS Conscript in protest, they tend to destroy cargo rather than return it to their new “compatriots".

column12: Windcatcher. This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her masts.
column13: Named in honor of the warhorse of the legendary Spanish hero, El Cid, the Babieca displays strength and stamina in combat fitting of her namesake.

column12: Junk. Mercenary. Dories. American crew can use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Unwilling to cede the end of the Jade Empire, Huang Bai nonetheless realizes the need to pause and rebuild—as a mercenary. His first customer, America, is eager to pit him and “Golden Axe” against the expanding Spanish empire.

column12: Ex-Patriot. Hostile: Spain. Once per turn, you can eliminate one of this ship's crew to give her an extra action. After looking at treasure on a wild island, you can trade any one treasure from that island for a random treasure on any other wild island. This ship must load the traded treasure.
Junk. Mercenary. Dories. Spanish crew can use their abilities on this ship.
column13: Left behind to clean up after Spain's conflicts with the Jade Rebellion, Castillo decided the life of a mercenary was both more lucrative and somehow more honorable. Despite his past, he and “Fortress” were still hired to assist in Spain's clashes with America.

column12: Captain. Ex-Patriot. Hostile: America. Place this crew face up during setup. Reduce the cost of all other crew placed on this ship by 1.
Octopus, Fear
column13: Named by the Spanish, who frequently encounter its snake-like arms, Ochobrazo seems strangely tied to the Straits of Gibraltar. Some claim the beast has a giant lair under the rock, where a graveyard of destroyed ships sits in the darkness.

Serving far from the front lines and utterly unspectacular in every way, Castigue is where careers in the Spanish Navy go to die. Few are aware she actually exists and even fewer have ever seen her, but the rumors told of Castigue make the mere threat of being punished with a reassignment to her enough to keep even the most troublesome of sailors in line.

column12: This ship may not be shot at while docked.
column13: Tall, noble and sleek - like the bird for which she is named - the Blue Heron proudly crests the waves in search for gold and glory. It is rumored that her crew knows the location of every hidden cove and islet on the Spanish Main.

column12: Sea Dragon. When this ship is given a shoot action, for every cannon roll of 6, the target's controller eliminates an extra mast. For every 1, eliminate a mast from this ship.
column13: French ships have begun to encounter the Old Man with more frequency, but they know this elderly sea dragon's eyesight means it has just as much of a chance of nipping its own tail as it does one or more of their masts.

column12: If this ship wins a boarding party, she can take as much treasure from the other ship as she can carry.
column13: Sailors the world over refuse to say this ship's name, for fear of summoning El Fantasma to their decks.

column12: If this ship has a crew with the Captain keyword, she gets +1 to her cannon rolls.
column13: El Fantasma uses the Wraith to remind every nation that his dominion over the seas is beyond challenge.

column12: Loyal: Cursed. Captain.
column13: El Fantasma knows that there are secrets that the ancient gods have hidden and that few would risk to obtain. He alone intends to discover and unleash those secrets—and then watch as all of humanity bows before him.

column12: Once per turn, you can reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: When “Cannonball” Gallows stumbled across the Charming Mary while she was docked in Havana, he knew two things for certain: He had to have her and her rum.

column12: If this ship has a crew with the Captain keyword, she gets +L to her base move.
column13: Attacked as a distraction while Gallows stole the Charming Mary, the Mercy ended up part of “Cannonball's” fleet as a bonus.

column12: Loyal: Pirate. Captain.
column13: War looms between England and France, and even the pirates are choosing sides. El Fantasma seems to grow stronger and the seas more dangerous. Yet “Cannonball” knows that right now there is nothing he'd rather do than be a freedom-loving pirate.

column5: Eye of the Leviathan (Gem Shard Red & Blue)
column14: Eye of the Leviathan Gem Shard (Blue), 1(Red), 2 (Yellow), 3 (Blue), 4 (Green), 5 (Red), 6 (Yellow), 1 (Blue), 2 (Green)

column5: Eye of the Leviathan (Gem Shard Green & Yellow)
column14: Eye of the Leviathan Gem Shard (Yellow), 1 (Green), 2, (Blue), 3 (Yellow), 4 (Red), 5 (Blue), 6 (Green), 3 (Red), 4 (Yellow)

column1: The following are from official Wizkids documents.

column12: When this ship is at full cargo capacity, her move is S.
This ship sinks when her last mast is removed.
This ship cannot carry crew.
When a ship docks here, you may repair all of her masts.
When this ship is pinned, you may kill a crewman on the ship that pinned you.
When this ship is damaged, remove any crew member, except this one, instead of a mast.
When a ship docks here, roll a D6, on a 5 or 6, the ships loses it's next turn.
If this ship has a Captain, add +1 to the die roll for all cannon shots.
This ship cannot be shot at while docked.
In a turn when this ship damages another ship, the damaged ship loses an extra mast.
When this ship is at full cargo capacity, her move is S.
When your ship docks at an island, on the next turn, place this fort, it not acts as a second home port.
This ship cannot sink. It can be scuttled.

Roll a d6 when this fort is attacked. The result is the amount of musketeers with a 3S attack rating that help defend the fort for this attack. You must defeat all of the musketeers before you destroy any cannons. Musketeers that are not defeated leave after the combat.
This ship eliminates two masts with one hit.
You may give this fort a repair action. It may only repair one cannon per turn.
This fort gets +1 to its cannon rolls when a ship is docked at it.
Once per turn, one of this fort's cannons may shoot again if it misses.
Schooner. This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her masts.
A ship docked here may use its action to look at one face-down cargo on each island.
Reveal this event at the beginning of one of your turns and choose an enemy ship. Roll one d6 for each crew on that ship. On a 6, remove that crew from the game. Remove Mutiny from the game.

Limit. At the beginning of one of your turns, place White Whale any place on the play area (except on islands or terrain). Pick an opponent's ship. That ship must "hunt" the White Whale and cannot dock or attack any other ship. At the start of your turn move White Whale S in any direction. White Whale is defeat if it takes a total of 3 hits by cannon or crew (they do not have to be in the same turn). If the White Whale rams or is rammed remove one mast and one crew from the ship. If the Whale destroys the ship remove it form the game. No other ship can "aid" in destroying the White Whale. No ship can attack the obssessed ship while the Whale is alive. If the Whale is destroyed the cargo hold is full of whale blubber and when it docks at that cargo is worth 10 gold.
Parley.
column13:
“It's not just about living forever, Jackie. It's about living with yourself forever.”
—Captain Teague

column12: If a sea monster begins its move within L of this ship, it gets +L to its base move.
column13: The crew of the USS Loggerhead were given the dubious task of locating reported beasts of the sea and herding them to where they can do the most damage to America's enemies.

column12: This ship gets +S to her base move if she has all of her masts.
column13: Sent to hamper America's efforts at exploration, El Viento Enfermo blows swiftly through the south pacific raining terror on any enemy ship she sees.

column12: Once per turn, this ship can look at one face-down treasure on any island.
column13: Several years after the disappearance of Lord and Lady Alfred Howell at sea, their children comissioned creation of the HMS Howell, with the stipulation that it search for their parents whenever able.

column12: This ship ignores the first hit she takes each turn as long as she has all of her masts.
column13: France would like her enemies to think the Coeur de Diamant is as tough as her namesake, but under a sustained barrage she tends to show her cracks.

column12: If this ship has a crew with the Captain keyword, she gets +L to her base move.
column13: The crew of Volarè may not be able to take to the air, but under a captain's expert direction they fly across the water towards their enemies.

column12: One of this ship's treasures is worth +2 gold when unloaded at your home island.
column13: A man's home may be his castle, but for some pirates a man's home is on the Kisimul raiding for often more-than-expected profit.

column12: Sea Monster. Once per turn when this sea creature hits an enemy ship, also eliminate one crew from that ship.
column13: When young, the beast Le Fléau du Marin began following French ships and feeding off scraps of food thrown over the side. Now full grown, it follows ships into battle looking for tastier morsels to fall over the side.                                                                                –From the Journal of Pierre Aronnax.

column12: Sea Monster. If this sea monster is within S of a friendly ship, it gets +1 to its cannon rolls.
column13:
Sombra de la Nave is often found beneath ships, enjoying in particular the shade provided by large vessels such as the vast Treasure ships of Spain. The creature is said to demolish enemy ships attacking its source of shade.
–From the Journal of Pierre Aronnax.

column12: Junk. When this ship hits another ship, you choose which mast is eliminated.
column13: Apu-Hau's Jewel often appears in the middle of terrible storms; unharmed by wind or wave, to attack ships trapped in the storm. It is rumored to be crewed by the spirits of drowned islanders.

column12: Junk. Once per turn, you can reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: The Sea Orchid's crew is partly made up of islanders curious to learn more about the Americans. The knowledge of the islanders has saved the ship and crew from many dangers.

column12: Hoist. Secret Hold.
column13: Brazos del Dios was constructed by the Spanish as a way to take on Cargo from islands where docking ships would put them in danger.

column12: Give this ship a move action but do not move her. Instead you may transfer one treasure from any ship within S of this ship to this ship.
Once per turn, you can reroll any die roll you make for this ship; you must use the second die roll result.
column13: Shinji Smith's past experience of life on mysterious islands has proven invaluable to the American exploration of new regions. Shinji, however, is still just looking for a place to call home.

column12: This ship's cannons have a range of 2L against sea creatures.
column13: Changed by his time aboard the Nautilus, Pierre Aronnax continues his quest to understand the mysteries of the deep. He is hungry for knowledge of the strange beasts haunting the coasts of the savage shores…the beasts, however, are just hungry.

column12: Hostile: Spain. Captain. Explorer.
column13: Genny Gallows' newly recruited crew may sail for plunder, but Genny now sails the savage shores to save the one thing the Spanish could take away that is truly priceless; the life of her son “Cannonball” Gallows.

column12: When this treasure is revealed, mark all wild islands as explored and choose any wild island and look at all the face down treasure on that island. Then remove Abandoned Charts from the game.
Cargo Master.

Before this treasure is unloaded at your home island roll a d6. On a result of 1-3, eliminate all of this ship's crew. On a result of 4-6, randomly choose four face down coins from any wild islands and place them face up on your home island.
Cargo Master.

Hoist. Secret Hold. If this ship is within S of a friendly ship when it is given a
move action, this ship gets +S to its base move.

column18: Edits

Fixed flavor text of Commodore David Porter: "Backed by the power of the new American government, David Porter was tasked with ridding the area of pirates, using the efficiency of a military operation."
Added apostrophe to "Nemos" in flavor text for Slipstream (MI 301).
Fixed second ability text of Raptor Maw (F&S 226): sea creature instead of "sea monster".
Fixed spelling of Julius Caesar (from "Ceaser") in links on Jonathan Haraden (RV 091 and RV UL091).
Fixed all spellings of Benoit de Marseilles in BC and BCUL (changed from "Marsilles").

Fixed flavor text of USS Thomas Jefferson (SCS 086): pluralized "sea", added hyphen and corrected "freind" to friend. Fixed flavor text spelling on USS Mercury (MI 300) from "Annaloplis" to Annapolis.
Fixed cargo of Le Renard qui Vole (MI 206) - 2, not 1.
Fixed flavor text of Guichuan (DJC 300): hailed instead of "hauled".

Fixed ability text of Lian (PotC 024a): If any crew on this ship with point cost 5 or more would be eliminated, eliminate Lian instead.    Note on Park (PotC 024b) now matches the exact ability text on the card: Original ability text: "If any crew on this ship with point cost 5 or more would be eliminated, eliminate Park instead."
Fixed spelling of Ms. Cheng (from "Mrs. Chang") in flavor text for Grand Dynasty (SCS 001).
Changed USS Atlanta (OE 090) cannons from 3L-4L-2S to 2S-3L-4L.
Added treasure values to Scrye the Explorer (SM PP-375-C): 1,1,1,2,2,2,3,4,5,6
Changed keyword of HMN Rumbarrel (MI 212) from Mercenary to Turtle Ship.

Eliminated extra "is" from ability text for Dr. Forbes Beattie (CC 045), Doctor Urbano Javier (062), Father Rene Bordeaux (RV 064a and RV UL064a), and "Hacksaw" Riley (RV 097a and RV UL097a). Also added comma after "eliminated" for all of their ability texts.
Added a note to F&S 201 (Chain Shot) about how it is a double-sided equipment with two copies of it on the same card.
Fixed "thto" spelling error in flavor text for USS Seattle (OE 146).

Fixed ability text for Bloody Gold and Savage Natives (RotF 210+211). (replaced "Blood Money" with "Bloody Gold" and "Cursed Natives" with "Savage Natives")  Fixed ability text of Captain Jack Sparrow (PotC 058): "This ship can move and shoot using the same move action. When this ship is given an explore action, you can swap a treasure on the wild island with a crew on any friendly ship." (added the word "with")
Fixed spelling errors in Skin Flayer flavor text. (F&S 129)
Deleted "El" from name of Halcon (RotF 007).
Addition to note on MI 029 (Coleoptera): No "correct" version of this game piece exists in the English release of Mysterious Islands. It was corrected in the German version of the set.
Fixed spelling of Intermediaro (SS 002) from "Intermedario". Added note about how the Spanish word spelled correctly is "Intermediario", so it looks like Wizkids misspelled it.
Missing treasure values for generic crew/treasure cards. Added SMUL 112 values from the Scan Project. Likely to add more in future as time allows.
Fixed apostrophe location on name of SCS 214 Dragon's Talon (from after the s to before).
Fixed spelling of F&S Cannoneers (111-116) (removed extra e's).
Changed all Treasure/Generic crew Rarity to "Generic" instead of "Common" (applicable for all generic crew from Spanish Main through Ocean's Edge).  Fixed Savage Shores island note from 110 to 101.
Fixed point cost of HMS Bolingbroke to 9 (from 10) in both SM 1st Edition and SM Unlimited.
Deleted "The" from the UT Cursed Conch name (DJC 107).
GC-001 El Fantasma (Spanish Main 1st Edition) point cost fixed from 4 to 3.
Fixed Le Coeur du Lion in Ocean's Edge (name was "de" instead of "du").
Fixed the middle cannon on Siren's Song to 3L from 2L (RotF 032).
Changed all versions of apostrophe ' to '. Fixed spelling of Musketeer on SMUL 093b. (from "Musketter")
Streamlined notes in Name cells for MI 300-303.
Fixed spelling of Arazure in Arrogant's flavor text (F&S 011). Fixed MI 213 (Obsidian Sun): deleted "HMS" from name, added Turtle Ship ability, and corrected spelling of "emperor" in the flavor text.

Added link to All Spanish ships to Almirante Carlos Pavón y Miranda. Added notes to rarities of HMS Discovery and San Leandro to reflect that their cards show red/common rarity corners. Fixed spelling of Carcharodon. Fixed rarity on the CC-009 Amity (from uncommon to common). Changed OE135 (Squalo) mast count from 4 to 2 and point cost from 12 to 9. Fixed spelling of Specter in RotF story notes. Added Barbary Coast UL136 (Captain crew).
Fixed Phillipe du Brissac's link (Maurice Aristide instead of Maurcie), changed name of Blackgate (no space).
fixed name of the Flying Fish in RV UL, and changed Revenant faction from Spanish to Pirate in SM 1st Edition.
changed point costs on Spanish Main +1 to boards crew to 2 points. (Genny's Red Rampage, Lynch's Noose, Castro's Loyalists)
Santa Teresa name fixed in both versions of SM (no “La”), fixed incorrect game piece types in original version of RV.
Fixed mispelling of Norrington (PotC 080a). Fixed ability text of Spanish Main GS-004. Fixed numbers of OE French ships. Changed “rices” to riches in Thomas Tew's flavor text.
Rigetti>Ragetti. Pintell>Pintel in a flavor text. Handful of game piece type changes, mostly from Ship>Crew or vice versa.
Oarsmen>Oarsman in RV UL, fixed ability text for Homemade Flag (both versions of SM).

Divers point cost from 2 to 1, RV #138 from Oarsmen to Oarsman, deleted “showing” from BC Serpiente's ability text, fixed Admiral Yi's ability text, SCS 030 cost changed from 6 to 2, added cost of 2 to SCS 085, changed DJC Fantasma ability from Captain to Reverse Captain, gave cost to DJC #062, changed abilities of La Catedral del Mar and Dark Fox to Fear from the written-out keyword text, Santos Romanos masts from 3 to 2, fixed Monte Cristo's masts and point cost, fixed ability of L'Eroica, added cannons for Baochuan, fixed mispelling of HMS Auckland and San Theodora, changed Grendel's mast cound from 3 to 2, fixed cost of USS Cheyenne, fixed Squalo's point cost and segment count, fixed Teach's segment count, deleted Ochobrazo from RotF sheet, fixed misspellings of Bombardier, added Explorer ability to F&S Scepter.
Duex-Deux, The Red Skull instead of The Cursed, Alquimista speed from L to S+L, added Fort Brompton's cannons, changed CC #123 from “Specialist” to Cannoneer.
Added cannons to HMS Lord Walpole.
Fixed a few point costs in Spanish Main.
Changed El Raton's base move from S+S to S+L.
Added cannons to the American ships in MI after Xerecs noticed they were missing.
